Form
of
government
Ideology
Political
campaigning
Political
parties
Politics
portal
v
t
e
Politics
from
Greek
politik
affairs
of
cities
is
set
of
activities
that
are
associated
with
making
decisions
in
groups
or
other
forms
of
power
relations
between
individuals
such
as
distribution
of
resources
or
status
The
branch
of
social
science
that
studies
politics
is
referred
to
as
political
science
It
may
be
used
positively
in
context
of
political
solution
which
is
compromising
and
nonviolent
or
descriptively
as
art
or
science
of
government
but
also
often
carries
negative
connotation
For
example
abolitionist
Wendell
Phillips
declared
that
we
do
not
play
politics
antislavery
is
no
halfjest
with
us
The
concept
has
been
defined
in
various
ways
and
different
approaches
have
fundamentally
differing
views
on
whether
it
should
be
used
extensively
or
limitedly
empirically
or
normatively
and
on
whether
conflict
or
cooperation
is
more
essential
to
it
A
variety
of
methods
are
deployed
in
politics
which
include
promoting
ones
own
political
views
among
people
negotiation
with
other
political
subjects
making
laws
and
exercising
force
including
warfare
against
adversaries
Politics
is
exercised
on
wide
range
of
social
levels
from
clans
and
tribes
of
traditional
societies
through
modern
local
governments
companies
and
institutions
up
to
sovereign
states
to
international
level
In
modern
nation
states
people
often
form
political
parties
to
represent
their
ideas
Members
of
party
often
agree
to
take
same
position
on
many
issues
and
agree
to
support
same
changes
to
law
and
same
leaders
An
election
is
usually
competition
between
different
parties
A
political
system
is
framework
which
defines
acceptable
political
methods
within
society
The
history
of
political
thought
can
be
traced
back
to
early
antiquity
with
seminal
works
such
as
Platos
Republic
Aristotles
Politics
Chanakyas
Arthashastra
and
Chanakya
Niti
rd
century
BCE
as
well
as
works
of
Confucius
Contents
Etymology
Definitions
Approaches
Extensive
and
limited
Moralism
and
realism
Conflict
and
cooperation
History
Prehistoric
Early
states
State
formation
Ancient
history
Modern
states
Globalization
Political
science
Political
system
Forms
of
government
Source
of
power
Vertical
integration
State
Constitutions
Political
culture
Political
dysfunction
Political
corruption
Political
conflict
Levels
of
politics
Macropolitics
Mesopolitics
Micropolitics
Political
values
Democracy
Aggregative
Deliberative
Radical
Equality
Leftright
spectrum
Freedom
Authoritarianism
and
libertarianism
See
also
References
Notes
Citations
Bibliography
Further
reading
Etymologyedit
The
English
politics
has
its
roots
in
name
of
Aristotles
classic
work
Politik
which
introduced
Greek
term
politik
affairs
of
cities
In
midth
century
Aristotles
composition
would
be
rendered
in
Early
Modern
English
as
Polettiques
sic
which
would
become
Politics
in
Modern
English
The
singular
politic
first
attested
in
English
in
coming
from
Middle
French
politiqueitself
taking
from
politicus
Latinization
of
Greek
politikos
from
polites
citizen
and
polis
city
Definitionsedit
In
view
of
Harold
Lasswell
politics
is
who
gets
what
when
how
For
David
Easton
it
is
about
authoritative
allocation
of
values
for
society
To
Vladimir
Lenin
politics
is
most
concentrated
expression
of
economics
Bernard
Crick
argued
that
politics
is
distinctive
form
of
rule
whereby
people
act
together
through
institutionalized
procedures
to
resolve
differences
to
conciliate
diverse
interests
and
values
and
to
make
public
policies
in
pursuit
of
common
purposes
According
to
Adrian
Leftwich
Politics
comprises
all
activities
of
cooperation
negotiation
and
conflict
within
and
between
societies
whereby
people
go
about
organizing
use
production
or
distribution
of
human
natural
and
other
resources
in
course
of
production
and
reproduction
of
their
biological
and
social
life
Approachesedit
There
are
several
ways
in
which
approaching
politics
has
been
conceptualized
Extensive
and
limitededit
Adrian
Leftwich
has
differentiated
views
of
politics
based
on
how
extensive
or
limited
their
perception
of
what
accounts
as
political
is
The
extensive
view
sees
politics
as
present
across
sphere
of
human
social
relations
while
limited
view
restricts
it
to
certain
contexts
For
example
in
more
restrictive
way
politics
may
be
viewed
as
primarily
about
governance
while
feminist
perspective
could
argue
that
sites
which
have
been
viewed
traditionally
as
nonpolitical
should
indeed
be
viewed
as
political
as
well
This
latter
position
is
encapsulated
in
slogan
personal
is
political
which
disputes
distinction
between
private
and
public
issues
Instead
politics
may
be
defined
by
use
of
power
as
has
been
argued
by
Robert
A
Dahl
Moralism
and
realismedit
Some
perspectives
on
politics
view
it
empirically
as
exercise
of
power
while
others
see
it
as
social
function
with
normative
basis
This
distinction
has
been
called
difference
between
political
moralism
and
political
realism
For
moralists
politics
is
closely
linked
to
ethics
and
is
at
its
extreme
in
utopian
thinking
For
example
according
to
Hannah
Arendt
view
of
Aristotle
was
that
to
be
politicalmeant
that
everything
was
decided
through
words
and
persuasion
and
not
through
violence
while
according
to
Bernard
Crick
politics
is
way
in
which
free
societies
are
governed
Politics
is
politics
and
other
forms
of
rule
are
something
else
In
contrast
for
realists
represented
by
those
such
as
Niccol
Machiavelli
Thomas
Hobbes
and
Harold
Lasswell
politics
is
based
on
use
of
power
irrespective
of
ends
being
pursued
Conflict
and
cooperationedit
Agonism
argues
that
politics
essentially
comes
down
to
conflict
between
conflicting
interests
Political
scientist
Elmer
Schattschneider
argued
that
at
root
of
all
politics
is
universal
language
of
conflict
while
for
Carl
Schmitt
essence
of
politics
is
distinction
of
friend
from
foe
This
is
in
direct
contrast
to
more
cooperative
views
of
politics
by
Aristotle
and
Crick
However
more
mixed
view
between
these
extremes
is
provided
by
Irish
political
scientist
Michael
Laver
who
noted
that
Politics
is
about
characteristic
blend
of
conflict
and
cooperation
that
can
be
found
so
often
in
human
interactions
Pure
conflict
is
war
Pure
cooperation
is
true
love
Politics
is
mixture
of
both
Historyedit
Main
article
Political
history
of
world
See
also
History
of
political
thought
The
history
of
politics
spans
human
history
and
is
not
limited
to
modern
institutions
of
government
Prehistoricedit
Frans
de
Waal
argued
that
already
chimpanzees
engage
in
politics
through
social
manipulation
to
secure
and
maintain
influential
positions
Early
human
forms
of
social
organizationbands
and
tribeslacked
centralized
political
structures
These
are
sometimes
referred
to
as
stateless
societies
Early
statesedit
In
ancient
history
civilizations
did
not
have
definite
boundaries
as
states
have
today
and
their
borders
could
be
more
accurately
described
as
frontiers
Early
dynastic
Sumer
and
early
dynastic
Egypt
were
first
civilizations
to
define
their
borders
Moreover
up
to
th
century
many
people
lived
in
nonstate
societies
These
range
from
relatively
egalitarian
bands
and
tribes
to
complex
and
highly
stratified
chiefdoms
State
formationedit
Main
article
State
formation
There
are
number
of
different
theories
and
hypotheses
regarding
early
state
formation
that
seek
generalizations
to
explain
why
state
developed
in
some
places
but
not
others
Other
scholars
believe
that
generalizations
are
unhelpful
and
that
each
case
of
early
state
formation
should
be
treated
on
its
own
Voluntary
theories
contend
that
diverse
groups
of
people
came
together
to
form
states
as
result
of
some
shared
rational
interest
The
theories
largely
focus
on
development
of
agriculture
and
population
and
organizational
pressure
that
followed
and
resulted
in
state
formation
One
of
most
prominent
theories
of
early
and
primary
state
formation
is
hydraulic
hypothesis
which
contends
that
state
was
result
of
need
to
build
and
maintain
largescale
irrigation
projects
Conflict
theories
of
state
formation
regard
conflict
and
dominance
of
some
population
over
another
population
as
key
to
formation
of
states
In
contrast
with
voluntary
theories
these
arguments
believe
that
people
do
not
voluntarily
agree
to
create
state
to
maximize
benefits
but
that
states
form
due
to
some
form
of
oppression
by
one
group
over
others
Some
theories
in
turn
argue
that
warfare
was
critical
for
state
formation
Ancient
historyedit
The
first
states
of
sorts
were
those
of
early
dynastic
Sumer
and
early
dynastic
Egypt
which
arose
from
Uruk
period
and
Predynastic
Egypt
respectively
around
approximately
BCE
Early
dynastic
Egypt
was
based
around
Nile
River
in
northeast
of
Africa
kingdoms
boundaries
being
based
around
Nile
and
stretching
to
areas
where
oases
existed
Early
dynastic
Sumer
was
located
in
southern
Mesopotamia
with
its
borders
extending
from
Persian
Gulf
to
parts
of
Euphrates
and
Tigris
rivers
Although
stateforms
existed
before
rise
of
Ancient
Greek
empire
Greeks
were
first
people
known
to
have
explicitly
formulated
political
philosophy
of
state
and
to
have
rationally
analyzed
political
institutions
Prior
to
this
states
were
described
and
justified
in
terms
of
religious
myths
Several
important
political
innovations
of
classical
antiquity
came
from
Greek
citystates
polis
and
Roman
Republic
The
Greek
citystates
before
th
century
granted
citizenship
rights
to
their
free
population
in
Athens
these
rights
were
combined
with
directly
democratic
form
of
government
that
was
to
have
long
afterlife
in
political
thought
and
historycitation
needed
Modern
statesedit
Women
voter
outreach
The
Peace
of
Westphalia
is
considered
by
political
scientists
to
be
beginning
of
modern
international
system
in
which
external
powers
should
avoid
interfering
in
another
countrys
domestic
affairs
The
principle
of
noninterference
in
other
countries
domestic
affairs
was
laid
out
in
midth
century
by
Swiss
jurist
Emer
de
Vattel
States
became
primary
institutional
agents
in
interstate
system
of
relations
The
Peace
of
Westphalia
is
said
to
have
ended
attempts
to
impose
supranational
authority
on
European
states
The
Westphalian
doctrine
of
states
as
independent
agents
was
bolstered
by
rise
in
th
century
thought
of
nationalism
under
which
legitimate
states
were
assumed
to
correspond
to
nationsgroups
of
people
united
by
language
and
culture
In
Europe
during
th
century
classic
nonnational
states
were
multinational
empires
Austrian
Empire
Kingdom
of
France
Kingdom
of
Hungary
Russian
Empire
Spanish
Empire
Ottoman
Empire
and
British
Empire
Such
empires
also
existed
in
Asia
Africa
and
Americas
in
Muslim
world
immediately
after
death
of
Muhammad
in
Caliphates
were
established
which
developed
into
multiethnic
transnational
empires
The
multinational
empire
was
absolute
monarchy
ruled
by
king
emperor
or
sultan
The
population
belonged
to
many
ethnic
groups
and
they
spoke
many
languages
The
empire
was
dominated
by
one
ethnic
group
and
their
language
was
usually
language
of
public
administration
The
ruling
dynasty
was
usually
but
not
always
from
that
group
Some
of
smaller
European
states
were
not
so
ethnically
diverse
but
were
also
dynastic
states
ruled
by
royal
house
A
few
of
smaller
states
survived
such
as
independent
principalities
of
Liechtenstein
Andorra
Monaco
and
republic
of
San
Marino
Most
theories
see
nation
state
as
thcentury
European
phenomenon
facilitated
by
developments
such
as
statemandated
education
mass
literacy
and
mass
media
However
historianswho
also
note
early
emergence
of
relatively
unified
state
and
identity
in
Portugal
and
Dutch
Republic
Scholars
such
as
Steven
Weber
David
Woodward
Michel
Foucault
and
Jeremy
Black
have
advanced
hypothesis
that
nation
state
did
not
arise
out
of
political
ingenuity
or
unknown
undetermined
source
nor
was
it
accident
of
history
or
political
invention
Rather
nation
state
is
inadvertent
byproduct
of
thcentury
intellectual
discoveries
in
political
economy
capitalism
mercantilism
political
geography
and
geography
combined
together
with
cartography
and
advances
in
mapmaking
technologies
Some
nation
states
such
as
Germany
and
Italy
came
into
existence
at
least
partly
as
result
of
political
campaigns
by
nationalists
during
th
century
In
both
cases
territory
was
previously
divided
among
other
states
some
of
them
very
small
Liberal
ideas
of
free
trade
played
role
in
German
unification
which
was
preceded
by
customs
union
Zollverein
National
selfdetermination
was
key
aspect
of
United
States
President
Woodrow
Wilsons
Fourteen
Points
leading
to
dissolution
of
AustroHungarian
Empire
and
Ottoman
Empire
after
First
World
War
while
Russian
Empire
became
Soviet
Union
after
Russian
Civil
War
Decolonization
lead
to
creation
of
new
nation
states
in
place
of
multinational
empires
in
Third
World
Globalizationedit
Main
article
Political
globalization
Political
globalization
began
in
th
century
through
intergovernmental
organizations
and
supranational
unions
The
League
of
Nations
was
founded
after
World
War
I
and
after
World
War
II
it
was
replaced
by
United
Nations
Various
international
treaties
have
been
signed
through
it
Regional
integration
has
been
pursued
by
African
Union
ASEAN
European
Union
and
Mercosur
International
political
institutions
on
international
level
include
International
Criminal
Court
International
Monetary
Fund
and
World
Trade
Organization
Political
scienceedit
This
section
does
not
cite
any
sources
Please
help
improve
this
section
by
adding
citations
to
reliable
sources
Unsourced
material
may
be
challenged
and
removed

how
and
when
to
remove
this
template
message
Main
article
Political
science
Plato
left
and
Aristotle
right
from
detail
of
The
School
of
Athens
fresco
by
Raphael
Platos
Republic
and
Aristotles
Politics
secured
two
Greek
philosophers
as
two
of
most
influential
political
philosophers
The
study
of
politics
is
called
political
science
or
politology
It
comprises
numerous
subfields
including
comparative
politics
political
economy
international
relations
political
philosophy
public
administration
public
policy
gender
and
politics
and
political
methodology
Furthermore
political
science
is
related
to
and
draws
upon
fields
of
economics
law
sociology
history
philosophy
geography
psychologypsychiatry
anthropology
and
neurosciences
Comparative
politics
is
science
of
comparison
and
teaching
of
different
types
of
constitutions
political
actors
legislature
and
associated
fields
all
of
them
from
intrastate
perspective
International
relations
deals
with
interaction
between
nationstates
as
well
as
intergovernmental
and
transnational
organizations
Political
philosophy
is
more
concerned
with
contributions
of
various
classical
and
contemporary
thinkers
and
philosophers
Political
science
is
methodologically
diverse
and
appropriates
many
methods
originating
in
psychology
social
research
and
cognitive
neuroscience
Approaches
include
positivism
interpretivism
rational
choice
theory
behavioralism
structuralism
poststructuralism
realism
institutionalism
and
pluralism
Political
science
as
one
of
social
sciences
uses
methods
and
techniques
that
relate
to
kinds
of
inquiries
sought
primary
sources
such
as
historical
documents
and
official
records
secondary
sources
such
as
scholarly
journal
articles
survey
research
statistical
analysis
case
studies
experimental
research
and
model
building
Political
systemedit
Main
article
Political
system
See
also
Systems
theory
in
political
science
Systems
view
of
politics
The
political
system
defines
process
for
making
official
government
decisions
It
is
usually
compared
to
legal
system
economic
system
cultural
system
and
other
social
systems
According
to
David
Easton
A
political
system
can
be
designated
as
interactions
through
which
values
are
authoritatively
allocated
for
society
Each
political
system
is
embedded
in
society
with
its
own
political
culture
and
they
in
turn
shape
their
societies
through
public
policy
The
interactions
between
different
political
systems
are
basis
for
global
politics
Forms
of
governmentedit
Legislatures
are
important
political
institution
Pictured
is
Parliament
of
Finland
Forms
of
government
can
be
classified
by
several
ways
In
terms
of
structure
of
power
there
are
monarchies
including
constitutional
monarchies
and
republics
usually
presidential
semipresidential
or
parliamentary
The
separation
of
powers
describes
degree
of
horizontal
integration
between
legislature
executive
judiciary
and
other
independent
institutions
Source
of
poweredit
The
source
of
power
determines
difference
between
democracies
oligarchies
and
autocracies
In
democracy
political
legitimacy
is
based
on
popular
sovereignty
Forms
of
democracy
include
representative
democracy
direct
democracy
and
demarchy
These
are
separated
by
way
decisions
are
made
whether
by
elected
representatives
referendums
or
by
citizen
juries
Democracies
can
be
either
republics
or
constitutional
monarchies
Oligarchy
is
power
structure
where
minority
rules
These
may
be
in
form
of
anocracy
aristocracy
ergatocracy
geniocracy
gerontocracy
kakistocracy
kleptocracy
meritocracy
noocracy
particracy
plutocracy
stratocracy
technocracy
theocracy
or
timocracy
Autocracies
are
either
dictatorships
including
military
dictatorships
or
absolute
monarchies
The
pathway
of
regional
integration
or
separation
Vertical
integrationedit
In
terms
of
level
of
vertical
integration
political
systems
can
be
divided
into
from
least
to
most
integrated
confederations
federations
and
unitary
states
A
federation
also
known
as
federal
state
is
political
entity
characterized
by
union
of
partially
selfgoverning
provinces
states
or
other
regions
under
central
federal
government
federalism
In
federation
selfgoverning
status
of
component
states
as
well
as
division
of
power
between
them
and
central
government
is
typically
constitutionally
entrenched
and
may
not
be
altered
by
unilateral
decision
of
either
party
states
or
federal
political
body
Federations
were
formed
first
in
Switzerland
then
in
United
States
in
in
Canada
in
and
in
Germany
in
and
in
Australia
Compared
to
federation
confederation
has
less
centralized
power
Stateedit
Federal
states
Unitary
states
No
government
All
above
forms
of
government
are
variations
of
same
basic
polity
sovereign
state
The
state
has
been
defined
by
Max
Weber
as
political
entity
that
has
monopoly
on
violence
within
its
territory
while
Montevideo
Convention
holds
that
states
need
to
have
defined
territory
permanent
population
government
and
capacity
to
enter
into
international
relations
A
stateless
society
is
society
that
is
not
governed
by
state
In
stateless
societies
there
is
little
concentration
of
authority
most
positions
of
authority
that
do
exist
are
very
limited
in
power
and
are
generally
not
permanently
held
positions
and
social
bodies
that
resolve
disputes
through
predefined
rules
tend
to
be
small
Stateless
societies
are
highly
variable
in
economic
organization
and
cultural
practices
While
stateless
societies
were
norm
in
human
prehistory
few
stateless
societies
exist
today
almost
entire
global
population
resides
within
jurisdiction
of
sovereign
state
In
some
regions
nominal
state
authorities
may
be
very
weak
and
wield
little
or
no
actual
power
Over
course
of
history
most
stateless
peoples
have
been
integrated
into
statebased
societies
around
them
Some
political
philosophies
consider
state
undesirable
and
thus
consider
formation
of
stateless
society
goal
to
be
achieved
A
central
tenet
of
anarchism
is
advocacy
of
society
without
states
The
type
of
society
sought
for
varies
significantly
between
anarchist
schools
of
thought
ranging
from
extreme
individualism
to
complete
collectivism
In
Marxism
Marxs
theory
of
state
considers
that
in
postcapitalist
society
state
undesirable
institution
would
be
unnecessary
and
wither
away
A
related
concept
is
that
of
stateless
communism
phrase
sometimes
used
to
describe
Marxs
anticipated
postcapitalist
society
Constitutionsedit
Constitutions
are
written
documents
that
specify
and
limit
powers
of
different
branches
of
government
Although
constitution
is
written
document
there
is
also
unwritten
constitution
The
unwritten
constitution
is
continually
being
written
by
legislative
and
judiciary
branch
of
government
this
is
just
one
of
those
cases
in
which
nature
of
circumstances
determines
form
of
government
that
is
most
appropriate
England
did
set
fashion
of
written
constitutions
during
Civil
War
but
after
Restoration
abandoned
them
to
be
taken
up
later
by
American
Colonies
after
their
emancipation
and
then
France
after
Revolution
and
rest
of
Europe
including
European
colonies
Constitutions
often
set
out
separation
of
powers
dividing
government
into
executive
legislature
and
judiciary
together
referred
to
as
trias
politica
in
order
to
achieve
checks
and
balances
within
state
Additional
independent
branches
may
also
be
created
including
civil
service
commissions
election
commissions
and
supreme
audit
institutions
Political
cultureedit
InglehartWeltzel
cultural
map
of
countries
Political
culture
describes
how
culture
impacts
politics
Every
political
system
is
embedded
in
particular
political
culture
Lucian
Pyes
definition
is
that
Political
culture
is
set
of
attitudes
beliefs
and
sentiments
which
give
order
and
meaning
to
political
process
and
which
provide
underlying
assumptions
and
rules
that
govern
behavior
in
political
system
Trust
is
major
factor
in
political
culture
as
its
level
determines
capacity
of
state
to
function
Postmaterialism
is
degree
to
which
political
culture
is
concerned
with
issues
which
are
not
of
immediate
physical
or
material
concern
such
as
human
rights
and
environmentalism
Religion
has
also
impact
on
political
culture
Political
dysfunctionedit
Political
corruptionedit
Main
article
Political
corruption
Political
corruption
is
use
of
powers
for
illegitimate
private
gain
conducted
by
government
officials
or
their
network
contacts
Forms
of
political
corruption
include
bribery
cronyism
nepotism
and
political
patronage
Forms
of
political
patronage
in
turn
includes
clientelism
earmarking
pork
barreling
slush
funds
and
spoils
systems
as
well
as
political
machines
which
is
political
system
that
operates
for
corrupt
ends
When
corruption
is
embedded
in
political
culture
this
may
be
referred
to
as
patrimonialism
or
neopatrimonialism
A
form
of
government
that
is
built
on
corruption
is
called
kleptocracy
rule
of
thieves
Political
conflictedit
Main
article
Political
conflict
Political
conflict
entails
use
of
political
violence
to
achieve
political
ends
As
noted
by
Carl
von
Clausewitz
War
is
mere
continuation
of
politics
by
other
means
Beyond
just
interstate
warfare
this
may
include
civil
war
wars
of
national
liberation
or
asymmetric
warfare
such
as
guerrilla
war
or
terrorism
When
political
system
is
overthrown
event
is
called
revolution
it
is
political
revolution
if
it
does
not
go
further
or
social
revolution
if
social
system
is
also
radically
altered
However
these
may
also
be
nonviolent
revolutions
Levels
of
politicsedit
Macropoliticsedit
Main
article
Global
politics
Macropolitics
can
either
describe
political
issues
that
affect
entire
political
system
eg
nation
state
or
refer
to
interactions
between
political
systems
eg
international
relations
Global
politics
or
world
politics
covers
all
aspects
of
politics
that
affect
multiple
political
systems
in
practice
meaning
any
political
phenomenon
crossing
national
borders
This
can
include
cities
nationstates
multinational
corporations
nongovernmental
organizations
andor
international
organizations
An
important
element
is
international
relations
relations
between
nationstates
may
be
peaceful
when
they
are
conducted
through
diplomacy
or
they
may
be
violent
which
is
described
as
war
States
that
are
able
to
exert
strong
international
influence
are
referred
to
as
superpowers
whereas
lesspowerful
ones
may
be
called
regional
or
middle
powers
The
international
system
of
power
is
called
world
order
which
is
affected
by
balance
of
power
that
defines
degree
of
polarity
in
system
Emerging
powers
are
potentially
destabilizing
to
it
especially
if
they
display
revanchism
or
irredentism
Politics
inside
limits
of
political
systems
which
in
contemporary
context
correspond
to
national
borders
are
referred
to
as
domestic
politics
This
includes
most
forms
of
public
policy
such
as
social
policy
economic
policy
or
law
enforcement
which
are
executed
by
state
bureaucracy
Mesopoliticsedit
Mesopolitics
describes
politics
of
intermediary
structures
within
political
system
such
as
national
political
parties
or
movements
A
political
party
is
political
organization
that
typically
seeks
to
attain
and
maintain
political
power
within
government
usually
by
participating
in
political
campaigns
educational
outreach
or
protest
actions
Parties
often
espouse
expressed
ideology
or
vision
bolstered
by
written
platform
with
specific
goals
forming
coalition
among
disparate
interests
Political
parties
within
particular
political
system
together
form
party
system
which
can
be
either
multiparty
twoparty
dominantparty
or
oneparty
depending
on
level
of
pluralism
This
is
affected
by
characteristics
of
political
system
including
its
electoral
system
According
to
Duvergers
law
firstpastpost
systems
are
likely
to
lead
to
twoparty
systems
while
proportional
representation
systems
are
more
likely
to
create
multiparty
system
Micropoliticsedit
Micropolitics
describes
actions
of
individual
actors
within
political
system
This
is
often
described
as
political
participation
Political
participation
may
take
many
forms
including
Activism
Boycott
Civil
disobedience
Demonstration
Petition
Picketing
Strike
action
Tax
resistance
Voting
or
its
opposite
abstentionism
Political
valuesedit
Main
article
Political
philosophy
Democracyedit
Part
of
Politics
series
Democracy

Theory

regime

democracy

topics

assembly

centralism

confederalism

republic

socialism

and
economic
growth
Democracy
in
Marxism
Democracy
promotion
Kleroterion
Liberalism
Libertarianism
Majoritarianism
Motion
Ochlocracy
Peaceful
transition
of
power
Peoples
democratic
dictatorship
Polyarchy
Populism
Sortition
Tyranny
of
majority
Voting
Wars
between
democracies
Waves
of
democracy
Politics
portal
v
t
e
Main
article
Democracy
Democracy
is
system
of
processing
conflicts
in
which
outcomes
depend
on
what
participants
do
but
no
single
force
controls
what
occurs
and
its
outcomes
The
uncertainty
of
outcomes
is
inherent
in
democracy
Democracy
makes
all
forces
struggle
repeatedly
to
realize
their
interests
and
devolves
power
from
groups
of
people
to
sets
of
rules
Among
modern
political
theorists
there
are
three
contending
conceptions
of
democracy
aggregative
deliberative
and
radical
Aggregativeedit
The
theory
of
aggregative
democracy
claims
that
aim
of
democratic
processes
is
to
solicit
preferences
of
citizens
and
aggregate
them
together
to
determine
what
social
policies
society
should
adopt
Therefore
proponents
of
this
view
hold
that
democratic
participation
should
primarily
focus
on
voting
where
policy
with
most
votes
gets
implemented
Different
variants
of
aggregative
democracy
exist
Under
minimalism
democracy
is
system
of
government
in
which
citizens
have
given
teams
of
political
leaders
right
to
rule
in
periodic
elections
According
to
this
minimalist
conception
citizens
cannot
and
should
not
rule
because
for
example
on
most
issues
most
of
time
they
have
no
clear
views
or
their
views
are
not
wellfounded
Joseph
Schumpeter
articulated
this
view
most
famously
in
his
book
Capitalism
Socialism
and
Democracy
Contemporary
proponents
of
minimalism
include
William
H
Riker
Adam
Przeworski
Richard
Posner
According
to
theory
of
direct
democracy
on
other
hand
citizens
should
vote
directly
not
through
their
representatives
on
legislative
proposals
Proponents
of
direct
democracy
offer
varied
reasons
to
support
this
view
Political
activity
can
be
valuable
in
itself
it
socializes
and
educates
citizens
and
popular
participation
can
check
powerful
elites
Most
importantly
citizens
do
not
rule
themselves
unless
they
directly
decide
laws
and
policies
Governments
will
tend
to
produce
laws
and
policies
that
are
close
to
views
of
median
voterwith
half
to
their
left
and
other
half
to
their
right
This
is
not
desirable
outcome
as
it
represents
action
of
selfinterested
and
somewhat
unaccountable
political
elites
competing
for
votes
Anthony
Downs
suggests
that
ideological
political
parties
are
necessary
to
act
as
mediating
broker
between
individual
and
governments
Downs
laid
out
this
view
in
his
book
An
Economic
Theory
of
Democracy
Robert
A
Dahl
argues
that
fundamental
democratic
principle
is
that
when
it
comes
to
binding
collective
decisions
each
person
in
political
community
is
entitled
to
have
hisher
interests
be
given
equal
consideration
not
necessarily
that
all
people
are
equally
satisfied
by
collective
decision
He
uses
term
polyarchy
to
refer
to
societies
in
which
there
exists
certain
set
of
institutions
and
procedures
which
are
perceived
as
leading
to
such
democracy
First
and
foremost
among
these
institutions
is
regular
occurrence
of
free
and
open
elections
which
are
used
to
select
representatives
who
then
manage
all
or
most
of
public
policy
of
society
However
these
polyarchic
procedures
may
not
create
full
democracy
if
for
example
poverty
prevents
political
participation
Similarly
Ronald
Dworkin
argues
that
democracy
is
substantive
not
merely
procedural
ideal
Deliberativeedit
Main
article
Deliberative
democracy
Deliberative
democracy
is
based
on
notion
that
democracy
is
government
by
deliberation
Unlike
aggregative
democracy
deliberative
democracy
holds
that
for
democratic
decision
to
be
legitimate
it
must
be
preceded
by
authentic
deliberation
not
merely
aggregation
of
preferences
that
occurs
in
voting
Authentic
deliberation
is
deliberation
among
decisionmakers
that
is
free
from
distortions
of
unequal
political
power
such
as
power
decisionmaker
obtained
through
economic
wealth
or
support
of
interest
groups
If
decisionmakers
cannot
reach
consensus
after
authentically
deliberating
on
proposal
then
they
vote
on
proposal
using
form
of
majority
rule
Radicaledit
Main
article
Radical
democracy
Radical
democracy
is
based
on
idea
that
there
are
hierarchical
and
oppressive
power
relations
that
exist
in
society
Democracys
role
is
to
make
visible
and
challenge
those
relations
by
allowing
for
difference
dissent
and
antagonisms
in
decisionmaking
processes
Equalityedit
Twoaxis
political
compass
chart
with
horizontal
socioeconomic
axis
and
vertical
sociocultural
axis
and
ideologically
representative
political
colours
example
for
frequently
used
model
of
political
spectrum
Three
axis
model
of
political
ideologies
with
both
moderate
and
radical
versions
and
goals
of
their
policies
Main
article
Social
equality
Equality
is
state
of
affairs
in
which
all
people
within
specific
society
or
isolated
group
have
same
social
status
especially
socioeconomic
status
including
protection
of
human
rights
and
dignity
and
equal
access
to
certain
social
goods
and
social
services
Furthermore
it
may
also
include
health
equality
economic
equality
and
other
social
securities
Social
equality
requires
absence
of
legally
enforced
social
class
or
caste
boundaries
and
absence
of
discrimination
motivated
by
inalienable
part
of
persons
identity
To
this
end
there
must
be
equal
justice
under
law
and
equal
opportunity
regardless
of
for
example
sex
gender
ethnicity
age
sexual
orientation
origin
caste
or
class
income
or
property
language
religion
convictions
opinions
health
or
disability
Leftright
spectrumedit
A
common
way
of
understanding
politics
is
through
leftright
political
spectrum
which
ranges
from
leftwing
politics
via
centrism
to
rightwing
politics
This
classification
is
comparatively
recent
and
dates
from
French
Revolution
when
those
members
of
National
Assembly
who
supported
republic
common
people
and
secular
society
sat
on
left
and
supporters
of
monarchy
aristocratic
privilege
and
Church
sat
on
right
Today
left
is
generally
progressivist
seeking
social
progress
in
society
The
more
extreme
elements
of
left
named
farleft
tend
to
support
revolutionary
means
for
achieving
this
This
includes
ideologies
such
as
Communism
and
Marxism
The
centerleft
on
other
hand
advocate
for
more
reformist
approaches
for
example
that
of
social
democracy
In
contrast
right
is
generally
motivated
by
conservatism
which
seeks
to
conserve
what
it
sees
as
important
elements
of
society
The
farright
goes
beyond
this
and
often
represents
reactionary
turn
against
progress
seeking
to
undo
it
Examples
of
such
ideologies
have
included
Fascism
and
Nazism
The
centerright
may
be
less
clearcut
and
more
mixed
in
this
regard
with
neoconservatives
supporting
spread
of
democracy
and
onenation
conservatives
more
open
to
social
welfare
programs
According
to
Norberto
Bobbio
one
of
major
exponents
of
this
distinction
left
believes
in
attempting
to
eradicate
social
inequalitybelieving
it
to
be
unethical
or
unnatural
while
right
regards
most
social
inequality
as
result
of
ineradicable
natural
inequalities
and
sees
attempts
to
enforce
social
equality
as
utopian
or
authoritarian
Some
ideologies
notably
Christian
Democracy
claim
to
combine
left
and
rightwing
politics
according
to
Geoffrey
K
Roberts
and
Patricia
Hogwood
In
terms
of
ideology
Christian
Democracy
has
incorporated
many
of
views
held
by
liberals
conservatives
and
socialists
within
wider
framework
of
moral
and
Christian
principles
Movements
which
claim
or
formerly
claimed
to
be
above
leftright
divide
include
Fascist
Terza
Posizione
economic
politics
in
Italy
and
Peronism
in
Argentina
Freedomedit
Main
article
Political
freedom
Political
freedom
also
known
as
political
liberty
or
autonomy
is
central
concept
in
political
thought
and
one
of
most
important
features
of
democratic
societies
Negative
liberty
has
been
described
as
freedom
from
oppression
or
coercion
and
unreasonable
external
constraints
on
action
often
enacted
through
civil
and
political
rights
while
positive
liberty
is
absence
of
disabling
conditions
for
individual
and
fulfillment
of
enabling
conditions
eg
economic
compulsion
in
society
This
capability
approach
to
freedom
requires
economic
social
and
cultural
rights
in
order
to
be
realized
Authoritarianism
and
libertarianismedit
Authoritarianism
and
libertarianism
disagree
amount
of
individual
freedom
each
person
possesses
in
that
society
relative
to
state
One
author
describes
authoritarian
political
systems
as
those
where
individual
rights
and
goals
are
subjugated
to
group
goals
expectations
and
conformities
while
libertarians
generally
oppose
state
and
hold
individual
as
sovereign
In
their
purest
form
libertarians
are
anarchists
who
argue
for
total
abolition
of
state
of
political
parties
and
of
other
political
entities
while
purest
authoritarians
are
by
definition
totalitarians
who
support
state
control
over
all
aspects
of
society
For
instance
classical
liberalism
also
known
as
laissezfaire
liberalism
is
doctrine
stressing
individual
freedom
and
limited
government
This
includes
importance
of
human
rationality
individual
property
rights
free
markets
natural
rights
protection
of
civil
liberties
constitutional
limitation
of
government
and
individual
freedom
from
restraint
as
exemplified
in
writings
of
John
Locke
Adam
Smith
David
Hume
David
Ricardo
Voltaire
Montesquieu
and
others
According
to
libertarian
Institute
for
Humane
Studies
libertarian
or
classical
liberal
perspective
is
that
individual
wellbeing
prosperity
and
social
harmony
are
fostered
by
as
much
liberty
as
possible
and
as
little
government
as
necessary
For
anarchist
political
philosopher
L
Susan
Brown
liberalism
and
anarchism
are
two
political
philosophies
that
are
fundamentally
concerned
with
individual
freedom
yet
differ
from
one
another
in
very
distinct
ways
Anarchism
shares
with
liberalism
radical
commitment
to
individual
freedom
while
rejecting
liberalisms
competitive
property
relations

alsoedit

portal
v
t

Politics
is
process
by
which
groups
of
people
make
decisionscitation
needed
Although
term
is
generally
applied
to
behavior
within
civil
governments
politics
is
observed
in
all
human
group
interactions
including
corporate
academic
and
religious
institutions
Politics
consists
of
social
relations
involving
authority
or
power
The
definition
of
politics
from
The
Free
Dictionary
is
study
of
political
behavior
and
examines
acquisition
and
application
of
power
Politics
study
include
political
philosophy
which
seeks
rationale
for
politics
and
ethic
of
public
behavior
and
public
administration
which
examines
practices

governance

Politics
exercise
of
power
process
by
which
groups
of
people
make
collective
decisions
Politics
is
art
or
science
of
running
governmental
or
state
affairs
including
behavior
within
civil
governments
institutions
fields
and
special
interest
groups
such
as
corporate
academic
and
religious
segments
of
society

science
field
concerning

and
practice
of
politics
and
description
and
analysis
of
political
systems
and
political
behavior

Political
theoryedit
Main
article
Political
theory
Anarchist
schools
of
thought
hold
that
all
forms
of
hierarchy
and
authority
are
illegitimate
Social
anarchism
views
individual
freedom
as
interrelated
with
mutual
aid
Individualist
anarchism
Democratic
theory
Athenian
democracy
form
of
Greek
democracy
in
which
free
male
citizens
had
direct
vote
on
all
government
actions
Republicanism
strain
of
political
thought
which
was
common
among
citystates
of
Italian
Renaissance
such
as
Republic
of
Venice

democracy

democracy
Initiative
Referendum

democracy

democracy

democracy

Decisionmakingedit
Voting
is
key
form
of
decisionmaking
in
politics
A
female
journalist
displays
her
inked
finger
after
casting
her
vote
in
Afghanistans
western
Herat
province
Electionedit
Electoral
systems
Plurality
voting
allows
each
voter
to
vote
for
single
candidate
with
candidate
with
most
votes
being
winner
It
is
often
combined
with
singlemember
districts
resulting
in
majoritarian
democracy
Cardinal
voting
systems
Approval
voting
Satisfaction
approval
voting
Majority
judgment
STAR
voting
Firstpastpost
voting
Single
nontransferable
vote
Limited
voting
Pluralityatlarge
voting
General
ticket
Proportional
representation
ensures
that
proportions
of
representation
allocated
in
elected
body
reflect
their
proportions
of
support
among
electorate
Often
combined
with
multimember
districts
to
produce
consensus
democracy
Partylist
proportional
representation
Mixed
electoral
systems
Mixedmember
proportional
representation
Parallel
voting
Scorporo
Majority
bonus
system
Alternative
vote
plus
Dualmember
proportional
representation
Ruralurban
proportional
representation

Right
of
foreigners
to
vote

of

to
vote
in
their
country
of
origin

suffrage

of
candidacy

Political
institutionsedit
Institutions
are
often
framework
within
which
politics
happens
Pictured
is
Supreme
Court
of
United
States
Branches
of
governmentedit
The
separation
of
powers
is
typically
set
in
constitution
or
basic
law
in
order
to
achieve
checks
and
balances
within
government
The
typical
model
has
three
branches
and
is
referred
to
as
trias
politica
Legislature
deliberates
and
passes
laws
Unicameralism
Bicameralism
Upper
house
Lower
house
Tricameralism
Tetracameralism
Multicameralism
Executive
executes
laws
Head
of
state
formal
often
symbolic
leader
of
state
Sometimes
has
veto
power
over
proposed
legislation
Monarch
Supreme
leader
President
Head
of
government
persons
in
charge
of
daytoday
affairs
of
state
Usually
heads
cabinet
Council
of
Ministers
or
Council
of
State
Chancellor
Chief
executive
Chief
minister
First
minister
Premier
Prime
minister
Judiciary
often
involved
in
politics
through
judicial
review
Supreme
court
Constitutional
court

parties
and
their
number
are
important
aspects
of
representative
systems
The
number
of
political
parties
in
Hellenic
Parliament
of
Greece
has
varied
across
time

By

poweredit
Autocracy
source
of
power
is
leader
Democracy
source
of
power
are
people
through
popular
sovereignty

source
of
power
is
ethnicity
Meritocracy
source
of
power
is
talent
Noocracy
talent
is
measured
by
wisdom
Technocracy
talent
is
measured
by
expertise
Stratocracy
source
of
power
is

dictatorship
Military
junta

of

state

elite

of
power
is

CategoryPolitics
and
conflicts
The
main
article
for
this
category
is
Politics
Politics
is
process
and
conduct
of
decisionmaking
for
groups
Although
it
is
usually
applied
to
governments
political
behavior
is
also
observed
in
corporations

also

of

topics

Politics
portal
v
t
e
Politics
is
process
by
which
groups
of
people
make
decisionscitation
needed
Although
term
is
generally
applied
to
behavior
within
civil
governments
politics
is
observed
in
all
human
group
interactions
including
corporate
academic
and
religious
institutions
Politics
consists
of
social
relations
involving
authority
or
power
The
definition
of
politics
from
The
Free
Dictionary
is
study
of
political
behavior
and
examines
acquisition
and
application
of
power
Politics
study
include
political
philosophy
which
seeks
rationale
for
politics
and
ethic
of
public
behavior
and
public
administration
which
examines
practices
of
governance

Politics
exercise
of
power
process
by
which
groups
of
people
make
collective
decisions
Politics
is
art
or
science
of
running
governmental
or
state
affairs
including
behavior
within
civil
governments
institutions
fields
and
special
interest
groups
such
as
corporate
academic
and
religious
segments
of
society

Political
theoryedit
Main
article
Political
theory
Anarchist
schools
of
thought
hold
that
all
forms
of
hierarchy
and
authority
are
illegitimate
Social
anarchism
views
individual
freedom
as
interrelated
with
mutual
aid
Individualist
anarchism
Democratic
theory
Athenian
democracy
form
of
Greek
democracy
in
which
free
male
citizens
had
direct
vote
on
all
government
actions
Republicanism
strain
of
political
thought
which
was
common
among
citystates
of
Italian
Renaissance
such
as
Republic
of
Venice

democracy

democracy

Electionedit
Electoral
systems
Plurality
voting
allows
each
voter
to
vote
for
single
candidate
with
candidate
with
most
votes
being
winner
It
is
often
combined
with
singlemember
districts
resulting
in
majoritarian
democracy
Cardinal
voting
systems
Approval
voting
Satisfaction
approval
voting
Majority
judgment
STAR
voting
Firstpastpost
voting
Single
nontransferable
vote
Limited
voting
Pluralityatlarge
voting
General
ticket
Proportional
representation
ensures
that
proportions
of
representation
allocated
in
elected
body
reflect
their
proportions
of
support
among
electorate
Often
combined
with
multimember
districts
to
produce
consensus
democracy
Partylist
proportional
representation
Mixed
electoral
systems

proportional
representation

voting

Branches
of
governmentedit
The
separation
of
powers
is
typically
set
in
constitution
or
basic
law
in
order
to
achieve
checks
and
balances
within
government

typical
model
has
three
branches
and
is
referred
to
as
trias
politica

deliberates
and
passes
laws

house

house

executes
laws

of
state

of

exercise
of
power
process
by
which
groups
of
people
make
collective
decisions
Politics
is
art
or
science
of
running
governmental
or
state
affairs
including
behavior
within
civil
governments
institutions
fields
and
special
interest
groups
such
as
corporate
academic
and
religious
segments
of
society
Political
science
field
concerning
theory
and
practice
of
politics
and
description
and
analysis
of
political
systems
and
political
behavior

Political
theoryedit
Main
article
Political
theory
Anarchist
schools
of
thought
hold
that
all
forms
of
hierarchy
and
authority
are
illegitimate
Social
anarchism
views
individual
freedom
as
interrelated
with
mutual
aid
Individualist
anarchism
Democratic
theory
Athenian
democracy
form
of
Greek
democracy
in
which
free
male
citizens
had
direct
vote
on
all
government
actions
Republicanism
strain
of
political
thought
which
was
common
among
citystates
of
Italian
Renaissance
such
as
Republic
of
Venice

democracy

Decisionmakingedit
Voting
is
key
form
of
decisionmaking
in
politics
A
female
journalist
displays
her
inked
finger
after
casting
her
vote
in
Afghanistans
western
Herat
province
Electionedit
Electoral
systems
Plurality
voting
allows
each
voter
to
vote
for
single
candidate
with
candidate
with
most
votes
being
winner
It
is
often
combined
with
singlemember
districts
resulting
in
majoritarian
democracy
Cardinal
voting
systems
Approval
voting
Satisfaction
approval
voting
Majority
judgment
STAR
voting
Firstpastpost
voting
Single
nontransferable
vote
Limited
voting
Pluralityatlarge
voting
General
ticket
Proportional
representation
ensures
that
proportions
of
representation
allocated
in
elected
body
reflect
their
proportions
of
support
among
electorate
Often
combined
with
multimember
districts
to
produce
consensus
democracy
Partylist
proportional
representation
Mixed
electoral
systems
Mixedmember
proportional
representation
Parallel
voting
Scorporo
Majority
bonus
system
Alternative
vote
plus
Dualmember
proportional
representation
Ruralurban
proportional
representation
Suffrage
Disfranchisement
Right
of
foreigners
to
vote

of
expatriates
to
vote
in
their
country
of
origin
Youth
suffrage

of
candidacy

voting

voting

above

Political
institutionsedit
Institutions
are
often
framework
within
which
politics
happens
Pictured
is
Supreme
Court
of
United
States
Branches
of
governmentedit
The
separation
of
powers
is
typically
set
in
constitution
or
basic
law
in
order
to
achieve
checks
and
balances
within
government
The
typical
model
has
three
branches
and
is
referred
to
as
trias
politica
Legislature
deliberates
and
passes
laws
Unicameralism
Bicameralism
Upper
house
Lower
house
Tricameralism
Tetracameralism
Multicameralism
Executive
executes
laws
Head
of
state
formal
often
symbolic
leader
of
state
Sometimes
has
veto
power
over
proposed
legislation
Monarch
Supreme
leader
President
Head
of
government
persons
in
charge
of
daytoday
affairs
of
state
Usually
heads
cabinet
Council
of
Ministers
or
Council
of
State
Chancellor
Chief
executive
Chief
minister
First
minister
Premier
Prime
minister
Judiciary
often
involved
in
politics
through
judicial
review
Supreme
court
Constitutional
court

across

source

is

source
of

are
people
through

sovereignty

source
of

is

of

is
talent

by
wisdom

This
list
summarises
country
subdivisions
which
have
separate
article
on
their
politics
Countries
where
significant
powers
delegated
to
federal
units
or
to
devolved
governments
and
where
political
system
is
multiparty
democracy
are
more
likely
to
have
articles
on
politics
of
their
subdivisions

listed
in
article

Discours
sur
loeconomie
politique
Political
economy
is
study
of
production
and
trade
and
their
relations
with
law
custom
and
government
and
with
distribution
of
national
income
and
wealth
As
discipline
political
economy
originated
in
moral
philosophy
in
th
century
to
explore
administration
of
states
wealth
with
political
signifying
Greek
word
polity
and
economy
signifying
Greek
word
household
management
The
earliest
works
of
political
economy
are
usually
attributed
to
British
scholars
Adam
Smith
Thomas
Malthus
and
David
Ricardo
although
they
were
preceded
by
work
of
French
physiocrats
such
as
Franois
Quesnay
and
AnneRobertJacques
Turgot
In
late
th
century
term
economics
gradually
began
to
replace
term
political
economy
with
rise
of
mathematical
modelling
coinciding
with
publication
of
influential
textbook
by
Alfred
Marshall
in
Earlier
William
Stanley
Jevons
proponent
of
mathematical
methods
applied
to
subject
advocated
economics
for
brevity
and
with
hope
of
term
becoming
recognised
name
of
science
Citation
measurement
metrics
from
Google
Ngram
Viewer
indicate
that
use
of
term
economics
began
to
overshadow
political
economy
around
roughly
becoming
preferred
term
for
discipline
by
Today
term
economics
usually
refers
to
narrow
study
of
economy
absent
other
political
and
social
considerations
while
term
political
economy
represents
distinct
and
competing
approach
Political
economy
where
it
isnt
considered
synonym
for
economics
may
refer
to
very
different
things
From
academic
standpoint
term
may
reference
Marxian
economics
applied
public
choice
approaches
emanating
from
Chicago
school
and
Virginia
school
In
common
parlance
political
economy
may
simply
refer
to
advice
given
by
economists
to
government
or
public
on
general
economic
policy
or
on
specific
economic
proposals
developed
by
political
scientists
A
rapidly
growing
mainstream
literature
from
s
has
expanded
beyond
model
of
economic
policy
in
which
planners
maximize
utility
of
representative
individual
toward
examining
how
political
forces
affect
choice
of
economic
policies
especially
as
to
distributional
conflicts
and
political
institutions
It
is
available
as
standalone
area
of
study
or
offered
under
economics
or
political
science
at
some
institutions
including
Harvard
University
Princeton
University
London
School
of
Economics
and
Stanford
University
among
others

Etymologyedit
Originally
political
economy
meant
study
of
conditions
under
which
production
or
consumption
within
limited
parameters
was
organized
in
nationstates
In
that
way
political
economy
expanded
emphasis
of
economics
which
comes
from
Greek
oikos
meaning
home
and
nomos
meaning
law
or
order
Political
economy
was
thus
meant
to
express
laws
of
production
of
wealth
at
state
level
quite
like
economics
concerns
putting
home
to
order
The
phrase
conomie
politique
translated
in
English
to
political
economy
first
appeared
in
France
in
with
wellknown
book
by
Antoine
de
Montchrtien
Trait
de
leconomie
politique
Other
contemporary
scholars
attribute
roots
of
this
study
to
th
Century
Tunisian
Arab
Historian
and
Sociologist
Ibn
Khaldun
for
his
work
on
making
distinction
between
profit
and
sustenance
in
modern
political
economy
terms
surplus
and
that
required
for
reproduction
of
classes
respectively
He
also
calls
for
creation
of
science
to
explain
society
and
goes
on
to
outline
these
ideas
in
his
major
work
Muqaddimah
In
AlMuqaddimah
Khaldun
states
Civilization
and
its
wellbeing
as
well
as
business
prosperity
depend
on
productivity
and
peoples
efforts
in
all
directions
in
their
own
interest
and
profit
seen
as
modern
precursor
to
Classical
Economic
thought
Leading
on
from
this
French
physiocrats
were
first
major
exponents
of
political
economy
although
intellectual
responses
of
Adam
Smith
John
Stuart
Mill
David
Ricardo
Henry
George
and
Karl
Marx
to
physiocrats
generally
receives
much
greater
attention
The
worlds
first
professorship
in
political
economy
was
established
in
at
University
of
Naples
Federico
II
in
southern
Italy
The
Neapolitan
philosopher
Antonio
Genovesi
was
first
tenured
professor
In
Joseph
von
Sonnenfels
was
appointed
Political
Economy
chair
at
University
of
Vienna
Austria
Thomas
Malthus
in
became
Englands
first
professor
of
political
economy
at
East
India
Company
College
Haileybury
Hertfordshire
At
present
political
economy
refers
to
different
yet
related
approaches
to
studying
economic
and
related
behaviours
ranging
from
combination
of
economics
with
other
fields
to
use
of
different
fundamental
assumptions
challenging
earlier
economic
assumptions
Current
approachesedit
Robert
Keohane
international
relations
theorist
Political
economy
most
commonly
refers
to
interdisciplinary
studies
drawing
upon
economics
sociology
and
political
science
in
explaining
how
political
institutions
political
environment
and
economic
systemcapitalist
socialist
communist
or
mixedinfluence
each
other
The
Journal
of
Economic
Literature
classification
codes
associate
political
economy
with
three
subareas
role
of
government
andor
class
and
power
relationships
in
resource
allocation
for
each
type
of
economic
system
international
political
economy
which
studies
economic
impacts
of
international
relations
and
economic
models
of
political
or
exploitative
class
processes
Much
of
political
economy
approach
is
derived
from
public
choice
theory
on
one
hand
and
radical
political
economics
on
other
hand
both
dating
from
s
Public
choice
theory
is
microfoundations
theory
closely
intertwined
with
political
economy
Both
approaches
model
voters
politicians
and
bureaucrats
as
behaving
in
mainly
selfinterested
ways
in
contrast
to
view
ascribed
to
earlier
mainstream
economists
of
government
officials
trying
to
maximize
individual
utilities
from
some
kind
of
social
welfare
function
As
such
economists
and
political
scientists
often
associate
political
economy
with
approaches
using
rationalchoice
assumptions
especially
in
game
theory
and
in
examining
phenomena
beyond
economics
standard
remit
such
as
government
failure
and
complex
decision
making
in
which
context
term
positive
political
economy
is
common
Other
traditional
topics
include
analysis
of
such
public
policy
issues
as
economic
regulation
monopoly
rentseeking
market
protection
institutional
corruption
and
distributional
politics
Empirical
analysis
includes
influence
of
elections
on
choice
of
economic
policy
determinants
and
forecasting
models
of
electoral
outcomes
political
business
cycles
centralbank
independence
and
politics
of
excessive
deficits
Susan
Strange
international
relations
scholar
A
ratherrecent
focus
has
been
put
on
modeling
economic
policy
and
political
institutions
concerning
interactions
between
agents
and
economic
and
political
institutions
including
seeming
discrepancy
of
economic
policy
and
economists
recommendations
through
lens
of
transaction
costs
From
mids
field
has
expanded
in
part
aided
by
new
crossnational
data
sets
allowing
tests
of
hypotheses
on
comparative
economic
systems
and
institutions
Topics
have
included
breakup
of
nations
origins
and
rate
of
change
of
political
institutions
in
relation
to
economic
growth
development
financial
markets
and
regulation
importance
of
institutions
backwardness
reform
and
transition
economies
role
of
culture
ethnicity
and
gender
in
explaining
economic
outcomes
macroeconomic
policy
environment
fairness
and
relation
of
constitutions
to
economic
policy
theoretical
and
empirical
Other
important
landmarks
in
development
of
political
economy
include
New
political
economy
which
may
treat
economic
ideologies
as
phenomenon
to
explain
per
traditions
of
Marxian
political
economy
Thus
Charles
S
Maier
suggests
that
political
economy
approach
interrogates
economic
doctrines
to
disclose
their
sociological
and
political
premises
in
sum
it
regards
economic
ideas
and
behavior
not
as
frameworks
for
analysis
but
as
beliefs
and
actions
that
must
themselves
be
explained
This
approach
informs
Andrew
Gambles
The
Free
Economy
and
Strong
State
Palgrave
Macmillan
and
Colin
Hays
The
Political
Economy
of
New
Labour
Manchester
University
Press
It
also
informs
much
work
published
in
New
Political
Economy
international
journal
founded
by
Sheffield
University
scholars
in
International
political
economy
IPE
interdisciplinary
field
comprising
approaches
to
actions
of
various
actors
According
to
International
Relations
scholar
Chris
Brown
University
of
Warwick
professor
Susan
Strange
was
almost
singlehandedly
responsible
for

international

as
field
of
study
In
United
States
these
approaches
are
associated
with
journal
International
Organization
which
in
s
became
leading
journal
of

under

Robert

Peter
J

They

Review

There
also
is
more
critical
school
of
IPE
inspired
by
thinkers
such

Antonio
Gramsci
and
Karl

two
major
figures
are
Matthew
Watson
and
Robert
W
Cox
The
use
of
political
economy
approach
by
anthropologists
sociologists
and
geographers
used
in
reference
to
regimes
of
politics
or
economic
values
that
emerge
primarily
at
level
of
states
or
regional
governance
but
also
within
smaller
social
groups
and
social
networks
Because
these
regimes
influence
and
are
influenced
by
organization
of
both
social
and
economic
capital
analysis
of
dimensions
lacking
standard
economic
value
eg
political
economy
of
language
of
gender
or
of
religion
often
draws
on
concepts
used
in
Marxian
critiques
of
capital
Such
approaches
expand
on
neoMarxian
scholarship
related
to
development
and
underdevelopment
postulated
by
Andr
Gunder
Frank
and
Immanuel
Wallerstein
Historians
have
employed
political
economy
to
explore
ways
in
past
that
persons
and
groups
with
common
economic
interests
have
used
politics
to
effect
changes
beneficial
to
their
interests
Political
economy
and
law
is
recent
attempt
within
legal
scholarship
to
engage
explicitly
with
political
economy
literature
In
s
and
s
legal
realists
eg
Robert
Hale
and
intellectuals
eg
John
Commons
engaged
themes
related
to
political
economy
In
second
half
of
th
century
lawyers
associated
with
Chicago
School
incorporated
certain
intellectual
traditions
from
economics
However
since
crisis
in
legal
scholars
especially
related
to
international
law
have
turned
to
more
explicitly
engage
with
debates
methodology
and
various
themes
within
political
economy
texts
Thomas
Pikettys
approach
and
call
to
action
which
advocated
for
reintroduction
of
political
consideration
and
political
science
knowledge
more
generally
into
discipline
of
economics
as
way
of
improving
robustness
of
discipline
and
remedying
its
shortcomings
which
had
become
clear
following
financial
crisis
In
only
Department
of
Political
Economy
in
United
Kingdom
formally
established
at
Kings
College
London
The
rationale
for
this
academic
unit
was
that
disciplines
of
Politics
and
Economics
are
inextricably
linked
and
that
it
was
not
possible
to
properly
understand
political
processes
without
exploring
economic
context
in
which
politics
operates
In
Political
Economy
UK
Group
abbreviated
PolEconUK
was
established
as
research
consortium
in
field
of
political
economy
It
hosts
annual
conference
and
counts
among
its
member
institutions

Related
disciplinesedit
Because
political
economy
is
not
unified
discipline
there
are
studies
using
term
that
overlap
in
subject
matter
but
have
radically
different
perspectives
Politics
studies
power
relations
and
their
relationship
to
achieving
desired
ends
Philosophy
rigorously
assesses
and
studies
set
of
beliefs
and
their
applicability
to
reality
Economics
studies
distribution
of
resources
so
that
material
wants
of
society
are
satisfied
enhance
societal
wellbeing
Sociology
studies
effects
of
persons
involvement
in
society
as
members
of
groups
and
how
that
changes
their
ability
to
function
Many
sociologists
start
from
perspective
of
productiondetermining
relation
from
Karl
Marx
Marxs
theories
on
subject
of
political
economy
are
contained
in
his
book
Das
Kapital
Anthropology
studies
political
economy
by
investigating
regimes
of
political
and
economic
value
that
condition
tacit
aspects
of
sociocultural
practices
eg
pejorative
use
of
pseudoSpanish
expressions
in
US
entertainment
media
by
means
of
broader
historical
political
and
sociological
processes
Analyses
of
structural
features
of
transnational
processes
focus
on
interactions
between
world
capitalist
system
and
local
cultures
Archaeology
attempts
to
reconstruct
past
political
economies
by
examining
material
evidence
for
administrative
strategies
to
control
and
mobilize
resources
This
evidence
may
include
architecture
animal
remains
evidence
for
craft
workshops
evidence
for
feasting
and
ritual
evidence
for
import
or
export
of
prestige
goods
or
evidence
for
food
storage
Psychology
is
fulcrum
on
which
political
economy
exerts
its
force
in
studying
decision
making
not
only
in
prices
but
as
field
of
study
whose
assumptions
model
political
economy
History
documents
change
often
using
it
to
argue
political
economy
some
historical
works
take
political
economy
as
narratives
frame
Ecology
deals
with
political
economy
because
human
activity
has
greatest
effect
upon
environment
its
central
concern
being
environments
suitability
for
human
activity
The
ecological
effects
of
economic
activity
spur
research
upon
changing
market
economy
incentives
Additionally
and
more
recently
ecological
theory
has
been
used
to
examine
economic
systems
as
similar
systems
of
interacting
species
eg
firms
Cultural
studies
examines
social
class
production
labor
race
gender
and
sex
Communications
examines
institutional
aspects
of
media
and
telecommunication
systems
As
area
of
study
focusing
on
aspects
of
human
communication
it
pays
particular
attention
to
relationships
between
owners
labor
consumers
advertisers
structures
of
production
and
state
and
power
relationships
embedded
in
these
relationships

Political
history
is
narrative
and
survey
of
political
events
ideas
movements
organs
of
government
voters
parties
and
leaders
It
is
interrelated
to
other
fields
of
history
especially
diplomatic
history
as
well
as
constitutional
history
and
public
history
Political
history
studies
organization
and
operation
of
power
in
large
societies
By
focusing
on
elites
in
power
on
their
impact
on
society
on
popular
response
and
on
relationships
with
elites
in
other
social
history
which
focuses
predominantly
on
actions
and
lifestyles
of
ordinary
people
or
peoples
history
which
is
historical
work
from
perspective
of
common
people
In
two
decades
from
to
proportion
of
professors
of
history
in
American
universities
identifying
with
social
history
rose
from
to
and
proportion
of
political
historians
fell
from
to
In
history
departments
of
British
and
Irish
universities
in
of
faculty
members
reporting
identified
themselves
with
social
history
and
political
history
came
next
at
faculty
members
Contents

world
history

of

history

Germany

of

also

Political
world
historyedit
Main
article
history
of
political
thinking
The
political
history
of
world
is
history
of
changes
of
political
events
Aspects
of
Political
Historyedit
The
first
scientific
political
history
was
written
by
Leopold
von
Ranke
in
Germany
in
th
century
His
methodologies
profoundly
affected
way
historians
critically
examine
sources
see
historiography
for
more
complete
analysis
of
methodology
of
various
approaches
to
history
An
important
aspect
of
political
history
is
study
of
ideology
as
force
for
historical
change
One
author
asserts
that
political
history
as
whole
cannot
exist
without
study
of
ideological
differences
and
their
implications
Studies
of
political
history
typically
centre
around
single
nation
and
its
political
change
and
development
Some
historians
identify
growing
trend
towards
narrow
specialization
in
political
history
during
recent
decades
while
college
professor
in
s
sought
to
identify
himself
as
historian
by
s
American
historian
was
designation
From
s
onwards
new
movements
challenged
traditional
approaches
to
political
history
The
development
of
social
history
shifted
emphasis
away
from
study
of
leaders
and
national
decisions
and
towards
role
of
ordinary
people
especially
outsiders
and
minorities
Younger
scholars
shifted
to
different
issues
usually
focused
on
race
class
and
gender
with
little
room
for
elites
After
social
history
itself
began
to
fade
replaced
with
postmodern
and
cultural
approaches
that
rejected
grand
narrative
United
States
The
new
political
historyedit
Traditional
political
history
focused
on
major
leaders
and
had
long
played
dominant
role
among
academic
historians
in
United
States
These
studies
accounted
for
about
of
scholarly
books
and
articles
written
by
American
historians
before
and
about
into
s
followed
by
diplomacy
The
arrival
in
s
and
s
of
new
interest
in
social
history
led
to
emergence
of
new
political
history
which
saw
young
scholars
put
much
more
emphasis
on
voters
behavior
and
motivation
rather
than
just
politicians
It
relied
heavily
on
quantitative
methods
to
integrate
social
themes
especially
regarding
ethnicity
and
religion
The
new
social
science
approach
was
harbinger
of
fading
away
of
interest
in
Great
Men
The
eclipse
of
traditional
political
approaches
during
s
was
major
shock
though
diplomatic
history
fell
even
further
It
was
upstaged
by
social
history
with
raceclassgender
model
The
number
of
political
articles
submitted
to
Journal
of
American
History
fell
by
half
from
to
Patterson
argued
that
contemporary
events
especially
Vietnam
War
and
Watergate
alienated
younger
scholars
away
from
study
of
politicians
and
their
deeds
Political
history
never
disappeared
but
it
never
recovered
its
dominance
among
scholars
despite
its
sustained
high
popularity
among
reading
public
Some
political
historians
made
fun
of
their
own
predicament
as
when
William
Leuchtenburg
wrote
status
of
political
historians
within
profession
has
sunk
to
somewhere
between
that
of
faith
healer
and
chiropractor
Political
historians
were
all
right
in
way
but
you
might
not
want
to
bring
one
home
to
meet
family
Others
were
more
analytical
as
when
Hugh
Davis
Graham
observed
The
ranks
of
traditional
political
historians
are
depleted
their
assumptions
and
methods
discredited
along
with
Great
White
Man
whose
careers
they
chronicled
Britainedit
Readman
discusses
historiography
of
British
political
history
in
th
century
He
describes
how
British
political
scholarship
mostly
ignored
th
century
history
due
to
temporal
proximity
to
recent
past
unavailability
of
primary
sources
and
potential
for
bias
The
article
explores
how
transitions
in
scholarship
have
allowed
for
greater
interest
in
th
century
history
among
scholars
which
include
less
reliance
on
archival
sources
methodological
changes
in
historiography
and
flourishing
of
new
forms
of
history
such
as
oral
history
Germanyedit
In
course
of
s
however
some
German
historians
notably
HansUlrich
Wehler
and
his
cohort
began
to
rebel
against
this
idea
instead
suggesting
Primacy
of
Domestic
Politics
Primat
der
Innenpolitik
in
which
insecurities
of
in
this
case
German
domestic
policy
drove
creation
of
foreign
policy
This
led
to
considerable
body
of
work
interpreting
domestic
policies
of
various
states
and
ways
this
influenced
their
conduct
of
foreign
policy
Franceedit
The
French
Annales
School
had
already
put
emphasis
on
role
of
geography
and
economics
on
history
and
of
importance
of
broad
slow
cycles
rather
than
constant
apparent
movement
of
history
of
events
of
high
politics
It
downplayed
politics
and
diplomacy
The
most
important
work
of
Annales
school
Fernand
Braudels
The
Mediterranean
and
Mediterranean
World
in
Age
of
Philip
II
contains
traditional
Rankean
diplomatic
history
of
Philip
IIs
Mediterranean
policy
but
only
as
third
and
shortest
section
of
work
largely
focusing
on
broad
cycles
of
history
in
longue
dure
long
term
The
Annales
were
broadly
influential
leading
to
turning
away
from
political
history
towards
emphasis
on
broader
trends
of
economic
and
environmental
change
Social
historyedit
Main
article
Social
history
In
s
and
s
increasing
emphasis
on
giving
voice
to
voiceless
and
writing
history
of
underclasses
whether
by
using
quantitative
statistical
methods
of
social
history
or
more
postmodern
assessments
of
cultural
history
also
undermined
centrality
of
politics
to
historical
discipline
Leff
noted
how
social
historians
disdained
political
history
as
elitist
shallow
altogether
passe
and
irrelevant
to
drama
of
everyday
lives
History
of
political
regimes
and
institutionsedit
MaxRange
data
is
project
that
defines
and
shows
in
detail
political
status
and
development
of
institutional
regimes
of
all
states
in
world
from
MaxRange
also
describes
background
development
external
sources
and
major
causes
behind
all
political
changes
MaxRange
is
dataset
defining
level
of
democracy
and
institutional
structure
regimetype
on
graded
scale
where
every
value
represents
unique
regimetype
Values
are
sorted
from
based
on
level
of
democracy
and
political
accountability
MaxRange
defines
value
regimetype
corresponding
to
all
states
and
every
month
from
to
and
updating
MaxRange
is
created
and
developed
by
Max
Range
and
is
now
associated
with
university
of
Halmstad
Sweden

alsoedit

v
t

The
political
history
of
world
is
history
of
various
political
entities
created
by
human
race
throughout
their
existence
and
way
these
states
define
their
borders
Throughout
history
political
entities
have
expanded
from
basic
systems
of
selfgovernance
and
monarchy
to
complex
democratic
and
totalitarian
systems
that
exist
today
In
parallel
political
systems
have
expanded
from
vaguely
defined
frontiertype
boundaries
to
national
definite
boundaries
existing
today
Contents

era
Ancient
history

and

dominance

dominance

dominance

dominance

subcontinent

Americas

era

and

Americas

modern

References
Prehistoric
eraedit
The
first
forms
of
human
social
organization
were
families
living
in
band
societies
as
huntergatherers
After
invention
of
agriculture
around
same
time
BCE
across
various
parts
of
world
human
societies
started
transitioning
to
tribal
forms
of
organization
There
is
evidence
of
diplomacy
between
different
tribes
but
also
of
endemic
warfare
This
could
have
been
caused
by
theft
of
livestock
or
crops
abduction
of
women
or
resource
and
status
competition
Ancient
historyedit
Main
article
Ancient
history
The
early
distribution
of
political
power
was
determined
by
availability
of
fresh
water
fertile
soil
and
temperate
climate
of
different
locations
These
were
all
necessary
for
development
of
highly
organized
societies
The
first
empires
were
those
of
Ancient
Egypt
and
Mesopotamia
Smaller
kingdoms
existed
in
North
China
Plain
IndoGangetic
Plain
Central
Asia
Anatolia
Eastern
Mediterranean
and
Central
America
while
rest
of
humanity
continued
to
live
in
small
tribes
Both
Egypt
and
Mesopotamia
had
been
able
to
take
advantage
of
their
large
rivers
with
irrigation
systems
enabling
higher
productivity
in
agriculture
and
thereby
sustaining
surpluses
and
population
growth
Middle
East
and
Mediterraneanedit
See
also
Cradle
of
civilization
Ancient
Near
East
and
Ancient
Mediterranean
Overview
map
of
ancient
Near
East
The
first
states
of
sorts
were
those
of
early
dynastic
Sumer
and
early
dynastic
Egypt
which
arose
from
Uruk
period
and
Predynastic
Egypt
respectively
at
approximately
BCE
Early
dynastic
Egypt
was
based
around
Nile
River
in
northeast
of
Africa
kingdoms
boundaries
being
based
around
Nile
and
stretching
to
areas
where
oases
existed
Upper
and
Lower
Egypt
were
unified
around
BCE
by
Pharaoh
Menes
Nevertheless
political
competition
continued
within
country
between
centers
of
power
such
as
Memphis
and
Thebes
The
geopolitical
environment
of
Egyptians
had
them
surrounded
by
Nubia
in
smaller
southern
oases
of
Nile
unreachable
by
boat
as
well
as
by
Libyan
warlords
operating
from
oases
around
modernday
Benghazi
and
finally
by
raiders
across
Sinai
and
sea
Mesopotamian
dominanceedit
Mesopotamia
is
situated
between
major
rivers
of
Tigris
and
Euphrates
and
first
political
power
in
region
was
Akkadian
Empire
starting
around
BCE
They
were
later
followed
by
Sumer
Babylon
and
Assyria
They
faced
competition
from
mountainous
areas
to
north
strategically
positioned
above
Mesopotamian
plains
with
kingdoms
such
as
Mitanni
Urartu
Elam
and
Medes
The
Mesopotamians
also
innovated
in
governance
by
writing
first
laws
A
dry
climate
in
Iron
Age
caused
turmoil
as
movements
of
people
put
pressure
on
existing
states
resulting
in
Late
Bronze
Age
collapse
with
Cimmerians
Arameans
Dorians
and
Sea
Peoples
migrating
among
others
Babylon
never
recovered
following
death
of
Hammurabi
in
BCE
Following
this
Assyria
grew
in
power
under
Adadnirari
II
By
late
ninth
century
BCE
Assyrian
Empire
controlled
almost
all
of
Mesopotamia
and
much
of
Levant
and
Anatolia
Meanwhile
Egypt
was
weakened
eventually
breaking
apart
after
death
of
Osorkon
II
until
BCE
In
Assyrians
fought
and
won
battle
against
coalition
of
Babylon
Egypt
Persia
Israel
Aram
and
ten
other
nations
with
over
troops
taking
part
according
to
contemporary
sources
However
empire
was
weakened
by
internal
struggles
for
power
and
was
plunged
into
decade
of
turmoil
beginning
with
plague
in
BCE
Following
revolts
by
cities
and
lesser
kingdoms
against
empire
coup
dtat
was
staged
in
by
TiglathPileser
III
He
raised
army
from
to
followed
by
his
successor
Sennacherib
who
raised
it
to
and
finally
by
Ashurbanipal
who
raised
army
of
over
This
allowed
empire
to
spread
over
Cyprus
entire
Levant
Phrygia
Urartu
Cimmerians
Persia
Medes
Elam
and
Babylon
Persian
dominanceedit
By
Assyria
had
started
declining
as
severe
drought
hit
Middle
East
and
alliance
was
formed
against
them
Eventually
they
were
replaced
by
Median
empire
as
main
power
of
region
following
Battle
of
Carchemish
and
Battle
of
Eclipse
The
Medians
served
as
launching
pad
for
rise
of
Persian
Empire
After
first
serving
as
vassals
under
third
Persian
king
Cambyses
I
their
influence
rose
and
in
they
rose
against
Medians
By
death
of
Cyrus
Great
Persian
Achaemenid
Empire
reached
from
Aegean
Sea
to
Indus
River
and
Caucasus
to
Nubia
The
empire
was
divided
into
provinces
ruled
by
satraps
who
collected
taxes
and
were
typically
local
power
brokers
The
empire
controlled
about
third
of
worlds
farm
land
and
quarter
of
its
population
In
after
King
Cambyses
IIs
death
Darius
Great
took
over
power
Greek
dominanceedit
As
population
of
Ancient
Greece
grew
they
began
colonization
of
Mediterranean
region
This
encouraged
trade
which
in
turn
caused
political
changes
in
citystates
with
old
elites
being
overthrown
in
Corinth
in
and
in
Athens
in
for
example
There
were
many
wars
between
cities
as
well
including
Messenian
Wars
Lelantine
War
and
First
Sacred
War
In
seventh
and
sixth
centuries
Corinth
and
Sparta
were
dominant
powers
of
Greece
The
former
was
eventually
supplanted
by
Athens
as
main
sea
power
while
Sparta
remained
dominant
landforce
In
in
Ionian
Revolt
Greek
cities
in
Asia
Minor
rebelled
against
Persian
Empire
but
were
crushed
in
Battle
of
Lade
After
this
Persians
invaded
Greek
mainland
in
GrecoPersian
Wars
The
Macedonian
King
Philip
II
conquered
much
of
Greece
In
he
formed
League
of
Corinth
to
liberate
Greeks
in
Asia
Minor
from
Persians
with
troops
invading
in
After
his
murder
his
son
Alexander
Great
took
charge
and
crossed
Dardanelles
in
After
Asia
Minor
had
been
conquered
Alexander
invaded
Levant
Egypt
and
Mesopotamia
defeating
Persians
under
Darius
Great
in
Battle
of
Gaugamela
in
and
ending
last
resistance
by
After
Alexanders
death
in
Babylon
in
empire
had
no
designated
successor
This
led
to
its
division
into
four
Antigonid
dynasty
in
Macedonia
Attalid
dynasty
in
Anatolia
Ptolemaic
Kingdom
in
Egypt
and
Seleucid
Empire
over
Mesopotamia
Roman
dominanceedit
Rome
became
dominant
in
Mediterranean
in
rd
century
BC
after
defeating
Samnites
Gauls
and
Etruscans
for
control
of
Italian
Peninsula
In
it
challenged
its
main
rival
Carthage
to
fight
for
Sicily
starting
Punic
Wars
A
truce
was
signed
in
with
Rome
gaining
Corsica
and
Sardinia
in
addition
to
Sicily
In
Carthaginian
general
Hannibal
marched
out
of
Spain
towards
Italy
crossing
Alps
with
his
war
elephants
After
years
of
fighting
Romans
beat
him
and
then
sent
troops
against
Carthage
itself
defeating
it
in
The
Second
Punic
War
alone
cost
Rome
casualties
In
Carthage
was
finally
destroyed
completely
Rome
suffered
from
various
internal
disturbances
and
destabilities
In
Tiberius
Gracchus
was
killed
alongside
hundreds
of
supporters
after
trying
to
redistribute
public
land
to
poor
The
Social
War
was
caused
by
neighbouring
cities
trying
to
secure
themselves
benefits
of
Roman
citizenship
In
general
Sulla
captured
power
violently
ending
Roman
Republic
and
becoming
dictator
Following
his
death
new
ower
struggles
emrged
and
in
Caesars
Civil
War
Julius
Caesar
and
Pompey
fought
over
empire
with
former
winning
After
ruler
was
assassinated
in
second
civil
war
broke
out
between
his
potential
heirs
Mark
Antony
and
Augustus
latter
becoming
emperor
This
then
led
to
Pax
Romana
long
period
of
peace
in
empire
The
quarrels
between
Ptolemaic
Kingdom
Seleucid
Empire
Parthian
Empire
and
Kingdom
of
Pontus
in
Near
East
allowed
Romans
to
expand
up
to
Euphrates
During
Augustus
reign
Rhine
Danube
and
Sahara
became
other
borders
of
empire
The
population
reached
about
million
Political
instability
in
Rome
grew
Emperor
Caligula
was
murdered
by
Praetorian
Guard
to
replace
him
with
Claudius
while
his
successor
Nero
burned
Rome
down
The
average
reign
from
his
death
to
Philip
Arab
was
six
years
Nevertheless
external
expansion
continued
with
Trajan
invading
Dacia
Parthia
and
Arabia
Its
only
formidable
enemy
was
Parthian
Empire
Migrating
peoples
started
exerting
pressure
on
borders
of
empire
The
drying
climate
of
Central
Asia
forced
Huns
to
move
and
in
they
crossed
Don
and
soon
after
Danube
forcing
Goths
on
move
which
in
turn
caused
other
Germanic
tribes
to
overrun
Roman
borders
In
Diocletian
appointed
three
rulers
for
different
parts
of
empire
It
was
formally
divided
in
by
Theodosius
I
into
Western
Roman
and
Byzantine
Empires
In
northern
border
of
former
was
overrun
by
Alemanni
Vandals
and
Suebi
invaded
In
Visigoths
invaded
Italy
and
then
sacked
Rome
in
The
final
collapse
of
Western
Empire
came
in
with
deposal
of
Romulus
Augustulus
Indian
subcontinentedit
See
also
Middle
kingdoms
of
India
The
Maurya
Empire
Build
around
Indus
River
by
BCE
Indus
Valley
Civilization
located
in
modernday
India
Pakistan
and
Afghanistan
had
formed
The
civilizations
boundaries
extended
to
km
from
Arabian
Sea
After
its
cities
Mohenjodaro
and
Harappa
were
abandoned
around
BCE
no
political
power
replaced
it
States
began
to
form
in
th
century
BCE
with
Mahajanapadas
Out
of
sixteen
such
states
four
strong
ones
emerged
Kosala
Magadha
Vatsa
and
Avanti
with
Magadha
dominating
rest
by
midfifth
century
The
Magadha
then
transformed
into
Nanda
Empire
under
Mahapadma
Nanda
extending
from
Gangetic
plains
to
Hindu
Kush
and
Deccan
Plateau
The
empire
was
however
overtaken
by
Chandragupta
Maurya
turning
it
into
Maurya
Empire
He
defended
against
Alexanders
invasion
from
West
and
received
control
of
Hindu
Kush
mountain
passes
in
peace
treaty
signed
in
By
time
of
his
grandson
Ashokas
rule
empire
stretched
from
Zagros
Mountains
to
Brahmaputra
River
The
empire
contained
population
of
to
million
governed
by
system
of
provinces
ruled
by
governorprinces
with
capital
in
Pataliputra
After
Ashokas
death
empire
had
begun
to
decline
with
Kashmir
in
north
Shunga
and
Satavahana
in
centre
and
Kalinga
as
well
as
Pandya
in
south
becoming
independent
In
to
this
power
vacuum
Yuezhi
were
able
to
establish
new
Kushan
Empire
in
CE
The
Gupta
Empire
was
founded
by
Chandragupta
I
which
in
sixty
years
expanded
from
Ganges
to
Bay
of
Bengal
and
Indus
River
following
downfall
of
Kushan
Empire
Gupta
governance
was
similar
to
that
of
Maurya
Following
wars
with
Hephthalites
and
other
problems
empire
fell
by
Qin
dynasty
Chinaedit
See
also
Ancient
China
In
North
China
Plain
Yellow
River
allowed
rise
of
states
such
as
Wei
and
Qi
This
area
was
first
unified
by
Shang
dynasty
around
BCE
and
replaced
by
Zhou
dynasty
in
Battle
of
Muye
in
BCE
with
reportedly
millions
taking
part
in
fighting
The
victors
were
however
hit
by
internal
unrest
soon
after
The
main
rivals
of
Zhou
were
Dongyi
in
Shandong
Xianyun
in
Ordos
Guifang
in
Shanxi
as
well
as
Chu
in
middle
reaches
of
Yangtze
Starting
in
eight
century
China
fell
into
state
of
anarchy
for
five
centuries
during

and

and

periods
During
latter
period
Jin
dynasty
split
into
Wei
Zhao
and
Han
states
while
rest
of
North
China
Plain
was
composed
of
Chu
Qin
Qi
and
Yan
states
while
Zhou
remained
in
centre
with
largely
ceremonial
power
While
Zhao
had
advantage
at
first
Qin
ended
up
defeating
them
in
with
about
half
million
soldiers
fighting
on
each
side
at

of
Changping
The
other
states
tried
to

against
Qin
but
were
defeated
In
Qin
dynasty
was
established
with
population
of
about
million
with
capital
of
in
Linzi
Under
leadership
of
Qin
Shi
Huang
dynasty
initiated
reforms
such
as
establishing

administrative
units
infrastructure
projects
including
Great

of
China
and
uniform

However
after
his

and
burial
with
Terracotta
Army
empire
started

apart
when
Chu
and
Han
started
fighting
over
power

left
by
weak

with
Han

rising
to
power
in
BCE
Under

population
of
China
rose
to
million
with
in
capital
Chang
and
with

to
Korea
Vietnam
and
Tien
Shan

were
also

against
Xiongnu
and
to
secure
Hexi
Corridor
Nanyue
kingdom
was
annexed
and
Hainan
and
Taiwan
conquered
The
Chinese
pressure
on
Xiongnu
forced
them
towards

leading
to
exodus
of
Yuezhi
who
in
turn
pillaged
capital
of
Bactria
This

their
new

following

in
CE
with

PreColumbian

The

were
first

culture
with
some

ones
such
as
Chavn
culture
amongst
mainly

The

as
well
as
lack
