Asiaedit
The
Tang
dynasty
in
CE
When
China
entered
Sui
Dynasty
government
changed
and
expanded
in
its
borders
as
many
separate
bureaucracies
unified
under
one
banner
This
evolved
into
Tang
Dynasty
when
Li
Yuan
took
control
of
China
in
By
now
Chinese
borders
had
expanded
from
eastern
China
up
north
into
Tang
Empire
The
Tang
Empire
fell
apart
in
and
split
into
ten
regional
kingdoms
and
five
dynasties
with
vague
borders
Fiftythree
years
after
separation
of
Tang
Empire
China
entered
Song
Dynasty
under
rule
of
Chao
Kuang
although
borders
of
this
country
expanded
they
were
never
as
large
as
those
of
Tang
dynasty
and
were
constantly
being
redefined
due
to
attacks
from
neighboring
Tartar
Mongol
people
known
as
Khitan
tribes
The
Mongol
Empire
emerged
from
unification
of
several
nomadic
tribes
in
Mongol
homeland
under
leadership
of
Genghis
Khan
c
whom
council
proclaimed
as
ruler
of
all
Mongols
in
The
empire
grew
rapidly
under
his
rule
and
that
of
his
descendants
who
sent
out
invading
armies
in
every
direction
The
vast
transcontinental
empire
connected
East
with
West
Pacific
to
Mediterranean
in
enforced
Pax
Mongolica
allowing
dissemination
and
exchange
of
trade
technologies
commodities
and
ideologies
across
Eurasia
The
empire
began
to
split
due
to
wars
over
succession
as
grandchildren
of
Genghis
Khan
disputed
whether
royal
line
should
follow
from
his
son
and
initial
heir
gedei
or
from
one
of
his
other
sons
such
as
Tolui
Chagatai
or
Jochi
The
Toluids
prevailed
after
bloody
purge
of
gedeid
and
Chagataid
factions
but
disputes
continued
among
descendants
of
Tolui
After
Mngke
Khan
died
rival
kurultai
councils
simultaneously
elected
different
successors
brothers
Ariq
Bke
and
Kublai
Khan
who
fought
each
other
in
Toluid
Civil
War
and
also
dealt
with
challenges
from
descendants
of
other
sons
of
Genghis
Kublai
successfully
took
power
but
civil
war
ensued
as
he
sought
unsuccessfully
to
regain
control
of
Chagatayid
and
gedeid
families
By
time
of
Kublais
death
in
Mongol
Empire
had
fractured
into
four
separate
khanates
or
empires
each
pursuing
its
own
separate
interests
and
objectives
Golden
Horde
khanate
in
northwest
Chagatai
Khanate
in
Central
Asia
Ilkhanate
in
southwest
and
Yuan
dynasty
in
east
based
in
modernday
Beijing
In
three
western
khanates
briefly
accepted
nominal
suzerainty
of
Yuan
dynasty
but
in
Han
Chinese
Ming
dynasty
took
over
Mongol
capital
The
Genghisid
rulers
of
Yuan
retreated
to
Mongolian
homeland
and
continued
to
rule
there
as
Northern
Yuan
dynasty
The
Ilkhanate
disintegrated
in
period
The
Golden
Horde
had
broken
into
competing
khanates
by
end
of
th
century
and
was
defeated
and
thrown
out
of
Russia
in
by
Grand
Duchy
of
Moscow
while
Chagatai
Khanate
lasted
in
one
form
or

until
Middle

and
Europeedit
The
ByzantineSasanian
Wars
of
and
produced
cumulative
effects
of
century
of
almost
continuous
conflict
leaving
both
empires
crippled
When

II
died
only

after

to
throne
Persia
was

into

of

and

The

were
further
weakened
by
economic
decline
heavy
taxation
from
Khosrau
IIs
campaigns
religious
unrest
and
increasing
power
of
provincial

The
Byzantine

was
also
severely
affected
with
its
financial
reserves
exhausted
by
war
and
Balkans
now
largely
in
hands
of
Slavs
Additionally
Anatolia
was
devastated
by
repeated
Persian
invasions
Empires
hold
on
its
recently
regained
territories
in
Caucasus
Syria
Mesopotamia
Palestine
and
Egypt
was
loosened
by
many
years
of
Persian
occupation
Neither
empire
was
given
any
chance
to
recover
and
according
to
George
Liska
unnecessarily
prolonged
ByzantinePersian
conflict
opened

for
Islam
The
Quraysh
ruled
cities
of
Mecca
and
Medina
and
expelled
their
member
Muhammad
from
former
to
latter
in
from
where
he
began
spreading
his
new
religion
Islam
In
Muhammad
marched
with
to
Mecca
and
conquered
it
before
dying
next
year
His
successors
united
most
of
Arabia
in

wars
and
then
started
Muslim

of
Levant
Egypt
and
Persia
latter

Sasanian
empire
In
less

extended

from

to

in

At

ruled
third
of

population
In

replaced
Umayyads
in

In
they
moved

to
Baghdad
The

of
Crdoba

while
in

The

started

North

from
onwards
and

broke

in
Persia
and
later
Mesopotamia
starting
in

The

Empire
under

around
CE
with

in
orange
In

of

began
and
in
they

European

They

by

prospect

Indiaedit

in

I
while

had
emreged

in

IndoGangetic

Early
modern
eraedit
Main
article
Early
modern
era
In
th
and
th
centuries
three
major
Muslim
empires
formed
Ottoman
Empire
in
Middle
East
Balkans
and
Northern
Africa
Safavid
Empire
in
Greater
Iran
and
Mughul
Empire
in
South
Asia
These
imperial
powers
were
made
possible
by
discovery
and
exploitation
of
gunpowder
and
more
efficient
administration
By
end
of
th
century
all
three
had
declined
and
by
early
th
century
with
Ottomans
defeat
in
World
War
I
last
Muslim
empire
collapsed
Silesias
position
in
Europe
in
red
In
Charles
II
of
Spain
died
naming
Phillip
of
Anjou
Louis
XIVs
grandson
his
heir
Charles
decision
was
not
well
met
by
British
who
believed
that
Louis
would
use
opportunity
to
ally
France
and
Spain
and
attempt
to
take
over
Europe
Britain
formed
Grand
Alliance
with
Holland
Austria
and
majority
of
German
states
and
declared
war
against
Spain
in
The
War
of
Spanish
Succession
lasted
years
and
ended
when
Treaty
of
Utrecht
was
signed
in
Less
than

later
in
war
broke
out
again
sparked
by
invasion
of
Silesia
part
of

by
King
Frederick
II
of
Prussia
Britain
Netherlands
and

supported

Over

in

until

keep
Silesia
The

began
when

and

In
Britain
won

and

east

Prussia
also
kept
Silesia
Van

in

of

in
th
century
In

was

to

during

Tasman

which
was
later

Tasmania
Australian
coast
and
New

in
Captain

Cook
was

in
to

eclipse
in
Tahiti
and
sailed
into

on

east

in

by
Scottish
in

and

In
Northern
America

was

when
in
British

on
mob
pelting
them
with
stones
event
later
known

British

were
unable

was

of
something
bigger
until
in
Rebel

by

British

on

Shortly

when

states

and
in

The
National
Assembly
By
late
s
France
was
falling
into
debt
with
higher
taxes
introduced
and
famines
ensuring
As
measure
of
last
resort
King
Louis
XVI
called
together
EstatesGeneral
in
and
reluctantly
agreed
to
turn
Third
Estate
which
made
up
all
of
nonnoble
and
nonclergy
French
into
National
Assembly
This
assembly
grew
very
popular
in
public
eye
and
on
July
following
evidence
that
King
planned
to
disband
Assembly
angry
mob
stormed
Bastille
taking
gunpowder
and
lead
shot
Stories
of
success
of
this
raid
spread
all
over
country
and
sparked
multiple

in
which
lowerclasses
robbed

and

houses
In

of

year

of
National
Assembly
wrote

of
Rights
of

and
of

which
proclaimed
freedom
of
speech
press
and
religion
By
other

states
were
attempting
to
quell
revolution
In
same
year

and
German

attempted
to
march
on
Paris
but

repelled
them

on
fears
of
European

radical
group
known

and

for

in

and

join

system

Political
system
From
Wikipedia
free
encyclopedia

to
navigation
Jump
to
search

of
series
on
Politics

topics

of
politics
articles

of
political
science

by
country

by
subdivision

economy

history

history
of
world

philosophy

systems

and

psychology

and

organisations

electoral

and
low
politics

systems

Form
of
government
Ideology

campaigning
Political
parties
Politics
portal
v
t
e
In
political
science
political
system
define
process
for
making
official
government
decisions
It
is
usually
compared
to
legal
system
economic
system
cultural
system
and
other
social
systems
However
this
is
very
simplified
view
of
much
more
complex
system
of
categories
involving
questions
of
who
should
have
authority
and
what
government
influence
on
its
people
and
economy
should
be
Contents
Definition
Anthropological
classification
Sociology
See
also
Notes
References
External
links
Definitionedit
According
to
David
Easton
A
political
system
can
be
designated
as
interactions
through
which
values
are
authoritatively
allocated
for
society
Anthropological
classificationedit
Anthropologists
generally
recognize
four
kinds
of
political
systems
two
of
which
are
uncentralized
and
two
of
which
are
centralized
Uncentralized
systems
Band
society
Small
family
group
no
larger
than
extended
family
or
clan
it
has
been
defined
as
consisting
of
no
more
than
to
individuals
A
band
can
cease
to
exist
if
only
small
group
walks
out
Tribe
Generally
larger
consisting
of
many
families
Tribes
have
more
social
institutions
such
as
chief
or
elders
More
permanent
than
bands
Many
tribes
are
subdivided
into
bands
Centralized
governments
Chiefdom
More
complex
than
tribe
or
band
society
and
less
complex
than
state
or
civilization
Characterized
by
pervasive
inequality
and
centralization
of
authority
A
single
lineagefamily
of
elite
class
becomes
ruling
elite
of
chiefdom
Complex
chiefdoms
have
two
or
even
three
tiers
of
political
hierarchy
An
autonomous
political
unit
comprising
number
of
villages
or
communities
under
permanent
control
of
paramount
chief
Sovereign
state
A
sovereign
state
is
state
with
permanent
population
defined
territory
government
and
capacity
to
enter
into
relations
with
other
sovereign
states
Supranational
political
systems
Supranational
political
systems
are
created
by
independent
nations
to
reach
common
goal
or
gain
strength
from
forming
alliance
Empires
Empires
are
widespread
states
or
communities
under
single
rule
They
are
characterized
by
rulers
desire
for
unanimous
religious
affiliation
or
posing
as
threat
to
other
empires
in
times
of
war
Empires
such
as
Romans
or
Americans
often
made
considerable
progress
in
ways
of
democratic
structures
creating
and
building
city
infrastructures
and
maintaining
civility
within
diverse
communities
Because
of
intricate
organization
of
empires
they
were
often
able
to
hold
large
majority
of
power
on
universal
level
Leagues
Leagues
are
international
organizations
composed
of
states
coming
together
for
single
common
purpose
In
this
way
leagues
are
different
from
empires
as
they
only
seek
to
fulfill
single
goal
Often
leagues
are
formed
on
brink
of
military
or
economic
downfall
Meetings
and
hearings
are
conducted
in
neutral
location
with
representatives
of
all
involved
nations
present
Sociologyedit
The
sociological
interest
in
political
systems
is
figuring
out
who
holds
power
within
relationship
of
government
and
its
people
and
how
governments
power
is
used
There
are
three
types
of
political
systems
that
sociologists
consider
Authoritarianism
In
authoritarian
governments
people
have
no
power
or
representation
and
it
is
characterized
by
absolute
or
blind
obedience
to
formal
authority
as
against
individual
freedom
and
related
to
expectation
of
unquestioning
obedience
The
elite
leaders
handle
all
economic
military
and
foreign
relations
A
prime
example
of
authoritarianism
is
dictatorship
Totalitarianism
is
most
extreme
form
of
authoritarianism
because
it
controls
all
aspects
of
life
including
communication
between
citizens
media
censorship
and
threatens
by
means
of
terror
Monarchy
A
monarchy
is
government
controlled
by
king
or
queen
determined
by
predisposed
line
of
sovereignty
In
other
words
it
can
be
seen
as
undivided
rule
or
absolute
sovereignty
by
single
person
In
modern
world
there
are
two
types
of
monarchies
absolute
monarchies
and
constitutional
monarchies
An
absolute
monarchy
works
like
dictatorship
in
that
king
has
complete
rule
over
his
country
A
constitutional
monarchy
gives
royal
family
limited
powers
and
usually
works
in
accordance
with
elected
body
of
officials
Social
revolutions
of
th
th
and
th
century
overthrew
majoritycitation
needed
of
existing
monarchies
in
favor
of
more
democratic
governments
and
rising
middle
class
as
well
as
of
authoritarian
regimes
like
Soviet
Union
Democracy
A
democracy
is
form
of
government
in
which
citizens
create
and
vote
for
laws
directly
or
indirectly
via
representatives
democratic
republic
The
idea
of
democracy
stems
back
from
ancient
Greece
and
profound
works
of
ancient
academics
However
presence
of
democracy
does
not
always
mean
citizens
wishes
will
be
equally
represented
For
example
in
many
democratic
countrieswhich
immigrants
and
racial
and
ethnic
minorities
do
not
receive
same
rightsclarification
needed
as
majority
citizensaccording
to
whom
See
alsoedit
Government
Political
structure
Polity
Systems
theory
in
political
science
Tractatus
Politicus
Voting
system

Anarchy

Wikipedia
free
encyclopedia

other
uses
see
Anarchy
disambiguation

of
society
being
without
governing
body

of
Politics
series

forms
of
government

source

rule
by
many

Politics
portal
v
t
e
Anarchy
is
state
of
society
being
freely
constituted
without
authorities
or
governing
body
It
may
also
refer
to
society
or
group
of
people
that
entirely
rejects
set
hierarchy
Anarchy
was
first
used
in
meaning
absence
of
government
PierreJoseph
Proudhon
adopted
anarchy
and
anarchist
in
his
treatise
What
Is
Property
to
refer
to
anarchism
new
political
philosophy
and
social
movement
which
advocates
stateless
societies
based
on
free
and
voluntary
associations
Anarchists
seek
system
based
on
abolishment
of
all
unjustified
coercitive
hierarchy
and
creation
of
system
of
direct
democracy
and
worker
cooperatives
In
practical
terms
anarchy
can
refer
to
curtailment
or
abolition
of
traditional
forms
of
government
and
institutions
It
can
also
designate
nation
or
any
inhabited
place
that
has
no
system
of
government
or
central
rule
Anarchy
is
primarily
advocated
by
individual
anarchists
who
propose
replacing
government
with
voluntary
institutions
These
true
institutions
or
associations
generally
are
modeled
on
nature
since
they
can
represent
concepts
such
as
community
and
economic
selfreliance
interdependence
or
individualism
Although
anarchy
is
often
negatively
used
as
synonym
of
chaos
or
societal
collapse
this
is
not
meaning
that
anarchists
attribute
to
anarchy
society
without
hierarchies
Proudhon
wrote
that
anarchy
is
Not
Daughter
But
Mother
of
Order
Contents
Etymology
Overview
Anthropology
International
relations
Political
philosophy
Anarchism
Immanuel
Kant
Examples
of
statecollapse
anarchy
English
Civil
War
French
Revolution
Jamaica
China
Albania
Somalia
Anarchist
communities
Russian
Civil
War
Spain
Lists
of
ungoverned
communities
Ungoverned
communities
Anarchist
communities
See
also
References
External
links
Etymology
Anarchy
comes
from
Medieval
Latin
anarchia
and
from
Greek
anarchos
having
no
ruler
with
archos
ruler
literally
meaning
without
ruler
The
circleA
anarchist
symbol
is
monogram
that
consists
of
capital
letter
A
surrounded
by
capital
letter
O
The
letter
A
is
derived
from
first
letter
of
anarchy
or
anarchism
in
most
European
languages
and
is
same
in
both
Latin
and
Cyrillic
scripts
The
O
stands
for
order
and
together
they
stand
for
society
seeks
order
in
anarchy
French
la
socit
cherche
lordre
dans
lanarchie
phrase
written
by
PierreJoseph
Proudhon
in
his
book
What
Is
Property
Overview
Anthropology
See
also
Acephalous
society
and
Primitive
communism
CircleA
anarchist
symbol
Although
most
known
societies
are
characterized
by
presence
of
hierarchy
or
state
anthropologists
have
studied
many
egalitarian
stateless
societies
including
most
nomadic
huntergatherer
societies
and
horticultural
societies
such
as
Semai
and
Piaroa
Many
of
these
societies
can
be
considered
to
be
anarchic
in
sense
that
they
explicitly
reject
idea
of
centralized
political
authority
The
egalitarianism
typical
of
human
huntergatherers
is
interesting
when
viewed
in
evolutionary
context
One
of
humanitys
two
closest
primate
relatives
chimpanzee
is
anything
but
egalitarian
forming
hierarchies
that
are
dominated
by
alpha
males
So
great
is
contrast
with
human
huntergatherers
that
it
is
widely
argued
by

that
resistance
to

was

factor

of
human
consciousness
language
kinship
and

organization
In
Fragments
of
Anarchist
Anthropology
anarchist
anthropologist
David

to

of
research
that

might
explore
in
creating
cohesive
body
of
anarchist
social
theory
Graeber
posited
that
anthropology
is
particularly
well
positioned
as
academic
discipline
that
can
look
at
gamut
of
human

and

to
study

and

and

and

to
world
In
Society
Against
State
Pierre
Clastres
examined
stateless
societies
where
certain
cultural
practices
and
attitudes
avert
development
of
hierarchy
and
state
Clastres
dismissed
notion
that
state
is
natural
outcome
of
evolution
of

In
The
Art
of
Not
Being
Governed
James
C
Scott
studied
Zomia
vast
stateless
upland
region
on
Southeast
Asia
The
hills
of
Zomia
isolate
it
from
lowland
states
and
create
refuge
for
people
to
escape
to
Scott
argues
that
particular
social
and
cultural
characteristics
of
hill
people
were
adapted
to
escape
capture
by
lowland
states
and
should
not
be
viewed
as
relics
of
barbarism
abandoned
by
civilization
Peter
Leeson
examined
variety
of
institutions
of
private
law
enforcement
developed
in
anarchic
situations
by
eighteenth
century
pirates
preliterate
tribesmen
and
Californian
prison
gangs
These
groups
all
adapted
different
methods
of
private
law
enforcement
to
meet
their
specific
needs
and
particulars
of
their
anarchic
situation
Anarchoprimitivists
base
their
critique
of
civilization
partly
on
anthropological
studies
of
nomadic
huntergatherers
noting
that
shift
towards
domestication
has
likely
caused
increases
in
disease
labor
inequality
warfare
and
psychological
disorders
Authors
such
as
John
Zerzan
have
argued
that
negative
stereotypes
of
primitive
societies
eg
that
they
are
typically
extremely
violent
or
impoverished
are
used
to
justify
values
of
modern
industrial
society
and
to
move
individuals
further
away
from
more
natural
and
equitable
conditions

and

Definition
of
anarchism
and
libertarianism
Labour
movement
Left
communism
Leftlibertarianism
Libertarianism

Marxism

Anarchism
portal
Politics
portal
v
t
e
Main
article
Anarchism
As
political
philosophy
anarchism
advocates
selfgoverned
societies
based
on
voluntary
institutions
These
are
often
described
as
stateless
societies
although
several
authors
have
defined
them
more
specifically
as
institutions
based
on
nonhierarchical
free
associations
Anarchism
holds
state
to
be
undesirable
unnecessary
or
harmful
While
opposition
to
state
is
central
it
is
necessary
but
not
sufficient
condition
hence
why
in
spite
of
their
names
anarchocapitalism
and
nationalanarchism
are
either
not
recognized
as
anarchist
schools
of
thought
and
as
part
of
anarchist
movement
or
are
seen
by
anarchists
and
scholars
as
fraudulent
and
oxymoron
Anarchism
entails
opposing
authority
or
hierarchical
organisation
in
conduct
of
all
human
relations
including
yet
not
limited
to
state
system
There
are
many
types
and
traditions
of
anarchism
not
all
of
which
are
mutually
exclusive
Anarchist
schools
of
thought
can
differ
fundamentally
supporting
anything
from
extreme
individualism
to
complete
collectivism
Strains
of
anarchism
have
been
divided
into
categories
of
individualist
and
social
anarchism
or
similar
dual
classifications
Anarchism
is
often
considered
to
be
radical
leftwing
or
farleft
movement
and
much
of
anarchist
economics
and
anarchist
law
reflect
antiauthoritarian
antistatist
and
libertarian
interpretations
of
leftwing
and
socialist
politics
such
communism
mutualism
and
syndicalism
among
other
libertarian
socialist
and
socialist
economics
such
as
collectivist
anarchism
freemarket
anarchism
green
anarchism
and
participatory
economics
Within
anarchism
some
individualist
anarchists
are
communists
while
some
anarchocommunists
are
egoists
or
individualists
Where
individualist
forms
of
anarchism
emphasize
personal
autonomy
and
rational
nature
of
human
beings
social
anarchism
sees
individual
freedom
as
conceptually
connected
with
social
equality
and
emphasize
community
and
mutual
aid
In
European
Socialism
A
History
of
Ideas
and
Movements
Carl
Landauer
summarized
difference
between
communist
and
individualist
anarchists
by
stating
that
communist
anarchists
also
do
not
acknowledge
any
right
to
society
to
force
individual
They
differ
from
anarchistic
individualists
in
their
belief
that
men
if
freed
from
coercion
will
enter
into
voluntary
associations
of
communistic
type
while
other
wing
believes
that
free
person
will
prefer
high
degree
of
isolation
As
social
movement
anarchism
has
regularly
endured
fluctuations
in
popularity
The
central
tendency
of
anarchism
as
mass
social
movement
has
been
represented
by
anarchocommunism
and
anarchosyndicalism
with
individualist
anarchism
being
primarily
literary
phenomenon
while
social
anarchism
has
been
dominant
form
of
anarchism
emerging
in
late
th
century
as
distinction
from
individualist
anarchism
after
anarchocommunism
replaced
collectivist
anarchism
as
dominant
tendency
Nonetheless
individualist
anarchism
did
influence
bigger
currents
and
individualists
also
participated
in
large
anarchist
organizations
Some
anarchists
are
pacifists
who
support
selfdefense
or
nonviolence
anarchopacifism
while
others
have
supported
use
of
militant
measures
including
revolution
and
propaganda
of
deed
on
path
to
anarchist
society
Since
s
term
libertarianism
has
been
used
as
synonym
for
anarchism
and
was
used
almost
exclusively
in
this
sense
until
midth
century
development
of
rightlibertarianism
in
United
States
where
classical
liberals
began
to
describe
themselves
as
libertarians
It
has
since
become
necessary
to
distinguish
their
classical
liberal
individualist
and
freemarket
capitalist
philosophy
from
anarchism
The
former
is
often
referred
to
as
rightlibertarianism
whereas
latter
is
described
by
terms
leftlibertarianism
libertarian
socialism
and
socialist
libertarianism
Rightlibertarians
are
divided
into
anarchocapitalists
minarchists
and
voluntaryists
Outside
Englishspeaking
world
libertarianism
generally
retains
its
association
with
anarchism
anticapitalism
libertarian
socialism
and
social
anarchism
Immanuel
Kant
The
German
philosopher
Immanuel
Kant
treated
anarchy
in
his
Anthropology
from
Pragmatic
Point
of
View
as
consisting
of
Law
and
Freedom
without
Force
For
Kant
anarchy
falls
short
of
being
true
civil
state
because
law
is
only
empty
recommendation
if
force
is
not
included
to
make
this
law
efficacious
legitimation
etymologically
fancifully
from
legem
timere
ie
fearing
law
For
there
to
be
such
state
force
must
be
included
while
law
and
freedom
are
maintained
state
which
Kant
calls
republic
Kant
identified
four
kinds
of
government
Law
and
freedom
without
force
anarchy
Law
and
force
without
freedom
despotism
Force
without
freedom
and
law
barbarism
Force
with
freedom
and
law
republic

of
statecollapse
anarchy

also

states

James

The
Commonwealth
of
Oceana
uses
term
to

situation
where

force

absolute

French
Revolution
Main
articles
French
Revolution
and
Reign
of
Terror
Heads
of
aristocrats
on
spikes
Thomas
Carlyle
Scottish
essayist
of
Victorian
era
known
foremost
for
his

rebellion
in
Albania
In
Albania

of

crime

of

Authority
is
defined
in
terms
of
right
to
exercise
social
control
as
explored
in

of
power
and
correlative
duty
to
obey

explored
in

of
practical
reason
Anarchism

relations
by
its

of

Anarchism
then
really
stands
for
liberation
of
human
mind
from
dominion
of

of
human

from

of
property
liberation
from

and

of
government

order
based

of

for

of

real
social
wealth
order
that
will

to

earth
and

of

of

and

Individual
Liberty
Individualist
anarchist
Benjamin

defined
anarchism
as
opposition
to
authority
as
follows

found
that
they
must

or

of

way

and

Thus
were
born
State
Socialism
and
Anarchism
Authority
takes
many
shapes
but
broadly
speaking
her
enemies
divide
themselves
into
three
classes
first
those
who
abhor
her
both
as
means
and
as
end
of
progress
opposing
her
openly
avowedly
sincerely
consistently
universally
second
those
who
profess
to
believe
in
her
as
means
of
progress
but
who
accept
her
only
so
far
as
they
think
she
will
subserve
their
own
selfish
interests
denying
her
and
her
blessings
to
rest
of
world

those
who
distrust
her
as
means
of
progress
believing
in
her
only
as
end
to
be
obtained
by
first
trampling
upon
violating
and
outraging
her
These
three
phases
of
opposition
to
Liberty
are
met
in
almost

sphere
of
thought
and
human
activity
representatives
of
first
are
seen
in
Catholic

and

autocracy
of
second
in

and

school
of
politics

of

in

of

and

Anarchism

Anarchocapitalists
are
against
State
simply

are
capitalists

for
weak

and
ignorant
As

anarchocapitalism
overlooks
egalitarian
implications
of
traditional
individualist
anarchists
like
Spooner
and
Tucker
In
fact
few
anarchists
would
accept
anarchocapitalists
into
anarchist
camp
since
they
do
not
share
concern
for
economic
equality
and
social
justice
Their
selfinterested
calculating
market
men
would
be
incapable
of
practising
voluntary
cooperation
and
mutual
aid
Anarchocapitalists
even
if
they
do
reject
state
might
therefore
best
be
called
rightwing
libertarians
rather
than
anarchists
b
Goodway
David
Anarchist
Seeds
Beneath
Snow
LeftLibertarian
Thought
and
British
Writers
from
William
Morris
to
Colin
Ward
Liverpool
Liverpool
University
Press
p
Libertarian
and
libertarianism
are
frequently
employed
by
anarchists
as
synonyms
for
anarchist
and
anarchism
largely
as
attempt
to
distance
themselves
from
negative
connotations
of
anarchy
and
its
derivatives
The
situation
has
been
vastly
complicated
in
recent
decades
with
rise
of
anarchocapitalism
minimal
statism
and
extreme
rightwing
laissezfaire
philosophy
advocated
by
such
theorists
as
Rothbard
and
Nozick
and
their
adoption
of
words
libertarian
and
libertarianism
It
has
therefore
now
become
necessary
to
distinguish
between
their
right
libertarianism
and
left
libertarianism
of
anarchist
tradition
Newman
Saul
The
Politics
of
Postanarchism
Edinburgh
University
Press
p
It
is
important
to
distinguish
between
anarchism
and
certain
strands
of
rightwing
libertarianism
which
at
times
go
by
same
name
for
example
Rothbards
anarchocapitalism
ISBN
b
c
Carlson
Jennifer
D
Libertarianism
In
Miller
Wilburn
R
ed
The
Social
History
of
Crime
and
Punishment
in
America

p

Otero
Language
and

AK
Press
p
Marshall
Peter
Demanding
Impossible
A
History
of
Anarchism
London
HarperCollins
p
For
long
time
libertarian
was
interchangeable
in
France
with
anarchist
but
in
recent
years
its
meaning
has
become
more
ambivalent
In
general
anarchism
is
closer
to
socialism
than
liberalism
Anarchism
finds
itself
largely
in
socialist
camp
but
it
also
has
outriders
in
liberalism
It
cannot
be
reduced
to
socialism
and
is
best
seen
as
separate
and
distinctive
doctrine

But
if
we
define
anarchy
as
places
without
governments
and
we
define
governments
as
agencies
with
legal
right
to
impose
violence
on
their
subjects
then
whatever
else
occurred
in
Haiti
Sudan
and
Somalia
it
wasnt
anarchy
For
there
were
wellorganized
gangs
eg
governments
in
each
of
these
places
demanding
tribute
and
fighting
others
who
made
similar
impositions
Absence
of
government
means
absence
of
government
whether
well
established
ones
or
flybynights

Politics
portal
v
t
e
A
citystate
is
independent
sovereign
city
which
serves
as
center
of
political
economic
and
cultural
life
over
its
contiguous
territory
They
have
existed
in
many
parts
of
world
since
dawn
of
history
including
cities
such
as
Rome
Athens
Sparta
Carthage
and
Italian
citystates
during
Middle
Ages
and
Renaissance
such
as
Florence
Venice
Genoa
and
Milan
With
rise
of
nation
states
worldwide
only
few
modern
sovereign
citystates
exist
with
some
disagreement
as
to
which
qualify
Monaco
Singapore
and
Vatican
City
are
most
commonly
accepted
as
such
Singapore
is
clearest
example
with
full
selfgovernance
its
own
currency
robust
military
and
population
of
million
A
number
of
other
small
states
share
many
of
these
characteristics
and
are
sometimes
cited
as
modern
citystates
Qatar
Brunei
Kuwait
Bahrain
and
Malta
each
have
urban
center
comprising
significant
proportion
of
population
though
each
has
more
than
one
distinct
municipality
with
one
identified
as
capital
city
Occasionally
microstates
with
high
population
densities
such
as
San
Marino
are
cited
despite
lacking
large
urban
centre
Several
nonsovereign
cities
enjoy
high
degree
of
autonomy
and
are
sometimes
considered
citystates
Macau
Hong
Kong
and
members
of
United
Arab
Emirates
most
notably
Dubai
and
Abu
Dhabi
are
often
cited
as
such
Contents
Historical
background
Ancient
and
medieval
world
Southeast
Asia
Central
Europe
Italy
thcentury
cities
under
international
supervision
Danzig
Fiume
Shanghai
Tangier
Memel
Trieste

square

sq
mi
making

ndmostdensely

world

citystate
well

for

world
Main
article

Until
September

of

his

States

in

of

km
sq
mi

citystatesedit
The
city
of

located
on

is
historic
citystate
and
Swiss
canton
Some
cities
or
urban
areas
while
not
sovereign
states
may
nevertheless
be
constituent
states
of
federation
or
enjoy
high
degree
of
autonomy
As
such
they
function
as
citystates
within
context
of
sovereign
state
to
which
they
belong
Historian
Mogens
Herman
Hansen
describes
this
aspect
of
selfgovernment
as
The
citystate
is
selfgoverning
but
not
necessarily
independent
political
unit
A

with
more
limited

may
be
referred
to
as
independent
city

which
high
degree
of
autonomy
which
have

described
as

Spain
Ceuta
and

of
city
as
sovereign

to

meaning
three

in

and

and

In

citys

and

that

would
prosper

that
then

System
of
government
of
for
and
by
people

representative
democracy
that
operates
under
principles
of
classical
liberalism
see
Liberal
democracy
For
other
uses
see
Democracy
disambiguation
and
Democrat
disambiguation

of

Political

Politics
portal
v
t
e
Democracy
Greek
dmokrati
from
dmos
people
and
kratos
rule
is
form
of
government
in
which
people
have
authority
to
choose
their
governing
legislators
The
decisions
on
who
is
considered
part
of
people
and
how
authority
is
shared
among
or
delegated
by
people
have
changed
over
time
and
at
different
speeds
in
different
countries
but
they
have
included
more
and
more
of
inhabitants
of
all
countries
Cornerstones
include
freedom
of
assembly
and
speech
inclusiveness
and
equality
membership
consent
voting
right
to
life
and
minority
rights
The
notion
of
democracy
has
evolved
over
time
considerably
and
generally
two
current
types
of
democracy
are
direct
and
representative
In
direct
democracy
people
directly
deliberate
and
decide
on
legislation
In
representative
democracy
people
elect
representatives
to
deliberate
and
decide
on
legislation
such
as
in
parliamentary
or
presidential
democracy
Liquid
democracy
combines
elements
of
these
two
basic
types
Prevalent
daytoday
decision
making
of
democracies
is
majority
rule
though
other
decision
making
approaches
like
supermajority
and
consensus
have
been
equally
integral
to
democracies
They
serve
crucial
purpose
of
inclusiveness
and
broader
legitimacy
on
sensitive
issues
counterbalancing
majoritarianism
and
therefore
mostly
take
precedence
on
constitutional
level
In
common
variant
of
liberal
democracy
powers
of
majority
are
exercised
within
framework
of
representative
democracy
but
constitution
limits
majority
and
protects
minority
usually
through
enjoyment
by
all
of
certain
individual
rights
eg
freedom
of
speech
or
freedom
of
association
Besides
these
general
types
of
democracy
there
have
been
wealth
of
further
types
see
below
Democracy
makes
all
forces
struggle
repeatedly
to
realize
their
interests
and
devolves
power
from
groups
of
people
to
sets
of
rules
Western
democracy
as
distinct
from
that
which
existed
in
antiquity
is
generally
considered
to
have
originated
in
citystates
such
as
Classical
Athens
and
Roman
Republic
where
various
schemes
and
degrees
of
enfranchisement
of
free
male
population
were
observed
before
form
disappeared
in
West
at
beginning
of
late
antiquity
The
English
word
dates
back
to
th
century
from
older
Middle
French
and
Middle
Latin
equivalents
According
to
American
political
scientist
Larry
Diamond
democracy
consists
of
four
key
elements
political
system
for
choosing
and
replacing
government
through
free
and
fair
elections
active
participation
of
people
as
citizens
in
politics
and
civic
life
protection
of
human
rights
of
all
citizens
and
rule
of
law
in
which
laws
and
procedures
apply
equally
to
all
citizens
Todd
Landman
nevertheless
draws
our
attention
to
fact
that
democracy
and
human
rights
are
two
different
concepts
and
that
there
must
be
greater
specificity
in
conceptualisation
and
operationalisation
of
democracy
and
human
rights
The
term
appeared
in
th
century
BC
to
denote
political
systems
then
existing
in
Greek
citystates
notably
Athens
to
mean
rule
of
people
in
contrast
to
aristocracy
aristokrata
meaning
rule
of
elite
While
theoretically
these
definitions
are
in
opposition
in
practice
distinction
has
been
blurred
historically
The
political
system
of
Classical
Athens
for
example
granted
democratic
citizenship
to
free
men
and
excluded
slaves
and
women
from
political
participation
In
virtually
all
democratic
governments
throughout
ancient
and
modern
history
democratic
citizenship
consisted
of
elite
class
until
full
enfranchisement
was
won
for
all
adult
citizens
in
most
modern
democracies
through
suffrage
movements
of
th
and
th
centuries
Democracy
contrasts
with
forms
of
government
where
power
is
either
held
by
individual
as
in
absolute
monarchy
or
where
power
is
held
by
small
number
of
individuals
as
in
oligarchy
Nevertheless
these
oppositions
inherited
from
Greek
philosophy
are
now
ambiguous
because
contemporary
governments
have
mixed
democratic
oligarchic
and
monarchic
elements
Karl
Popper
defined
democracy
in
contrast
to
dictatorship
or
tyranny
thus
focusing
on
opportunities
for
people
to
control
their
leaders
and
to
oust
them
without
need
for
revolution
Contents
Characteristics
History
Historic
origins
and
protodemocratic
societies
Origins
Middle
Ages
Modern
era
Early
modern
period
th
and
th
centuries
th
and
st
centuries
Theory
Early
theory
Contemporary
theory
Aggregative
Deliberative
Radical
Measurement
of
democracy
Difficulties
in
measuring
democracy
Types
of
governmental
democracies
Basic
forms
Direct
Representative
Parliamentary
Presidential

or
semidirect
Variants

monarchy

democracy

democracy

politics

democracy

democracy

democracy
Justification
Legitimacy
Better
decisionmaking
Democratic
peace
Economic
success
Criticism
Arrows
theorem
Inefficiencies
Popular
rule
as
faade
Mob
rule
Political
instability

elections

also

cited

reading
External
links
Characteristicsedit
Most
democratic
closest
to
Least
democratic
closest
to
Democracys
de
facto
status
in
world
as
of
according
to
Democracy
Index
by
The
Economist
Democracys
de
jure
status
in
world
as
of
only
Saudi
Arabia
Oman
UAE
Qatar
Brunei
and
Vatican
do
not
claim
to
be
democracy
No
consensus
exists
on
how
to
define
democracy
indeed
one
study
found
that
at
least
descriptions
of
democracy
exist
in
English
language
but
legal
equality
political
freedom
and
rule
of
law
have
been
identified
as
important
characteristics
These
principles
are
reflected
in
all
eligible
citizens
being
equal
before
law
and
having
equal
access
to
legislative
processescitation
needed
For
example
in
representative
democracy
every
vote
has
equal
weight
no

can
apply
to
anyone
seeking
to

representativeaccording

Other

of

include
that
of
direct
democracy
One
theory
holds
that
democracy
requires
three
fundamental
principles
upward
control
sovereignty
residing
at
lowest
levels
of
authority
political
equality
and
social
norms
by
which
individuals
and
institutions
only
consider
acceptable
acts
that
reflect
first
two
principles
of
upward
control
and
political
equality
The
term

is
sometimes
used
as
shorthand
for

which
is
variant
of

that
may
include

before

for
redress
of

process

of

needed

Though

is

There

but

Without

like

of
individual

rights
political

can

competitive
approach
opposed
to

creating
need
that

and
generally

are
substantively
and

just
and

In
some

and

are
considered
important
to

enabling

It

that
basic

is
capacity

in
life
of

With

democracy

because

Originsedit

democracy
The
term
democracy
first
appeared
in
ancient
Greek
political
and
philosophical
thought
in
citystate
of
Athens
during
classical
antiquity
The
word
comes
from
demos
common
people
and
kratos
strength
Led
by
Cleisthenes
Athenians
established
what
is
generally
held
as
first
democracy
in
BC
Cleisthenes
is
referred
to
as
father
of
Athenian
democracy
Athenian
democracy
took
form
of
direct
democracy
and
it
had
two
distinguishing
features
random
selection
of
ordinary
citizens
to
fill
few
existing
government
administrative
and
judicial
offices
and
legislative
assembly
consisting
of
all
Athenian
citizens
All
eligible
citizens
were
allowed
to
speak
and
vote
in
assembly
which
set
laws
of
city
state
However
Athenian
citizenship
excluded
women
slaves
foreigners
mtoikoi
and
men
under
years
of
agecontradictory
Owning
land
was
not
requirement
for
citizenship
but
it
did
allow
one
to
purchase
land
The

of
large

of
population
from
citizen
body
is
closely
related
to
ancient
understanding
of
citizenship
In
most
of
antiquity
benefit
of

was
tied
to
obligation
to
fight
war
campaigns
Athenian
democracy
was
not
only
direct
in
sense
that

were
made
by
assembled
people
but
also
most
direct
in
sense
that
people
through
assembly
boule
and

of
law
controlled
entire
political
process
and
large
proportion
of

were

in
public

Even

of
individual
were
not
secured
by
Athenian

in
modern
sense
ancient
Greeks
had
no

for
rights

not

to
government
but
by

in
city
that

not

to
another
power
and

not

subjects
themselves
to
rule
of
another
person
Range

appeared
in

as

BC

of

shouts

this
childish

manner

After

Thomas
Hobbes
was
first
philosopher
to
articulate
detailed
social
contract
theory
Writing
in
Leviathan
Hobbes
theorized
that
individuals
living
in
state
of
nature
led
lives
that
were
solitary
poor
nasty
brutish
and
short
and
constantly
waged
war
of
all
against
all
In
order
to
prevent
occurrence
of
anarchic
state
of
nature
Hobbes
reasoned
that
individuals
ceded
their
rights
to
strong
authoritarian
government
Later

and
physician
John
Locke
would
posit
different
interpretation
of
social
contract
theory
Writing
in
his
Two
Treatises
of
Government
Locke
posited
that
all
individuals
possessed
inalienable
rights
to
life
liberty
and
estate
property
According
to
Locke
individuals
would
voluntarily
come
together
to
form
state
for
purposes
of
defending
their
rights
Particularly
important
for
Locke
were
property
rights
whose
protection
Locke
deemed
to
be
governments
primary
purpose
Furthermore
Locke
asserted
that
governments
were
legitimate
only
if
they
held
consent
of
governed
For
Locke
citizens
had
right
to
revolt
against
government
that
acted
against
their
interest
or
became
tyrannical
Although
they
were
not
widely
read
during
his
lifetime
Lockes
works
are
considered
founding
documents
of
liberal

and
profoundly

of
American
Revolution
and
later

His

of

remains
preeminent

The

issue

and

of

Democracy

year

Christian
Science
Monitor

that

and

at

of

Theoryedit
Early
theoryedit
Aristotle
contrasted
rule
by
many
democracytimocracy
with
rule
by
few
oligarchyaristocracy
and
with
rule
by
single
person
tyranny
or
today
autocracyabsolute
monarchy
He
also
thought
that
there
was
good
and
bad
variant
of
each
system
he
considered
democracy
to
be
degenerate
counterpart
to
timocracy
A
common
view
among
early
and
renaissance
Republican
theorists
was
that
democracy
could
only
survive
in
small
political
communities
Heeding
lessons
of
Roman
Republics
shift
to
monarchism
as
it
grew
larger
or
smaller
these
Republican
theorists
held
that
expansion
of
territory
and
population
inevitably
led
to
tyranny
Democracy
was
therefore
highly
fragile
and
rare
historically
as
it
could
only
survive
in
small
political
units
which
due
to
their
size
were
vulnerable
to
conquest
by
larger
political
units
Montesquieu
famously
said
if
republic
is
small
it
is
destroyed
by
outside
force
if
it
is
large
it
is
destroyed
by
internal
vice
Rousseau
asserted
It
is
therefore
natural
property
of
small
states
to
be
governed
as
republic
of
middling
ones
to
be
subject
to
monarch
and
of
large
empires
to
be
swayed
by
despotic
prince
Contemporary
theoryedit
Among
modern
political
theorists
there
are
three
contending
conceptions
of
democracy
aggregative
democracy
deliberative
democracy
and
radical
democracy
Aggregativeedit
The
theory
of
aggregative
democracy
claims
that
aim
of
democratic
processes
is
to
solicit
citizens
preferences
and
aggregate
them
together
to
determine
what
social
policies
society
should
adopt
Therefore
proponents
of
this
view
hold
that
democratic
participation
should
primarily
focus
on
voting
where
policy
with
most
votes
gets
implemented
Different
variants
of
aggregative
democracy
exist
Under
minimalism
democracy
is
system
of
government
in
which
citizens
have
given
teams
of
political
leaders
right
to
rule
in
periodic
elections
According
to
this
minimalist
conception
citizens
cannot
and
should
not
rule
because
for
example
on
most
issues
most
of
time
they
have
no
clear
views
or
their
views
are
not
wellfounded
Joseph
Schumpeter
articulated
this
view
most
famously
in
his
book
Capitalism
Socialism
and
Democracy
Contemporary
proponents
of
minimalism
include
William
H
Riker
Adam
Przeworski
Richard
Posner
According
to
theory
of
direct
democracy
on
other
hand
citizens
should
vote
directly
not
through
their
representatives
on
legislative
proposals
Proponents
of
direct
democracy
offer
varied
reasons
to
support
this
view
Political
activity
can
be
valuable
in
itself
it
socialises
and
educates
citizens
and
popular
participation
can
check
powerful
elites
Most
importantly
citizens
do
not
rule
themselves
unless
they
directly
decide
laws
and
policies
Governments
will
tend
to
produce
laws
and
policies
that
are
close
to
views
of
median
voterwith
half
to
their
left
and
other
half
to
their
right
This
is
not
desirable
outcome
as
it
represents
action
of
selfinterested
and
somewhat
unaccountable
political
elites
competing
for
votes
Anthony
Downs
suggests
that
ideological
political
parties
are
necessary
to
act
as
mediating
broker
between
individual
and
governments
Downs
laid
out
this
view
in
his
book
An
Economic
Theory
of
Democracy
Robert
A
Dahl
argues
that
fundamental
democratic
principle
is
that
when
it
comes
to
binding
collective
decisions
each
person
in
political
community
is
entitled
to
have
hisher
interests
be
given
equal
consideration
not
necessarily
that
all
people
are
equally
satisfied
by
collective
decision
He
uses
term
polyarchy
to
refer
to
societies
in
which
there
exists
certain
set
of
institutions
and
procedures
which
are
perceived
as
leading
to
such
democracy
First
and
foremost
among
these
institutions
is
regular
occurrence
of
free
and
open
elections
which
are
used
to
select
representatives
who
then
manage
all
or
most
of
public
policy
of
society
However
these
polyarchic
procedures
may
not
create
full
democracy
if
for
example
poverty
prevents
political
participation
Similarly
Ronald
Dworkin
argues
that
democracy
is
substantive
not
merely
procedural
ideal
Deliberativeedit
Deliberative
democracy
is
based
on
notion
that
democracy
is
government
by
deliberation
Unlike
aggregative
democracy
deliberative
democracy
holds
that
for
democratic
decision
to
be
legitimate
it
must
be
preceded
by
authentic
deliberation
not
merely
aggregation
of
preferences
that
occurs
in
voting
Authentic
deliberation
is
deliberation
among
decisionmakers
that
is
free
from
distortions
of
unequal
political
power
such
as
power
decisionmaker
obtained
through
economic
wealth
or
support
of
interest
groups
If
decisionmakers
cannot
reach
consensus
after
authentically
deliberating
on
proposal
then
they
vote
on
proposal
using
form
of
majority
rule
Citizens
assemblies
are
considered
by
many
scholars
as
practical
examples
of
deliberative
democracy
with
recent
OECD
report
identifying
citizens
assemblies
as
increasingly
popular
mechanism
to
involve
citizens
in
governmental
decisionmaking
Radicaledit
Radical
democracy
is
based
on
idea
that
there
are
hierarchical
and
oppressive
power
relations
that
exist
in
society
Democracys
role
is
to
make
visible
and
challenge
those
relations
by
allowing
for
difference
dissent
and
antagonisms
in
decisionmaking
processes
Measurement
of
democracyedit
Classification
of
countries
according
to
Freedom
Houses
Freedom
in
World
survey
concerning
state
of
world
freedom
in
Free
Partially
Free
Not
Free
Countries
designated
electoral
democracies
in
Freedom
Houses
Freedom
in
World
survey
covering
year
Several
freedom
indices
are
published
by
several
organisations
according
to
their
own
various
definitions
of
term
and
relying
on
different
types
of
data
Freedom
in
World
published
each
year
since
by
USbased
Freedom
House
ranks
countries
by
political
rights
and
civil
liberties
that
are
derived
in
large
measure
from
Universal
Declaration
of
Human
Rights
Countries
are
assessed
as
free
partly
free
or
unfreecitation
needed
Worldwide
Press
Freedom
Index
is
published
each
year
since
except
that
was
combined
with
by
Francebased
Reporters
Without
Borders
Countries
are
assessed
as
having
good
situation
satisfactory
situation
noticeable
problems
difficult
situation
or
very
serious
situation
The
Index
of
Freedom
in
World
is
index
measuring
classical
civil
liberties
published
by
Canadas
Fraser
Institute
Germanys
Liberales
Institute
and
US
Cato
Institute
It
is
not
currently
included
in
table
below
The
CIRI
Human
Rights
Data
Project
measures
range
of
human
civil
womens
and
workers
rights
It
is
now
hosted
by
University
of

Difficulties
in
measuring
democracyedit
Because
democracy
is
overarching
concept
that
includes
functioning
of
diverse
institutions
which
are
not
easy
to
measure
strong
limitations
exist
in
quantifying
and
econometrically
measuring
potential
effects
of
democracy
or
its
relationship
with
other
phenomenawhether
inequality
poverty
education
etc
Given
constraints
in
acquiring
reliable
data
with
withincountry
variation
on
aspects
of
democracy
academics
have
largely
studied
crosscountry
variations
Yet
variations
between
democratic
institutions
are
very
large
across
countries
which
constrains
meaningful
comparisons
using
statistical
approaches
Since
democracy
is
typically
measured
aggregately
as
macro
variable
using
single
observation
for
each
country
and
each
year
studying
democracy
faces
range
of
econometric
constraints
and
is
limited
to
basic
correlations
Crosscountry
comparison
of
composite
comprehensive
and
qualitative
concept
like
democracy
may
thus
not
always
be
for
many
purposes
methodologically
rigorous
or
useful
Types
of
governmental
democraciesedit
Main
article
Types
of
democracy
Democracy
has
taken
number
of
forms
both
in
theory
and
practice
Some
varieties
of
democracy
provide
better
representation
and
more
freedom
for
their
citizens
than
others
However
if
any
democracy
is
not
structured
to
prohibit
government
from
excluding
people
from
legislative
process
or
any
branch
of
government
from
altering
separation
of
powers
in
its
favour
then
branch
of
system
can
accumulate
too
much
power
and
destroy
democracy
Worlds
states
coloured
by
form
of
government
Full
presidential
republics
Semipresidential
republics
Parliamentary
republics
with
executive
president
dependent
on
legislature
Parliamentary
republics
Parliamentary
constitutional
monarchies
Constitutional
monarchies
which
have
separate
head
of
government
but
where
royalty
still
hold
significant
executive
andor
legislative
power
Absolute
monarchies
Oneparty
states
Countries
where
constitutional
provisions
for
government
have
been
suspended
eg
military
dictatorships
Countries
which
do
not
fit
any
of
above
systems

map
was

system

See

Several

are

states
This

only
de
jure

of

and
not

of
democracy
The
following

of

another

Basic
formsedit
Several
variants
of
democracy
exist
but
there
are
two
basic
forms
both
of
which
concern
how
whole
body
of
all
eligible
citizens
executes
its
will
One
form
of
democracy
is
direct
democracy
in
which
all
eligible
citizens
have
active
participation
in
political
decision
making
for
example
voting
on
policy
initiatives
directly
In
most
modern
democracies
whole
body
of
eligible
citizens
remain
sovereign
power
but
political
power
is
exercised
indirectly
through
elected
representatives
this
is
called
representative
democracy
Directedit
A
Landsgemeinde
in
of
canton
of
Glarus
example
of
direct

in
Switzerland
In
Switzerland
without
needing

register
every

receives

and

for
each

and
can
send
it
back
by
post

has
direct

system
and
votes
and

are
organised
about
four
times
year
here
to
Bernes
citizen
in
November
about
national
cantonal

and
elections
government
and

of
City

Main
article
Direct
democracy
Direct
democracy
is
political
system
where
citizens
participate
in
decisionmaking
personally
contrary
to
relying
on
intermediaries
or
representatives
The
use
of
lot
system
characteristic
of
Athenian
democracy
is
unique
to
direct
democracies
In
this
system
important
governmental
and
administrative
tasks
are
performed
by
citizens
picked
from
lottery
A
direct
democracy
gives
voting
population
power
to
Change
constitutional
laws
Put
forth
initiatives
referendums
and
suggestions
for
laws
Give
binding
orders
to
elective
officials
such
as
revoking
them
before
end
of
their
elected
term
or
initiating
lawsuit
for
breaking
campaign
promise
Within
modernday
representative
governments
certain
electoral
tools
like
referendums
citizens
initiatives
and
recall
elections
are
referred
to
as
forms
of
direct
democracy
However
some
advocates
of
direct
democracy
argue
for
local
assemblies
of
facetoface
discussion
Direct
democracy
as
government
system
currently
exists
in
Swiss
cantons
of
Appenzell
Innerrhoden
and
Glarus
Rebel
Zapatista
Autonomous
Municipalities
communities
affiliated
with
CIPORFM
Bolivian
city
councils
of
FEJUVE
and
Kurdish
cantons

Rojava
Representativeedit
Main
article
Representative
democracy
Representative
democracy
involves
election
of
government
officials
by
people
being
represented
If
head
of
state
is
also
democratically
elected
then
it
is
called
democratic
republic
The
most
common
mechanisms
involve
election
of
candidate
with
majority
or
plurality
of
votes
Most
western
countries
have
representative
systems
Representatives
may
be
elected
or
become
diplomatic
representatives
by
particular
district
or
constituency
or
represent
entire
electorate
through
proportional
systems
with
some
using
combination
of
two
Some
representative
democracies
also
incorporate
elements
of
direct
democracy
such
as
referendums
A
characteristic
of
representative
democracy
is
that
while
representatives
are
elected
by
people
to
act
in
peoples
interest
they
retain
freedom
to
exercise
their
own
judgement
as
how
best
to
do
so
Such
reasons
have
driven
criticism
upon
representative
democracy
pointing
out
contradictions
of
representation
mechanisms
with
democracy
Parliamentaryedit
Main
article
Parliamentary
system
Parliamentary
democracy
is
representative
democracy
where
government
is
appointed
by
or
can
be
dismissed
by
representatives
as
opposed
to
presidential
rule
wherein
president
is
both
head
of
state
and
head
of
government
and
is
elected
by
voters
Under
parliamentary
democracy
government
is
exercised
by
delegation
to
executive
ministry
and
subject
to
ongoing
review
checks
and
balances
by
legislative
parliament
elected
by
people
Parliamentary
systems
have
right
to
dismiss
Prime
Minister
at
any
point
in
time
that
they
feel
he
or
she
is
not
doing
their
job
to
expectations
of
legislature
This
is
done
through
Vote
of
No
Confidence
where
legislature
decides
whether
or
not
to
remove
Prime
Minister
from
office
by
majority
support
for
his
or
her
dismissal
In
some
countries
Prime
Minister
can
also
call
election
whenever
he
or
she
so
chooses
and
typically
Prime
Minister
will
hold
election
when
he
or
she
knows
that
they
are
in
good
favour
with
public
as
to
get
reelected
In
other
parliamentary
democracies
extra
elections
are
virtually
never
held
minority
government
being
preferred
until
next
ordinary
elections
An
important
feature
of
parliamentary
democracy
is
concept
of
loyal
opposition
The
essence
of
concept
is
that
second
largest
political
party
or
coalition
opposes
governing
party
or
coalition
while
still
remaining
loyal
to
state
and
its
democratic
principles
Presidentialedit
Main
article
Presidential
system
Presidential
Democracy
is
system
where
public
elects
president
through
free
and
fair
elections
The
president
serves
as
both
head
of
state
and
head
of
government
controlling
most
of
executive
powers
The
president
serves
for
specific
term
and
cannot
exceed
that
amount
of
time
Elections
typically
have
fixed
date
and
arent
easily
changed
The
president
has
direct
control
over
cabinet
specifically
appointing
cabinet
members
The
president
cannot
be
easily
removed
from
office
by
legislature
but
he
or
she
cannot
remove
members
of
legislative
branch
any
more
easily
This
provides
some
measure
of
separation
of
powers
In
consequence
however
president
and
legislature
may
end
up
in
control
of
separate
parties
allowing
one
to
block
other
and
thereby
interfere
with
orderly
operation
of
state
This
may
be
reason
why
presidential
democracy
is
not
very
common
outside
Americas
Africa
and
Central
and
Southeast
Asia
A
semipresidential
system
is
system
of
democracy
in
which
government
includes
both
prime
minister
and
president
The
particular
powers
held
by
prime
minister
and
president
vary
by
country
Hybrid
or
semidirectedit
See
also
Politics
of
Switzerland
and
Voting
in
Switzerland
Some
modern
democracies
that
are
predominantly
representative
in
nature
also
heavily
rely
upon
forms
of
political
action
that
are
directly
democratic
These
democracies
which
combine
elements
of
representative
democracy
and
direct
democracy
are
termed
hybrid
democracies
semidirect
democracies
or
participatory
democracies
Examples
include
Switzerland
and
some
US
states
where
frequent
use
is
made
of
referendums
and
initiatives
The
Swiss
confederation
is
semidirect
democracy
At
federal
level
citizens
can
propose
changes
to
constitution
federal
popular
initiative
or
ask
for
referendum
to
be
held
on
any
law
voted
by
parliament
Between
January
and
June
Swiss
citizens
voted
times
to
answer
questions
during
same
period
French
citizens
participated
in
only
two
referendums
Although
in
past
years
less
than
initiatives
have
been
put
to
referendum
The
populace
has
been
conservative
approving
only
about
of
initiatives
put
before
them
in
addition
they
have
often
opted
for
version
of
initiative
rewritten
by
governmentcitation
needed
Examples
include
extensive
use
of
referendums
in
US
state
of
California
which
is
state
that
has
more
than
million
voters
In
New
England
Town
meetings
are
often
used
especially
in
rural
areas
to
manage
local
government
This
creates
hybrid
form
of
government
with
local
direct

and
representative
state
government
For

most
Vermont

annual

in
March
in
which
town
officers
are
elected
budgets
for
town
and

are
voted
on
and
citizens
have
opportunity
to
speak
and
be
heard
on
political
matters

Constitutional
monarchyedit
Main
article
Constitutional
monarchy
Queen
Elizabeth
II
constitutional
monarch
Many
countries
such
as
United
Kingdom
Spain
Netherlands
Belgium
Scandinavian
countries
Thailand
Japan
and
Bhutan
turned
powerful

into

with
limited
or
often
gradually
merely

roles
For
example
in

states
to

began

and
has

since
Glorious

and

along
with
aristocratic

China

Germany
Austria

Italy

with

became

in

upper

Over

Republicedit
Main
article
Republicanism
The

has

meanings
but
today
often

to
representative
democracy
with
elected
head
of
state
such
as
president
serving
for

term
in
contrast
to
states
with

monarch
as
head
of
state
even
if
these
states
also
are
representative

with
elected
or
appointed
head
of
government
such
as

minister
The
Founding

of
United
States
rarely

and
often

democracy
which
in

to
specifically
mean
direct

often

protection
of
constitution
enshrining
basic
rights
James

especially
in
The

No
that
what

from

was
that
former
became

as

and

from

of

whereas
republic
could
get

as

got
larger
and
combats
faction
by
its
very
structure
What
was
critical
to
American
values
John
Adams
insisted
was
that
government
be

fixed
laws
which
people
have
voice
in

and

to
defend

republicif

Liberal
democracyedit
Main
article
Liberal
democracy
A
liberal
democracy
is
representative
democracy
in
which
ability
of
elected
representatives
to
exercise
decisionmaking
power
is
subject
to
rule
of
law
and
moderated
by
constitution
or
laws
that
emphasise
protection
of
rights
and
freedoms
of
individuals
and
which
places
constraints
on
leaders
and
on
extent
to
which
will
of
majority
can
be
exercised
against
rights
of
minorities
see
civil
liberties
In
liberal
democracy
it
is
possible
for
some
largescale
decisions
to
emerge
from
many
individual
decisions
that
citizens
are
free
to
make
In
other
words
citizens
can
vote
with
their
feet
or
vote
with
their
dollars
resulting
in
significant
informal
governmentbymasses
that
exercises
many
powers
associated
with
formal
government
elsewhere
Socialistedit
See
also
Democracy
in
Marxism
Socialist
thought
has
several
different
views
on
democracy
Social
democracy
democratic
socialism
and
dictatorship
of
proletariat
usually
exercised
through
Soviet
democracy
are
some
examples
Many
democratic
socialists
and
social
democrats
believe
in
form
of
participatory
industrial
economic
andor
workplace
democracy
combined
with
representative
democracy
Within
Marxist
orthodoxy
there
is
hostility
to
what
is
commonly
called
liberal
democracy
which
is
simply
referred
to
as
parliamentary
democracy
because
of
its
often
centralised
nature
Because
of
orthodox
Marxists
desire
to
eliminate
political
elitism
they
see
in
capitalism
Marxists
Leninists
and
Trotskyists
believe
in
direct
democracy
implemented
through
system
of
communes
which
are
sometimes
called
soviets
This
system
ultimately
manifests
itself
as
council
democracy
and
begins
with
workplace
democracy
Democracy
cannot
consist
solely
of
elections
that
are
nearly
always
fictitious
and
managed
by
rich
landowners
and
professional
politicians
Che
Guevara
Speech
Uruguay
Anarchistedit
Anarchists
are
split
in
this
domain
depending
on
whether
they
believe
that
majorityrule
is
tyrannic
or
not
To
many
anarchists
only
form
of
democracy
considered
acceptable
is
direct
democracy
PierreJoseph
Proudhon
argued
that
only
acceptable
form
of
direct
democracy
is
one
in
which
it
is
recognised
that
majority
decisions
are
not
binding
on
minority
even
when
unanimous
However
anarchocommunist
Murray
Bookchin
criticised
individualist
anarchists
for
opposing
democracy
and
says
majority
rule
is
consistent
with
anarchism
Some
anarchocommunists
oppose
majoritarian
nature
of
direct
democracy
feeling
that
it
can
impede
individual
liberty
and
optin
favour
of
nonmajoritarian
form
of
consensus
democracy
similar
to
Proudhons
position
on
direct
democracy
Henry
David
Thoreau
who
did
not
selfidentify
as
anarchist
but
argued
for
better
government
and
is
cited
as
inspiration
by
some
anarchists
argued
that
people
should
not
be
in
position
of
ruling
others
or
being
ruled
when
there
is
no
consent
Sortitionedit
Main
article
Sortition
Sometimes
called
democracy
without
elections
sortition
chooses
decision
makers
via
random
process
The
intention
is
that
those
chosen
will
be
representative
of
opinions
and
interests
of
people
at
large
and
be
more
fair
and
impartial
than
elected
official
The
technique
was
in
widespread
use
in
Athenian
Democracy
and
Renaissance
Florence
and
is
still
used
in
modern
jury
selection
Consociationaledit
Main
article
Consociational
democracy
A
consociational
democracy
allows
for
simultaneous
majority
votes
in
two
or
more
ethnoreligious
constituencies
and
policies
are
enacted
only
if
they
gain
majority
support
from
both
or
all
of
them
Consensus
democracyedit
Main
article
Consensus
democracy
A
consensus
democracy
in
contrast
would
not
be
dichotomous
Instead
decisions
would
be
based
on
multioption
approach
and
policies
would
be
enacted
if
they
gained
sufficient
support
either
in
purely
verbal
agreement
or
via
consensus
vote
multioption
preference
vote
If
threshold
of
support
were
at
sufficiently
high
level
minorities
would
be
as
it
were
protected
automatically
Furthermore
any
voting
would
be
ethnocolour
blind
Supranationaledit
Qualified
majority
voting
is
designed
by
Treaty
of
Rome
to
be
principal
method
of
reaching
decisions
in
European
Council
of
Ministers
This
system
allocates
votes
to
member
states
in
part
according
to
their
population
but
heavily
weighted
in
favour
of
smaller
states
This
might
be
seen
as
form
of
representative
democracy
but
representatives
to
Council
might
be
appointed
rather
than
directly
elected

Students

Youth
