Society
portal
v
t
e
Main
article
Inclusive
democracy
Inclusive
democracy
is
political
theory
and
political
project
that
aims
for
direct
democracy
in
all
fields
of
social
life
political
democracy
in
form
of
facetoface
assemblies
which
are
confederated
economic
democracy
in
stateless
moneyless
and
marketless
economy
democracy
in
social
realm
ie
selfmanagement
in
places
of
work
and
education
and
ecological
democracy
which
aims
to
reintegrate
society
and
nature
The
theoretical
project
of
inclusive
democracy
emerged
from
work
of
political
philosopher
Takis
Fotopoulos
in
Towards
An
Inclusive
Democracy
and
was
further
developed
in
journal
Democracy
Nature
and
its
successor
The
International
Journal
of
Inclusive
Democracy
The
basic
unit
of
decision
making
in
inclusive
democracy
is
demotic
assembly
ie
assembly
of
demos
citizen
body
in
given
geographical
area
which
may
encompass
town
and
surrounding
villages
or
even
neighbourhoods
of
large
cities
An
inclusive
democracy
today
can
only
take
form
of
confederal
democracy
that
is
based
on
network
of
administrative
councils
whose
members
or
delegates
are
elected
from
popular
facetoface
democratic
assemblies
in
various
demoi
Thus
their
role
is
purely
administrative
and
practical
not
one
of
policymaking
like
that
of
representatives
in
representative
democracy
The
citizen
body
is
advised
by
experts
but
it
is
citizen
body
which
functions
as
ultimate
decisiontaker
Authority
can
be
delegated
to
segment
of
citizen
body
to
carry
out
specific
duties
for
example
to
serve
as
members
of
popular
courts
or
of
regional
and
confederal
councils
Such
delegation
is
made
in
principle
by
lot
on
rotation
basis
and
is
always
recallable
by
citizen
body
Delegates
to
regional
and
confederal
bodies
should
have
specific
mandates
Participatory
politicsedit
Main
article
Participatory
politics
A
Parpolity
or
Participatory
Polity
is
theoretical
form
of
democracy
that
is
ruled
by
Nested
Council
structure
The
guiding
philosophy
is
that
people
should
have
decision
making
power
in
proportion
to
how
much
they
are
affected
by
decision
Local
councils
of
people
are
completely
autonomous
on
issues
that
affect
only
them
and
these
councils
send
delegates
to
higher
level
councils
who
are
again
autonomous
regarding
issues
that
affect
only
population
affected
by
that
council
A
council
court
of
randomly
chosen
citizens
serves
as
check
on
tyranny
of
majority
and
rules
on
which
body
gets
to
vote
on
which
issue
Delegates
may
vote
differently
from
how
their
sending
council
might
wish
but
are
mandated
to
communicate
wishes
of
their
sending
council
Delegates
are
recallable
at
any
time
Referendums
are
possible
at
any
time
via
votes
of
most
lowerlevel
councils
however
not
everything
is
referendum
as
this
is
most
likely
waste
of
time
A
parpolity
is
meant
to
work
in
tandem
with
participatory
economy
Cosmopolitanedit
Main
article
Cosmopolitan
democracy
Cosmopolitan
democracy
also
known
as
Global
democracy
or
World
Federalism
is
political
system
in
which
democracy
is
implemented
on
global
scale
either
directly
or
through
representatives
An
important
justification
for
this
kind
of
system
is
that
decisions
made
in
national
or
regional
democracies
often
affect
people
outside
constituency
who
by
definition
cannot
vote
By
contrast
in
cosmopolitan
democracy
people
who
are
affected
by
decisions
also
have
say
in
them
According
to
its
supporters
any
attempt
to
solve
global
problems
is
undemocratic
without
some
form
of
cosmopolitan
democracy
The
general
principle
of
cosmopolitan
democracy
is
to
expand
some
or
all
of
values
and
norms
of
democracy
including
rule
of
law
nonviolent
resolution
of
conflicts
and
equality
among
citizens
beyond
limits
of
state
To
be
fully
implemented
this
would
require
reforming
existing
international
organisations
eg
United
Nations
as
well
as
creation
of
new
institutions
such
as
World
Parliament
which
ideally
would
enhance
public
control
over
and
accountability
in
international
politics
Cosmopolitan
Democracy
has
been
promoted
among
others
by
physicist
Albert
Einstein
writer
Kurt
Vonnegut
columnist
George
Monbiot
and
professors
David
Held
and
Daniele
Archibugi
The
creation
of
International
Criminal
Court
in
was
seen
as
major
step
forward
by
many
supporters
of
this
type
of
cosmopolitan
democracy
Creative
democracyedit
Main
article
Creative
democracy
Creative
Democracy
is
advocated
by
American
philosopher
John
Dewey
The
main
idea
about
Creative
Democracy
is
that
democracy
encourages
individual
capacity
building
and
interaction
among
society
Dewey
argues
that
democracy
is
way
of
life
in
his
work
of
Creative
Democracy
The
Task
Before
Us
and
experience
built
on
faith
in
human
nature
faith
in
human
beings
and
faith
in
working
with
others
Democracy
in
Deweys
view
is
moral
ideal
requiring
actual
effort
and
work
by
people
it
is
not
institutional
concept
that
exists
outside
of
ourselves
The
task
of
democracy
Dewey
concludes
is
forever
that
of
creation
of
freer
and
more
humane
experience
in
which
all
share
and
to
which
all
contribute
Guided
democracyedit
Main
article
Guided
democracy
Guided
democracy
is
form
of
democracy
which
incorporates
regular
popular
elections
but
which
often
carefully
guides
choices
offered
to
electorate
in
manner
which
may
reduce
ability
of
electorate
to
truly
determine
type
of
government
exercised
over
them
Such
democracies
typically
have
only
one
central
authority
which
is
often
not
subject
to
meaningful
public
review
by
any
other
governmental
authority
Russianstyle
democracy
has
often
been
referred
to
as
Guided
democracy
Russian
politicians
have
referred
to
their
government
as
having
only
one
center
of
power
authority
as
opposed
to
most
other
forms
of
democracy
which
usually
attempt
to
incorporate
two
or
more
naturally
competing
sources
of
authority
within
same
government
Nongovernmental
democracyedit
Aside
from
public
sphere
similar
democratic
principles
and
mechanisms
of
voting
and
representation
have
been
used
to
govern
other
kinds
of
groups
Many
nongovernmental
organisations
decide
policy
and
leadership
by
voting
Most
trade
unions
and
cooperatives
are
governed
by
democratic
elections
Corporations
are
controlled
by
shareholders
on
principle
of
one
share
one
votesometimes
supplemented
by
workplace
democracy
Amitai
Etzioni
has
postulated
system
that
fuses
elements
of
democracy
with
sharia
law
termed
islamocracycitation
needed
Justificationedit
This
section
does
not
cite
any
sources
Please
help
improve
this
section
by
adding
citations
to
reliable
sources
Unsourced
material
may
be
challenged
and
removed
December
Learn
how
and
when
to
remove
this
template
message
Several
justifications
for
democracy
have
been
postulated
Legitimacyedit
Social
contract
theory
argues
that
legitimacy
of
government
is
based
on
consent
of
governed
ie
election
and
that
political
decisions
must
reflect
general
will
Better
decisionmakingedit
Condorcets
jury
theorem
is
logical
proof
that
if
each
decisionmaker
has
better
than
chance
probability
of
making
right
decision
then
having
largest
number
of
decisionmakers
ie
democracy
will
result
in
best
decisions
This
has
also
been
argued
by
theories
of
wisdom
of
crowd
Democratic
peaceedit
Democratic
peace
theory
claims
that
liberal
democracies
do
not
go
to
war
against
each
other
Economic
successedit
In
Why
Nations
Fail
Daron
Acemoglu
and
James
A
Robinson
argue
that
democracies
are
more
economically
successful
because
undemocratic
political
systems
tend
to
limit
markets
and
favor
monopolies
at
expense
of
creative
destruction
which
is
necessary
for
sustained
economic
growth
Criticismedit
Main
article
Criticism
of
democracy
Arrows
theoremedit
Arrows
impossibility
theorem
suggests
that
democracy
is
logically
incoherent
This
is
based
on
certain
set
of
criteria
for
democratic
decisionmaking
being
inherently
conflicting
Protests
However
Arrows
formal
premises
can
be
considered
overly
strict
and
with
their
reasonable
weakening
logical
incoherence
of
democracy
looks
much
less
critical
Inefficienciesedit
Some
economists
have
criticized
efficiency
of
democracy
citing
premise
of
irrational
voter
or
voter
who
makes
decisions
without
all
of
facts
or
necessary
information
in
order
to
make
truly
informed
decision
Another
argument
is
that
democracy
slows
down
processes
because
of
amount
of
input
and
participation
needed
in
order
to
go
forward
with
decision
A
common
example
often
quoted
to
substantiate
this
point
is
high
economic
development
achieved
by
China
nondemocratic
country
as
compared
to
India
democratic
country
According
to
economists
lack
of
democratic
participation
in
countries
like
China
allows
for
unfettered
economic
growth
On
other
hand
Socrates
believed
that
democracy
without
educated
masses
educated
in
broader
sense
of
being
knowledgeable
and
responsible
would
only
lead
to
populism
being
criteria
to
become
elected
leader
and
not
competence
This
would
ultimately
lead
to
demise
of
nation
This
was
quoted
by
Plato
in
book
of
The
Republic
in
Socrates
conversation
with
Adimantus
Socrates
was
of
opinion
that
right
to
vote
must
not
be
indiscriminate
right
for
example
by
birth
or
citizenship
but
must
be
given
only
to
people
who
thought
sufficiently
of
their
choice
Popular
rule
as
faadeedit
The
thcentury
Italian
thinkers
Vilfredo
Pareto
and
Gaetano
Mosca
independently
argued
that
democracy
was
illusory
and
served
only
to
mask
reality
of
elite
rule
Indeed
they
argued
that
elite
oligarchy
is
unbendable
law
of
human
nature
due
largely
to
apathy
and
division
of
masses
as
opposed
to
drive
initiative
and
unity
of
elites
and
that
democratic
institutions
would
do
no
more
than
shift
exercise
of
power
from
oppression
to
manipulation
As
Louis
Brandeis
once
professed
We
may
have
democracy
or
we
may
have
wealth
concentrated
in
hands
of
few
but
we
cant
have
bothclarification
needed
British
writer
Ivo
Mosley
grandson
of
blackshirt
Oswald
Mosley
describes
in
In
Name
of
People
PseudoDemocracy
and
Spoiling
of
Our
World
how
and
why
current
forms
of
electoral
governance
are
destined
to
fall
short
of
their
promise
A
study
led
by
Princeton
professor
Martin
Gilens
of
US
government
decisions
concluded
that
elites
and
organized
groups
representing
business
interests
have
substantial
independent
impacts
on
US
government
policy
while
average
citizens
and
massbased
interest
groups
have
little
or
no
independent
influence
Mob
ruleedit
Platos
The
Republic
presents
critical
view
of
democracy
through
narration
of
Socrates
Democracy
which
is
charming
form
of
government
full
of
variety
and
disorder
and
dispensing
sort
of
equality
to
equals
and
unequaled
alike
In
his
work
Plato
lists
forms
of
government
from
best
to
worst
Assuming
that
Republic
was
intended
to
be
serious
critique
of
political
thought
in
Athens
Plato
argues
that
only
Kallipolis
aristocracy
led
by
unwilling
philosopherkings
wisest
men
is
just
form
of
government
James
Madison
critiqued
direct
democracy
which
he
referred
to
simply
as
democracy
in
Federalist
No
arguing
that
representative
democracywhich
he
described
using
term
republicis
preferable
form
of
government
saying
democracies
have
ever
been
spectacles
of
turbulence
and
contention
have
ever
been
found
incompatible
with
personal
security
or
rights
of
property
and
have
in
general
been
as
short
in
their
lives
as
they
have
been
violent
in
their
deaths
Madison
offered
that
republics
were
superior
to
democracies
because
republics
safeguarded
against
tyranny
of
majority
stating
in
Federalist
No
same
advantage
which
republic
has
over
democracy
in
controlling
effects
of
faction
is
enjoyed
by
large
over
small
republic
Political
instabilityedit
More
recently
democracy
is
criticised
for
not
offering
enough
political
stability
As
governments
are
frequently
elected
on
and
off
there
tends
to
be
frequent
changes
in
policies
of
democratic
countries
both
domestically
and
internationally
Even
if
political
party
maintains
power
vociferous
headlinegrabbing
protests
and
harsh
criticism
from
popular
media
are
often
enough
to
force
sudden
unexpected
political
change
Frequent
policy
changes
with
regard
to
business
and
immigration
are
likely
to
deter
investment
and
so
hinder
economic
growth
For
this
reason
many
people
have
put
forward
idea
that
democracy
is
undesirable
for
developing
country
in
which
economic
growth
and
reduction
of
poverty
are
top
priorities
This
opportunist
alliance
not
only
has
handicap
of
having
to
cater
to
too
many
ideologically
opposing
factions
but
it
is
usually
shortlived
since
any
perceived
or
actual
imbalance
in
treatment
of
coalition
partners
or
changes
to
leadership
in
coalition
partners
themselves
can
very
easily
result
in
coalition
partner
withdrawing
its
support
from
government
Biased
media
has
been
accused
of
causing
political
instability
resulting
in
obstruction
of
democracy
rather
than
its
promotion
Fraudulent
electionsedit
In
representative
democracies
it
may
not
benefit
incumbents
to
conduct
fair
elections
A
study
showed
that
incumbents
who
rig
elections
stay
in
office
times
as
long
as
those
who
permit
fair
elections
Democracies
in
countries
with
high
per
capita
income
have
been
found
to
be
less
prone
to
violence
but
in
countries
with
low
incomes
tendency
is
reverse
Election
misconduct
is
more
likely
in
countries
with
low
per
capita
incomes
small
populations
rich
in
natural
resources
and
lack
of
institutional
checks
and
balances
SubSaharan
countries
as
well
as
Afghanistan
all
tend
to
fall
into
that
category
Governments
that
have
frequent
elections
tend
to
have
significantly
more
stable
economic
policies
than
those
governments
who
have
infrequent
elections
However
this
trend
does
not
apply
to
governments
where
fraudulent
elections
are
common
Oppositionedit
Main
article
Antidemocratic
thought
Democracy
in
modern
times
has
almost
always
faced
opposition
from
previously
existing
government
and
many
times
it
has
faced
opposition
from
social
elites
The
implementation
of
democratic
government
within
nondemocratic
state
is
typically
brought
about
by
democratic
revolution
Developmentedit
Main
article
Democratization
Banner
in
Hong
Kong
asking
for
democracy
August
Several
philosophers
and
researchers
have
outlined
historical
and
social
factors
seen
as
supporting
evolution
of
democracy
Other
commentators
have
mentioned
influence
of
economic
development
In
related
theory
Ronald
Inglehart
suggests
that
improved
livingstandards
in
modern
developed
countries
can
convince
people
that
they
can
take
their
basic
survival
for
granted
leading
to
increased
emphasis
on
selfexpression
values
which
correlates
closely
with
democracy
Douglas
M
Gibler
and
Andrew
Owsiak
in
their
study
argued
about
importance
of
peace
and
stable
borders
for
development
of
democracy
It
has
often
been
assumed
that
democracy
causes
peace
but
this
study
shows
that
historically
peace
has
almost
always
predated
establishment
of
democracy
Carroll
Quigley
concludes
that
characteristics
of
weapons
are
main
predictor
of
democracy
Democracythis
scenariotends
to
emerge
only
when
best
weapons
available
are
easy
for
individuals
to
obtain
and
use
By
s
guns
were
best
personal
weapons
available
and
in
United
States
of
America
already
nominally
democratic
almost
everyone
could
afford
to
buy
gun
and
could
learn
how
to
use
it
fairly
easily
Governments
couldnt
do
any
better
it
became
age
of
mass
armies
of
citizen
soldiers
with
guns
Similarly
Periclean
Greece
was
age
of
citizen
soldier
and
democracy
Other
theories
stressed
relevance
of
education
and
of
human
capitaland
within
them
of
cognitive
ability
to
increasing
tolerance
rationality
political
literacy
and
participation
Two
effects
of
education
and
cognitive
ability
are
distinguishedneed
quotation
to
verify
cognitive
effect
competence
to
make
rational
choices
better
informationprocessing
ethical
effect
support
of
democratic
values
freedom
human
rights
etc
which
itself
depends
on
intelligence
Evidence
consistent
with
conventional
theories
of
why
democracy
emerges
and
is
sustained
has
been
hard
to
come
by
Statistical
analyses
have
challenged
modernisation
theory
by
demonstrating
that
there
is
no
reliable
evidence
for
claim
that
democracy
is
more
likely
to
emerge
when
countries
become
wealthier
more
educated
or
less
unequal
Neither
is
there
convincing
evidence
that
increased
reliance
on
oil
revenues
prevents
democratisation
despite
vast
theoretical
literature
on
Resource
Curse
that
asserts
that
oil
revenues
sever
link
between
citizen
taxation
and
government
accountability
seen
as
key
to
representative
democracy
The
lack
of
evidence
for
these
conventional
theories
of
democratisation
have
led
researchers
to
search
for
deep
determinants
of
contemporary
political
institutions
be
they
geographical
or
demographic
More
inclusive
institutions
lead
to
democracy
because
as
people
gain
more
power
they
are
able
to
demand
more
from
elites
who
in
turn
have
to
concede
more
things
to
keep
their
positioncitation
needed
This
virtuous
circle
may
end
up
in
democracy
An
example
of
this
is
disease
environment
Places
with
different
mortality
rates
had
different
populations
and
productivity
levels
around
world
For
example
in
Africa
tsetse
flywhich
afflicts
humans
and
livestockreduced
ability
of
Africans
to
plow
land
This
made
Africa
less
settled
As
consequence
political
power
was
less
concentrated
This
also
affected
colonial
institutions
European
countries
established
in
Africa
Whether
colonial
settlers
could
live
or
not
in
place
made
them
develop
different
institutions
which
led
to
different
economic
and
social
paths
This
also
affected
distribution
of
power
and
collective
actions
people
could
take
As
result
some
African
countries
ended
up
having
democracies
and
others
autocracies
An
example
of
geographical
determinants
for
democracy
is
having
access
to
coastal
areas
and
rivers
This
natural
endowment
has
positive
relation
with
economic
development
thanks
to
benefits
of
trade
Trade
brought
economic
development
which
in
turn
broadened
power
Rulers
wanting
to
increase
revenues
had
to
protect
propertyrights
to
create
incentives
for
people
to
invest
As
more
people
had
more
power
more
concessions
had
to
be
made
by
ruler
and
in
manyquantify
places
this
process
lead
to
democracy
These
determinants
defined
structure
of
society
moving
balance
of
political
power
In
st
century
democracy
has
become
such
popular
method
of
reaching
decisions
that
its
application
beyond
politics
to
other
areas
such
as
entertainment
food
and
fashion
consumerism
urban
planning
education
art
literature
science
and
theology
has
been
criticised
as
reigning
dogma
of
our
time
The
argument
suggests
that
applying
populist
or
marketdriven
approach
to
art
and
literature
for
example
means
that
innovative
creative
work
goes
unpublished
or
unproduced
In
education
argument
is
that
essential
but
more
difficult
studies
are
not
undertaken
Science
as
truthbased
discipline
is
particularly
corrupted
by
idea
that
correct
conclusion
can
be
arrived
at
by
popular
vote
However
more
recently
theoristswhich
have
also
advanced
concept
epistemic
democracy
to
assert
that
democracy
actually
does
good
job
tracking
truth
Robert
Michels
asserts
that
although
democracy
can
never
be
fully
realised
democracy
may
be
developed
automatically
in
act
of
striving
for
democracy
The
peasant
in
fable
when
on
his
deathbed
tells
his
sons
that
treasure
is
buried
in
field
After
old
mans
death
sons
dig
everywhere
in
order
to
discover
treasure
They
do
not
find
it
But
their
indefatigable
labor
improves
soil
and
secures
for
them
comparative
wellbeing
The
treasure
in
fable
may
well
symbolise
democracy
Dr
Harald
Wydra
in
his
book
Communism
and
The
Emergence
of
Democracy
maintains
that
development
of
democracy
should
not
be
viewed
as
purely
procedural
or
as
static
concept
but
rather
as
ongoing
process
of
meaning
formation
Drawing
on
Claude
Leforts
idea
of
empty
place
of
power
that
power
emanates
from
people
but
is
power
of
nobody
he
remarks
that
democracy
is
reverence
to
symbolic
mythical
authorityas
in
reality
there
is
no
such
thing
as
people
or
demos
Democratic
political
figures
are
not
supreme
rulers
but
rather
temporary
guardians
of
empty
place
Any
claim
to
substance
such
as
collective
good
public
interest
or
will
of
nation
is
subject
to
competitive
struggle
and
times
of
forclarification
needed
gaining
authority
of
office
and
government
The
essence
of
democratic
system
is
empty
place
void
of
real
people
which
can
only
be
temporarily
filled
and
never
be
appropriated
The
seat
of
power
is
there
but
remains
open
to
constant
change
As
such
peoples
definitions
of
democracy
or
of
democratic
progress
throughout
history
as
continual
and
potentially
neverending
process
of
social
construction

is
subject

law

all

effective

control
whereby

might

enforced

subjects

Relevance
of
education
and
intelligence
for
political
development
of
nations
Democracy
rule
of
law
and
political
liberty
Intelligence
doijintell
Political
theory
has
described
positive
linkage
between
education
cognitive
ability
and
democracy
This
assumption
is
confirmed
by
positive
correlations
between
education
cognitive
ability
and
positively
valued
political
conditions
N
It
is
shown
that
in
second
half
of
th
century
education
and
intelligence
had
strong
positive
impact
on
democracy
rule
of
law
and
political
liberty
independent
from
wealth
GDP
and
chosen
country
sample
One
possible
mediator
of
these
relationships
is
attainment
of
higher
stages
of
moral
judgment
fostered
by
cognitive
ability
which
is
necessary
for
function
of
democratic
rules
in
society
The
other
mediators
for
citizens
as
well
as
for
leaders
could
be
increased
competence
and
willingness
to
process
and
seek
information
necessary
for
political
decisions
due
to
greater
cognitive
ability
There
are
also
weaker
and
less
stable
reverse
effects
of
rule
of
law
and
political
freedom
on
cognitive

Dictatorship
Wikipedia
Dictatorship
From
Wikipedia
free
encyclopedia
Jump
to
navigation
Jump
to
search
Authoritarian
form
of
government
Benito
Mussolini
left
and
Adolf
Hitler
Hitlers
policies
and
orders
both
directly
and
indirectly
resulted
in
deaths
of
about
million
people
in
Europe
Mussolini
was
dictator
who
marked
beginning
of
Fascism
in
Europe
Part
of
Politics
series
Basic
forms
of
government
Power
source

rule
by
many

Politics
portal
v
t
e
A
dictatorship
is
form
of
government
characterized
by
single
leader
or
group
of
leaders
and
little
or
no
toleration
for
political
pluralism
or
independent
media
According
to
other
definitions
democracies
are
form
of
government
in
which
those
who
govern
are
selected
through
contested
elections
therefore
dictatorships
are
not
democracies
With
advent
of
th
and
th
centuries
dictatorships
and
constitutional
democracies
emerged
as
worlds
two
major
forms
of
government
gradually
eliminating
monarchies
one
of
traditional
widespread
forms
of
government
of
time
Typically
in
dictatorial
regime
leader
of
country
is
identified
with
title
of
dictator
although
their
formal
title
may
more
closely
resemble
something
similar
to
leader
A
common
aspect
that
characterized
dictatorship
is
taking
advantage
of
their
strong
personality
usually
by
suppressing
freedom
of
thought
and
speech
of
masses
in
order
to
maintain
complete
political
and
social
supremacy
and
stability
Dictatorships
and
totalitarian
societies
generally
employ
political
propaganda
to
decrease
influence
of
proponents
of
alternative
governing
systems
Contents

dictatorships

in
Roman
Empire

American
caudillos

dictatorships
of
th
century

American
dictatorships
of
th
century

established
by
Operation
Condor

dictatorships

in
Africa
and
Asia
after
World
War
II
Democratization
Theories
of
dictatorship
See
also
References
Further
reading
Etymologyedit
Main
article
Roman
dictator
The
word
dictator
comes
from
Latin
language
word
dicttor
agent
noun
from
dictare
dictt
past
participial
stem
of
dictre
dictate
v
or
or
suffix
In
Latin
use
dictator
was
judge
in
Roman
Republic
temporarily
invested
with
absolute
power
Typesedit
A
dictatorship
has
been
largely
defined
as
form
of
government
in
which
absolute
power
is
concentrated
in
hands
of
leader
commonly
identified
as
dictator
small
clique
or
government
organization
and
it
aims
to
abolish
political
pluralism
and
civilian
mobilization
On
other
hand
democracy
which
is
generally
compared
to
concept
of
dictatorship
is
defined
as
form
of
government
in
which
power
belongs
to
population
and
rulers
are
elected
through
contested
elections
A
newer
form
of
government
originating
around
early
th
century
commonly
linked
to
concept
of
dictatorship
is
known
as
totalitarianism
It
is
characterized
by
presence
of
single
political
party
and
more
specifically
by
powerful
leader
real
role
model
who
imposes
his
personal
and
political
prominence
The
two
fundamental
aspects
that
contribute
to
maintenance
of
power
are
steadfast
collaboration
between
government
and
police
force
and
highly
developed
ideology
The
government
has
total
control
of
mass
communications
and
social
and
economic
organizations
According
to
Hannah
Arendt
totalitarianism
is
new
and
extreme
form
of
dictatorship
composed
of
atomized
isolated
individuals
In
addition
she
affirmed
that
ideology
plays
leading
role
in
defining
how
entire
society
should
be
organized
According
to
political
scientist
Juan
Linz
distinction
between
authoritarian
regime
and
totalitarian
one
is
that
while
authoritarian
regime
seeks
suffocate
politics
and
political
mobilization
but
totalitarianism
seeks
to
control
politics
and
political
mobilization
However
one
of
most
recent
classification
of
dictatorships
does
not
identify
totalitarianism
as
form
of
dictatorship
Barbara
Geddess
study
focuses
in
how
eliteleader
and
elitemass
relations
influence
authoritarian
politics
Her
typology
identifies
key
institutions
that
structure
elite
politics
in
dictatorships
ie
parties
and
militaries
The
study
is
based
on
and
directly
related
to
some
factors
like
simplicity
of
categorizations
crossnational
applicability
emphasis
on
elites
and
leaders
and
incorporation
of
institutions
parties
and
militaries
as
central
to
shaping
politics
According
to
her
dictatorial
government
may
be
classified
in
five
typologies
military
dictatorships
singleparty
dictatorships
personalist
dictatorships
monarchies
and
hybrid
dictatorships
Military
dictatorshipsedit
Main
article
Military
dictatorship
Military
dictatorships
are
regimes
in
which
group
of
officers
holds
power
determines
who
will
lead
country
and
exercises
influence
over
policy
Highlevel
elites
and
leader
are
members
of
military
dictatorship
Military
dictatorships
are
characterized
by
rule
by
professionalized
military
as
institution
In
military
regimes
elites
are
referred
to
as
junta
members
who
are
typically
senior
officers
and
often
other
highlevel
officers
in
military
This
type
of
dictatorship
was
imposed
during
th
century
in
countries
such
as
Chile
by
Augusto
Pinochet
Argentina
by
Jorge
Rafael
Videla
and
other
leaders
Uruguay
by
Juan
Maria
Bordaberry
Paraguay
by
Alfredo
Stroessner
Bolivia
by
Hugo
Banzer
Brazil
by
Humberto
de
Alencar
Castelo
Branco
Singleparty
dictatorshipsedit
Main
article
Oneparty
state
Xi
Jinping
current
CCP
General
Secretary
ruling
China
Singleparty
dictatorships
are
regimes
in
which
one
party
dominates
politics
In
singleparty
dictatorships
single
party
has
access
to
political
posts
and
control
over
policy
In
singleparty
dictatorships
party
elites
are
typically
members
of
ruling
body
of
party
sometimes
called
central
committee
politburo
or
secretariat
Those
groups
of
individuals
controls
selection
of
party
officials
and
organizes
distribution
of
benefits
to
supporters
and
mobilizes
citizens
to
vote
and
show
support
for
party
leaders
Current
oneparty
states
include
China
Cuba
Eritrea
Laos
North
Korea
and
Vietnam
though
North
Korea
is
sometimes
also
classified
as
personalist
dictatorship
The
Sahrawi
Arab
Democratic
Republic
which
is
not
recognized
by
UN
is
also
oneparty
state
but
is
not
considered
to
be
dictatorship
Personalist
dictatorshipsedit
Personalist
dictatorships
are
regimes
in
which
all
power
lies
in
hands
of
single
individual
Personalist
dictatorships
differ
from
other
forms
of
dictatorships
in
their
access
to
key
political
positions
other
fruits
of
office
and
depend
much
more
on
discretion
of
personalist
dictator
Personalist
dictators
may
be
members
of
military
or
leaders
of
political
party
However
neither
military
nor
party
exercises
power
independently
from
dictator
In
personalist
dictatorships
elite
corps
are
usually
made
up
of
close
friends
or
family
members
of
dictator
These
individuals
are
all
typically
handpicked
to
serve
their
posts
by
dictator
According
to
study
personalist
dictatorships
are
more
repressive
than
other
forms
of
dictatorship
Monarchic
dictatorshipsedit
Main
article
Absolute
monarchy
King
Salman
of
Saudi
Arabia
Monarchic
dictatorships
are
in
regimes
in
which
person
of
royal
descent
has
inherited
position
of
head
of
state
in
accordance
with
accepted
practice
or
constitution
Regimes
are
not
considered
dictatorships
if
monarchs
role
is
largely
ceremonial
but
absolute
monarchies
such
as
Saudi
Arabia
can
be
considered
hereditary
dictatorships
Real
political
power
must
be
exercised
by
monarch
for
regimes
to
be
classified
as
such
Elites
in
monarchies
are
typically
members
of
royal
family
Hybrid
dictatorshipsedit
Hybrid
dictatorships
are
regimes
that
blend
qualities
of
personalist
singleparty
and
military
dictatorships
When
regimes
share
characteristics
of
all
three
forms
of
dictatorships
they
are
referred
to
as
triple
threats
The
most
common
forms
of
hybrid
dictatorships
are
personalistsingleparty
hybrids
and
personalistmilitary
hybrids
Measuring
dictatorshipsedit
Democracy
Index
by
Economist
Intelligence
Unit
Green
represents
more
democratic
countries
while
yellow
and
red
are
considered
as
hybrid
regimes
and
authoritarian
governments
respectively
Most
dictatorships
are
represented
as
darker
shades
of
red
One
of
tasks
in
political
science
is
to
measure
and
classify
regimes
as
either
dictatorships
or
democracies
US
based
Freedom
House
Polity
IV
and
DemocracyDictatorship
Index
are
three
of
most
used
data
series
by
political
scientists
Generally
two
research
approaches
exist
minimalist
approach
which
focuses
on
whether
country
has
continued
elections
that
are
competitive
and
substantive
approach
which
expands
concept
of
democracy
to
include
human
rights
freedom
of
press
and
rule
of
law
The
DemocracyDictatorship
Index
is
seen
as
example
of
minimalist
approach
whereas
Polity
data
series
is
more
substantive
Historyedit
Between
two
world
wars
three
types
of
dictatorships
have
been
described
constitutional
counterrevolutionary
and
fascist
Since
World
War
II
broader
range
of
dictatorships
has
been
recognized
including
Third
World
dictatorships
theocratic
or
religious
dictatorships
and
dynastic
or
familybased
dictatorships
Dictators
in
Roman
Empireedit
During
Republican
phase
of
Ancient
Rome
Roman
dictator
was
special
magistrate
who
held
well
defined
powers
normally
for
six
months
at
time
usually
in
combination
with
consulship
Caesar
Augustus
Germanicus
Alias
Caligula
was
Roman
dictator
most
cruel
of
Roman
Empire
ruled
since
AD
until
AD
Roman
dictators
were
allocated
absolute
power
during
times
of
emergency
In
execution
their
power
was
originally
neither
arbitrary
nor
unaccountable
being
subject
to
law
and
requiring
retrospective
justification
There
were
no
such
dictatorships
after
beginning
of
nd
century
BC
and
later
dictators
such
as
Sulla
and
Roman
emperors
exercised
power
much
more
personally
and
arbitrarily
A
concept
that
remained
anathema
to
traditional
Roman
society
institution
was
not
carried
forward
into
Roman
Empire
thcentury
Latin
American
caudillosedit
Main
article
Caudillo
Antonio
Lpez
de
Santa
Anna
wearing
Mexican
military
uniform
After
collapse
of
Spanish
colonial
rule
various
dictators
came
to
power
in
many
liberated
countries
Often
leading
private
army
these
caudillos
or
selfappointed
politicalmilitary
leaders
attacked
weak
national
governments
once
they
controlled
regions
political
and
economic
powers
with
examples
such
as
Antonio
Lpez
de
Santa
Anna
in
Mexico
and
Juan
Manuel
de
Rosas
in
Argentina
Such
dictatorships
have
been
also
referred
to
as
personalismos
The
wave
of
military
dictatorships
in
South
America
in
second
half
of
twentieth
century
left
particular
mark
on
Latin
American
culture
In
Latin
American
literature
dictator
novel
challenging
dictatorship
and
caudillismo
is
significant
genre
There
are
also
many
films
depicting
Latin
American
military
dictatorships
Fascist
dictatorships
of
th
centuryedit
In
first
half
of
th
century
fascist
dictatorships
appeared
in
variety
of
European
countries
at
same
time
as
rise
of
communism
which
are
distinct
from
dictatorships
in
Latin
America
and
postcolonial
dictatorships
in
Africa
and
Asia
The
main
examples
of
fascist
dictatorship
include
The
Nazi
Germany
of
Adolf
Hitler
during
World
War
II
annexed
various
territories
like
Luxembourg
Netherlands
and
Belgium
The
Empire
of
Japan
which
was
led
by
Hideki
Tojo
and
others
The
Prathet
Thai
of
Plaek
Phibunsongkhram
which
was
only
Asian
independent
ally
of
Empire
of
Japan
The
Fascist
Italy
of
Benito
Mussolini
which
would
later
be
renamed
as
Italian
Social
Republic
The
Austrofascist
Austria
of
Engelbert
Dollfuss
and
succeeded
by
Kurt
Schuschnigg
The
Protectorate
of
Bohemia
and
Moravia
of
Emil
Hcha
The
Slovak
Republic
of
Jozef
Tiso
The
Spain
of
Francisco
Franco
The
France
of
Philippe
Ptain
The
Romania
of
Ion
Antonescu

of
Mikls

The

under

and

Dictatorships
in
Africa
and
Asia
after
World
War
IIedit
Mobutu
Sese
Seko
Zaires
longtime
dictator
After
World
War
II
dictators
established
themselves
in
several
new
states
of
Africa
and
Asia
often
at
expense
or
failure
of
constitutions
inherited
from
colonial
powers
These
constitutions
often
failed
to
work
without
strong
middle
class
or
work
against
preexisting
autocratic
rule
Some
elected
presidents
and
prime
ministers
captured
power
by
suppressing
opposition
and
installing
oneparty
rule
and
others
established
military
dictatorships
through
their
armies
Whatever
their
form
these
dictatorships
had
adverse
impact
on
economic
growth
and
quality
of
political
institutions
Dictators
who
stayed
in
office
for
long
period
of
time
found
it
increasingly
difficult
to
carry
out
sound
economic
policies
The
oftencited
exploitative
dictatorship
is
regime
of

Sese
Seko

ruled

from

billion
from

Democratizationedit
The
global
dynamics
of
democratization
has
been
central
question
for
political
scientists
The
Third
Wave
Democracy
was
said
to
turn
some
dictatorships
into
democracies
see
also
contrast
between
two
figures
of
DemocracyDictatorship
Index
in
and
One
of
rationales
that
Bush
Administration
employed
periodically
during
runup
to
invasion
of
Iraq
is
that
deposing
Saddam
Hussein
and
installing
democratic
government
in
Iraq
would
promote
democracy
in
other
Middle
Eastern
countries
However
according
to
The
Huffington
Post
The
nations
and
territories
with
little
or
no
democratic
rule
represent
more
than
half
of
roughly
countries
now
hosting
US
bases
Research
by
political
scientist
Kent
Calder
confirms
whats
come
to
be
known
as
dictatorship
hypothesis
The
United
States
tends
to
support
dictators
and
other
undemocratic
regimes
in
nations
where
it
enjoys
basing
facilities
Theories
of
dictatorshipedit
This
section
needs
expansion
You
can
help
by
adding
to
it
December
See
also
Dictatorship
of
proletariat
Mancur
Olson
suggests
that
emergence
of
dictatorships
can
be
linked
to
concept
of
roving
bandits
individuals
in
atomic
system
who
move
from
place
to
place
extracting
wealth
from
individuals
These
bandits
provide
disincentive
for
investment
and
production
Olson
states
that
community
of
individuals
would
be
served
less
badly
if
that
bandit
were
to
establish
himself
as
stationary
bandit
to
monopolize
theft
in
form
of
taxes
Except
from
community
bandits
themselves
will
be
better
served
according
to
Olson
by
transforming
themselves
into
stationary
bandits
By
settling
down
and
making
themselves
rulers
of
territory
they
will
be
able
to
make
more
profits
through
taxes
than
they
used
to
obtain
through
plunder
By
maintaining
order
and
providing
unsollicited
protection
to
community
bandits
will
create
environment
in
which
people
can
increase
their
surplus
which
means
greater
taxable
base
Thus
potential
dictator
will
have
greater
incentive
to
provide
illusion
of
security
to
given
community
from
which
he
is
extracting
taxes
and
conversely
unthinking
part
of
people
from
whom
he
extracts
taxes
are
more
likely
to
produce
because
they
will
be
unconcerned
with
potential
theft
by
other
bandits
This
is
rational
that
bandits
use
in
order
to
explain
their
transformation
from
roving
bandits
into
stationary
bandits

to

Appendix
Unlike
substantive
measures
of
democracy
eg
Polity
IV
and
Freedom
House
binary
conceptualization
of
democracy
most
recently
described
by
Cheibub
Gandhi
and
Vreeland
focuses
on
one
institutionelectionsto
distinguish
between
dictatorships
and
democracies
Using
minimalist
measure
of
democracy
rather
than
substantive
one
better
allows
for
isolation
of
causal
mechanisms
Cheibub
Gandhi
and
Vreeland
linking
regime
type
to
human
rights
outcomes

xiv

Retrieved
March
In
period
between
two
world
wars
three
types
of
dictatorships
were
described
by
number
of
smart
people
constitutional
counterrevolutionary
and
fascist
Many
have
rightfully
questioned
distinctions
between
these
prototypes
In
fact
since
World
War
II
we
have
recognized
that
range
of
dictatorships
is
much
broader
than
earlier
posited
and
it
includes
socalled
Third
World
dictatorships
in
Africa
Asia
Latin
America
and
Middle
East
and
religious
dictatorshipsThey
are
also
family
dictatorships

translation
like
DeepL
or
Google
Translate
is
useful
starting
point
for
translations
but
translators
must
revise
errors
as
necessary
and
confirm
that
translation
is
accurate
rather
than
simply
copypasting
machinetranslated
text
into
English
Wikipedia

not
translate
text
that
appears
unreliable
or
lowquality

possible

with

in

Great

Superpower
Politics
portal
v
t
e
A
directorial
republic
is
country
ruled
by
college
of
several
people
who
jointly
exercise
powers
of
head
of
state
andor
head
of
government
In
political
history
term
directory
in
French
directoire
is
applied
to
high
collegial
institutions
of
state
composed
of
members
styled
director
The
most
important
of
these
by
far
was
Directory
of
in
France
The
system
was
inspired
by
Pennsylvania
Constitution
of
which
prominently
featured
collegial
member
Supreme
Executive
Council
with
primus
inter
pares
President
Variants
of
this
form
of
government
based
on
French
model
were
also
established
in
European
regions
conquered
by
France
during
French
Revolutionary
Wars
In
past
Uruguay
Yugoslavia
after
Ukraine
and
other
countries
were
ruled
by
directories
The
government
of
Soviet
Union
could
in
some
ways
be
characterized
as
directory
but
it
developed
in
much
different
pattern
discussed
in
article
on
Communist
states
The
sole
country
now
using
this
form
of
government
is
Switzerland
and
to
lesser
extent
San
Marino
where
directories
rule
all
levels
of
administration
federal
cantonal
and
municipal
The
Swiss
Federal
Council
is
elected
by
Parliament
for
four
years
its
members
cannot
be
dismissed
and
is
composed
of
seven
members
among
whom
one
is
president
and
one
is
vicepresident
on
rotating
basis
although
these
positions
are
symbolic
in
normal
circumstances
There
is
no
relationship
of
confidence
between
Parliament
and
Federal
Council
It
is
shared
system
of
government
that
reflects
and
represents
heterogeneity
and
multiethnicity
of
Swiss
people

popular
elections
are
used
at

Definitionedit
A
directorial
system
is
system
of
government
in
which
executive
power
is
split
among
select
number
of
individuals
who
are
or
de
facto
are
equals
Somewho
have
argued
that
diarchies
such
as
Andorra
are
directorial
as
executive
power
is
held
between
more
than
one
personcitation
needed
Israels
parliamentary
system
codified
streamlined
variant
of
Westminster
System
under
which
executive
power
is
vested
directly
in
multiperson
Cabinet
in
contrast
to
President
acting
on
advice
of
Cabinet
as
in
normal
Westminster
System
can
be
seen
as
semidirectorial

A
federacy
is
form
of
government
where
one
or
several
substate
units
enjoy
considerably
more
independence
than
majority
of
substate
units
To
some
extent
such
arrangement
can
be
considered
to
be
similar
to
asymmetric
federalism

Descriptionedit
A
federacy
is
form
of
government
with
features
of
both
federation
and
unitary
state
In
federacy
at
least
one
of
constituent
parts
of
state
is
autonomous
while
other
constituent
parts
are
either
not
autonomous
or
comparatively
less
autonomous
An
example
of
such
arrangement
is
Finland
where
land
which
has
status
of
autonomous
province
has
considerably
more
autonomy
than
other
provinces
The
autonomous
constituent
part
enjoys
degree
of
independence
as
though
it
was
part
of
federation
while
other
constituent
parts
are
as
independent
as
subunits
in
unitary
state
This
autonomy
is
guaranteed
in
countrys
constitution
The
autonomous
subunits
are
often
former
colonial
possessions
or
are
home
to
different
ethnic
group
from
rest
of
country
These
autonomous
subunits
often
have
special
status
in
international
relations
Federaciesedit
This
list
is
incomplete
you
can
help
by
adding
missing
items
with
reliable
sources
Several
states
are
federacies
The
exact
autonomy
of
subunits
differs
from
country
to
country

articles

of

branch
and
Barbuda
Council

is
autonomous
within
Antigua
and
Barbuda
Australia
and
Norfolk
Islandedit
Norfolk
Island
selfgovernment
was
revoked
by
Australian
Federal
Government
in
Its
laws
were
subsumed
into
laws
of
Australian
federal
government
and
be
subordinate
to
them
On
July
federal
government
increased
federal
regulations
so
that
federal
laws
would
also
apply
to
Norfolk
Island
and
to
make
it
semiautonomous
Since
then
opposition
by
several
organizations
have
protested
these
action
to
United
Nations
to
include
island
on
its
list
of
nonselfgoverning
territories
Azerbaijan
and
Nakhchivanedit

is
autonomous
part
of
Azerbaijan
Fiji
and

articles

and

and

has
status
of
dependency
in

Finland
and
landedit
The
archipelago
of
land
is
region
of
Finland
but
compared
to
other
regions
it
enjoys
high
degree
of
home
rule
Extensive
autonomy
was
granted
to
it
in
Act
on
Autonomy
of
land
of
last
revised
and
autonomy
was
affirmed
by
League
of
Nations
decision
in
The
Parliament
of
land
Lagtinget
handles
duties
that
in
other
provinces
are
exercised
by
state
provincial
offices
of
central
government
land
sends
one
representative
to
Finnish
parliament
and
is
member
of
Nordic
Council
It
is
demilitarised
and
population
is
exempt
from
conscription
land
has
issued
its
own
postage
stamps
since
and
runs
its
own
police
force
Most
of
lands
inhabitants
speak
Swedish
as
their
first
language
in
lands
autonomous
status
was
result
of
disputes
between
Sweden
and
Imperial
Russia
in
and
between
Finland
and
Sweden
France
and
its
overseas
landsedit
The
French
Republic
is
divided
into
rgions
of
which
are
in
metropolitan
France
Corsica
one
of
these
is
strictly
speaking
not
rgion
but
is
often
counted
as
such
Five
of
rgions
are
rgions
doutremer
overseas
regions
France
also
has
five
collectivits
doutremer
one
territoire
doutremer
and
one
collectivit
sui
generis
All
are
integral
parts
of
France
and
subject
to
French
law
but
New
Caledonia
collectivit
sui
generis
and
French
Polynesia
one
of
five
collectivits
doutremer
but
with
designation
of
pays
doutremer
have
considerably
more
autonomy
All
except
uninhabited
French
Southern
and
Antarctic
Lands
are
represented
in
French
parliament
Defence
and
diplomatic
affairs
are
responsibilities
of
France
but
they
do
participate
in
some
organisations
directly
Runion
for
example
is
member
of
Indian
Ocean
Commission
In
addition
France
has
remote
Clipperton
Island
in
Pacific
under
direct
authority
of
Minister
of
Overseas
France
French
overseas
territories
were
in
past
colonial
possessions
Iraq
and
Kurdistanedit
Kurdistan
Region
Arab
Iraq
and
Kurdistan
Region
have
de
jure
full
sovereignty
over
internal
matters
for
their
respective
regions
The
agreement
was
upheld
in
countrys
constitution
Kashmir
and
IndiaPakistanedit
After
independence
from
British
rule
princely
states
of
British
India
were
given
choice
to
opt
for
either
India
or
Pakistan
The
Kashmir
state
was
ruled
by
Hindu
king
Maharaja
Hari
Singh
but
majority
of
its
population
was
Muslim
According
to
Burton
Steins
History
of
India
Kashmir
was
neither
as
large
nor
as
old
independent
state
as
Hyderabad
it
had
been
created
rather
offhandedly
by
British
after
first
defeat
of
Sikhs
in
as
reward
to
former
official
who
had
sided
with
British
The
Himalayan
kingdom
was
connected
to
India
through
district
of
Punjab
but
its
population
was
per
cent
Muslim
and
it
shared
boundary
with
Pakistan
Hence
it
was
anticipated
that
maharaja
would
accede
to
Pakistan
when
British
paramountcy
ended
on
August
When
he
hesitated
to
do
this
Pathan
tribesman
launched
guerrilla
onslaught
meant
to
sway
its
ruler
into
their
favour
and
became
fugitive
leader
Instead
Maharaja
appealed
to
Mountbatten
for
assistance
and
governorgeneral
agreed
on
condition
that
ruler
accede
to
India
Indian
soldiers
entered
Kashmir
and
drove
Pakistanisponsored
irregulars
from
all
but
small
section
of
state
The
United
Nations
was
then
invited
to
mediate
quarrel
The
UN
mission
insisted
that
opinion
of
Kashmiris
must
be
ascertained
while
India
insisted
that
no
referendum
could
occur
until
all
of
state
had
been
cleared
of
irregulars
Currently
region
is
divided
amongst
three
countries
in
territorial
dispute
Pakistan
controls
northwest
portion
GilgitBaltistan
and
Azad
Jammu
and
Kashmir
India
controls
central
and
southern
portion
Jammu
and
Kashmir
and
Ladakh
and
Peoples
Republic
of
China
controls
northeastern
portion
Aksai
Chin
and
TransKarakoram
Tract
India
controls
majority
of
Siachen
Glacier
area
including
Saltoro
Ridge
passes
whilst
Pakistan
controls
lower
territory
just
southwest
of
Saltoro
Ridge
India
controls
km
sq
mi
of
disputed
territory
Pakistan
km
sq
mi
and
PRC
remaining
km
sq
mi
Mauritius
and
Rodriguesedit
On
November
Mauritius
National
Assembly
unanimously
adopted
two
laws
giving
Rodrigues
its
autonomy
creating
decentralised
government
system
This
new
legislation
has
allowed
implementation
of
regional
assembly
in
Rodrigues
constituting
members
and
executive
council
headed
by
Chief
Commissioner
The
council
meets
every
week
to
make
decisions
draw
up
laws
and
manage
budget
The
Chief
Commissioner
has
main
task
of
informing
Mauritian
Prime
Minister
of
management
of
islands
concerns
Moldova
and
Gagauziaedit
In
Gagauzia
territory
in
southern
part
of
Republic
of
Moldova
inhabited
by
Gagauz
people
ethnic
group
distinct
from
majority
Moldovans
was
given
autonomy
including
right
of
external
selfdetermination
This
is
in
contrast
to
other
subdivisions
of
Moldova
raioane
which
are
countylevel
administrative
areas
with
little
autonomy
However
eastern
part
of
Moldova
is
internationally
unrecognized
breakaway
republic
Transnistria
which
is
de
facto
selfgoverning
Netherlands
Aruba
Curaao
and
Sint
Maartenedit
The
Kingdom
of
Netherlands
consists
of
four
autonomous
countries
linked
by
Charter
for
Kingdom
of
Netherlands
as
constituent
parts
Netherlands
autonomous
independent
country
and
Aruba
Curaao
and
Sint
Maarten
three
separate
nonindependent
autonomous
countries
Aruba
Curaao
and
Sint
Maarten
formerly
made
up
Netherlands
Antilles
which
was
colony
of
Netherlands
until
Aruba
reached
agreement
on
decolonization
with
Kingdom
of
Netherlands
following
referendum
held
in
and
became
autonomous
and
separate
from
Antilles
with
status
aparte
meaning
status
of
autonomous
country
with
its
full
autonomous
country
status
officially
recognized
in
Charter
since
The
Charter
links
four
separate
autonomous
countries
The
three
countries
Aruba
Curaao
and
StMaarten
dont
have
statehood
but
do
have
Dutch
nationality
and
passport
in
common
with
Netherlands
All
four
countries
including
State
of
Netherlands
have
separate
constitutions
governments
and
parliaments
but
Aruba
alone
has
its
own
national
currency
and
Central
Bank
The
Council
of
Ministers
of
Kingdom
as
whole
consists
de
facto
of
Council
of
Ministers
of
Netherlands
together
with
three
ministers
plenipotentiary
one
nominated
by
each
of
other
countries
The
legislature
of
Kingdom
consists
of
parliament
of
Netherlands
De
facto
cabinet
and
parliament
of
Netherlands
are
responsible
for
administration
of
dependencies
Aruba
Curaao
and
St
Maarten
besides
being
responsible
for
Dutch
government
There
is
limited
participation
of
politicians
of
other
countries
Aruba
Curaao
and
Sint
Maarten
share
Common
Court
of
Appeals
Dutch
Hoge
Raad
High
Council
acts
as
their
supreme
court
Dutch
nationals
related
to
these
territories
are
fully
European
citizens
however
DutchCaribbean
citizens
residing
in
Aruba
Curaao
and
Sint
Maarten
are
normally
not
entitled
to
vote
in
Dutch
elections
but
can
vote
in
elections
for
European
Parliament
Aruba
Curaao
and
Sint
Maarten
are
overseas
countries
and
territories
OCTs
listed
under
Annex
II
of
EC
Treaty
Hence
EC
law
does
not
apply
there
The
Netherlands
Antilles
was
scheduled
to
be
dissolved
as
unified
political
entity
on
December
so
that
five
constituent
islands
would
attain
new
constitutional
statuses
within
Kingdom
of
Netherlands
but
this
dissolution
was
postponed
until
October
Curaao
and
Sint
Maarten
gained
autonomy
as
nonindependent
countries
within
Kingdom
like
Aruba
did
in
and
three
remaining
islands
of
Bonaire
Sint
Eustatius
and
Saba
became
special
municipalities
of
Netherlands
itself
New
Zealand
and
Cook
Islandsedit
Cook
Islands
is
member
of
Pacific
Islands
Forum
and
as
such
is
part
of
Umbrella
Agreement
including
Australia
and
New
Zealand
called
Pacific
Agreement
on
Closer
Economic
Relations
PACER
This
agreement
includes
future
creation
of
free
trade
area
amongst
ACP
Forum
Islands
Countries
FICs
called
Pacific
Island
Countries
Trade
Agreement
PICTA
without
Australia
and
New
Zealand
Under
Cotonou
Agreement
Cook
Islands
is
committed
to
negotiating
new
reciprocal
Economic
Partnership
Agreement
EPA
between
ACP
states
and
EU
which
was
due
to
come
into
force
in
Cook
Islands
also
benefits
from
th
EDF
PRIP
Regional
Trade
and
Economic
Integration
Programme
which
provides
approximately
million
to
assist
Region
in
implementing
PICTA
negotiate
trade
agreements
with
developed
partners
eg
EPA
intensify
links
with
WTO
and
address
supplyside
constraints

Papua

autonomous
government
Saint
Kitts
and

within

and

Tom

from

Tom
since
Serbia

and

Metochia

latter

Tajikistan
and

Badakhshan
is
autonomous
region
in

consisting
of
local
districts
Its

is
considered
somewhat
sovereign
to
Tajik
government
but
region
has
from
time
to

been
in
militant
conflict
just
as
in
Tanzania
and
Zanzibaredit
Tanzania
is
divided
in
regions
Five
of
those
regions
together
form
Zanzibar
This
island
is
selfgoverning
region
It
elects
its
own
president
who
has
control
over
internal
matters
of
island
Zanzibar
was
independent
sultanate
and
British
protectorate
while
Tanganyika
was
German
Schutzgebiet
until
when

became
British
mandate
territory
The
two

united
in
after
popular

against
Sultan
of
Zanzibar

Ukraine
and
Crimeaedit
Soviet
postal
stamp
of
years
before
Crimean
transfer
The
Autonomous
Republic
of
Crimea
within
Ukraine
exists
in
unregulated
form
as
Constitution
of
Ukraine
states
that
Ukraine
is
unitary
state
Following
Russian
annexation
of
Crimea
second
annexation
there
appeared
number
of
speculations
around
region
To
justify
annexation
there
appeared
story
about
drunkard
and
Ukrainian
sympathizer
Nikita
Khrushchev
who
supposedly
unconstitutionally
transferred
territory
from
Russia
to
Ukraine
In
reality
following
World
War
II
peninsula
was
in
critical
situation
which
even
more
intensified
after
deportation
of
Crimean
Tatars
indigenous
population
in
spring
of
In
in
Ukraine
was
created
new
Kherson
Oblast
out
of
Mykolaiv
and
Zaporizhia
oblasts
In
summer
of
peninsula
was
stripped
of
its
autonomous
status
as
its
title
nation
was
removed
and
turned
to
regular
oblast
of
Russia
To
resolve
issue
of
drought
in
Crimea
in
in
Ukraine
started
construction
of
Kakhovka
Hydroelectric
Power
Plant
and
new
city
of
Nova
Kakhovka
to
serve
it
At
same
time
there
was
adopted
decision
to
build
North
Crimean
Canal
The
new
power
station
improve
supply
of
power
to
peninsula
while
its
dam
created
Kakhovka
Reservoir
waters
of
which
were
used
for
amelioration
of
steppe
areas
of
Kherson
oblast
and
Crimea
In
Crimean
Oblast
was
transferred
to
Ukraine
main
motif
was
to
put
all
sites
of
planned
power
station
dam
and
city
under
same
administration
During
s
to
Crimea
has
dug
North
Crimean
Canal
through
steppe
territory
of
Crimea
all
way
to
city
of
Kerch
By
time
of
dissolution
of
Soviet
Union
Crimean
Oblast
was
favorite
vacation
spot
for
top
Communist
official
from
whole
Soviet
Union
and
in
Foros
during
August
Putch
at
his
gosdacha
stayed
president
of
Soviet
Union
Mikhail
Gorbachev
In
political
sanctions
against
Crimean
Tatars
in
Soviet
Union
were
lifted
and
they
started
to
return
to
their
homeland
In
as
part
of
so
called
NovoOgarevo
process
reorganization
of
Soviet
Union
in
Crimean
Oblast
was
organized
referendum
on
revival
of
autonomy
but
not
with
its
lost
title
nation
After
August
putsch
in
Crimea
was
conducted
another
referendum
about
Ukrainian
independence
In
in
Crimea
ensued
conflict
around
Black
Sea
Fleet
which
was
based
out
of
Sevastopol
which
threatened
to
get
escalated
into
armed
conflict
In
Russian
parliament
adopted
official
statement
About
status
of
Sevastopol
City
where
it
laid
territorial
claims
against
Ukraine
despite
constitutions
of
both
Ukraine
and
Russia
as
well
as
friendship
treaty
The
issue
was
brought
to
Security
Council
In
there
took
place
so
called
Tuzla
Island
conflict
United
States
and
Puerto
Ricoedit
The
relationship
between
United
States
and
Puerto
Rico
is
federacy
Puerto
Rico
residents
are
United
States
citizens
and
may
freely
travel
between
US
mainland
and
Puerto
Rico
Residents
of
Puerto
Rico
are
exempt
from
some
federal
taxes
Puerto
Ricos
autonomy
is
granted
by
Congress
Federal
taxes
do
not
automatically
apply
to
Puerto
Rico
unless
Government
of
Puerto
Rico
wants
them
to
Although
US
government
has
full
say
over
its
foreign
policy
Puerto
Rico
does
maintain
direct
contacts
with
its
Caribbean
neighbors
Puerto
Rico
does
not
have
full
voting
representation
in
US
Congress
nor
do
its
people
vote
for
electors
in
US
presidential
elections
Uzbekistan
and
Karakalpakstanedit
Karakalpakstan
is
autonomous
republic
that
occupies
whole
western
portion
of
Uzbekistan
Comparison
to
other
systems
of
autonomyedit
Associated
statesedit
Main
article
Associated
state
A
federacy
also
differs
from
associated
state
such
as
Federated
States
of
Micronesia
Marshall
Islands
and
Palau
in
free
association
with
United
States
and
Cook
Islands
and
Niue
which
form
part
of
Realm
of
New
Zealand
There
are
two
kinds
of
associated
states
in
case
of
Federated
States
of
Micronesia
Marshall
Islands
and
Palau
association
is
concluded
by
treaty
between
two
sovereign
states
in
case
of
Cook
Islands
and
Niue
association
is
concluded
by
domestic
legal
arrangements
Asymmetric
federationsedit
Main
article
Asymmetric
federalism
In
asymmetric
federation
one
of
substates
has
more
independence
than
others
Examples
of
this
are
Canada
where
Quebec
has
been
given
political
deference
to
craft
independent
language
and
education
policies
Some
unitary
states
such
as
Spain
and
United
Kingdom
may
also
be
regarded
as
asymmetric
federations
For
example
in
Spain
Basque
Country
Catalonia
and
Galicia
later
also
Andalusia
Aragon
Balearic
Islands
Canary
Islands
Navarre
Valencia
etc
have
been
granted
greater
autonomy
and
political
deference
than
rest
of
Spanish
autonomous
communities
see
nationalities
and
regions
of
Spain
The
difference
between
asymmetric
federation
and
federacy
is
indistinct
federacy
is
essentially
extreme
case
of
asymmetric
federation
either
due
to
large
differences
in
level
of
autonomy
or
rigidity
of
constitutional
arrangements
British
Overseas
Territoriesedit
Main
article
British
Overseas
Territories
The
British
Overseas
Territories
are
vested
with
varying
degrees
of
power
some
enjoy
considerable
independence
from
United
Kingdom
which
only
takes
care
of
their
foreign
relations
and
defence
However
they
are
neither
considered
to
be
part
of
United
Kingdom
nor
recognised
as
sovereign
or
associated
states
Crown
dependenciesedit
Main
article
Crown
dependencies
The
relations
between
United
Kingdom
and
Crown
dependencies
ie
Isle
of
Man
and
bailiwicks
of
Guernsey
and
Jersey
in
Channel
Islands
are
very
similar
to
federate
relation
Islands
enjoy
independence
from
United
Kingdom
which
via
The
Crown
takes
care
of
their
foreign
relations
and
defence
although
UK
Parliament
does
have
overall
power
to
legislate
for
dependencies
However
islands
are
neither
incorporated
part
of
United
Kingdom
nor
are
they
considered
to
be
independent
or
associated
states
The
Isle
of
Man
does
not
have
monarch
but
Queen
Elizabeth
II
holds
position
of
Lord
of
Mann
Devolutionedit
A
federacy
differs
from
devolved
state
such
as
Denmark
Spain
and
United
Kingdom
because
in
devolved
state
central
government
can
revoke
independence
of
subunits
eg
Scottish
Parliament
National
Assembly
for
Wales
Northern
Ireland
Assembly
in
case
of
UK
without
changing
constitution
Criticismsedit
Jaime
Lluch
has
critiqued
classification
and
description
of
federacy
as
used
by
Elazar
and
Watts
Lluch
argues
that
category
of
federacy
is
misapplied
to
case
of
Puerto
Rico
and
to
other
comparable
cases
and
that
it
is
example
of
conceptual
stretching
He
finds
that
federacies
is
in
end
not
helpful
category
to
understanding
types
of
institutional
arrangements
referred
and
recommends
that
scholars
of
comparative
federalism
need
to
find
more
nuanced
category
to
describe
contemporary
actuallyexisting
autonomies
such
as
Puerto
Rico
Lluch
shows
that
federacies
have
little
to
do
with
federalism
and
are
in
fact
distinct
status
arrangements
that
are
more
properly
seen
as
autonomies
of
which
there
is
wide
variety
This
variety
includes
autonomies
which
are
classified
along
continuum
that
would
take
several
federacies
and
reclassify
them
thus
Autonomies
in
Unitary
States
Corsica
Aland
Islands
Faroe
Islands
Crimea
and
Gagauzia
Nonfederal
autonomies
in
federal
political
systems
which
he
defines
as
systems
having
two
or
more
levels
of
government
which
combine
elements
of
sharedrule
through
common
institutions
and
regional
selfrule
for
governments
of
constituent
units
This
broad
category
includes
spectrum
of
polities
including
unions
constitutionally
decentralized
unions
federations
confederations
and
associated
states
Puerto
Rico
Northern
Marianas
Guam
Nunavut
Isle
of
Man
Jersey
Guernsey
Devolutionary
autonomies
in
federal
political
systems
Scotland
Wales
Northern
Ireland
South
Tyrol
Valle
dAosta
Sardinia
Sicily
and
FriuliVenezia
Giulia
Semifederal
autonomies
in
federal
political
systems
Catalonia
Basque
Country
and
Galicia
The
case
of
Puerto
Ricoedit
In
examining
Puerto
Rico
case
Lluch
notes
that
although
Elazar
has
mischaracterized
nature
of
Puerto
RicoUSA
relationship
it
is
still
cited
as
prototype
of
federacy
Lluch
defines
Puerto
Rico
as
nonfederal
autonomy
which
is
officially
unincorporated
territory
belonging
to
federal
political
system
that
is
USA
and
subject
to
plenary
powers
of
US
Congress
under
Territorial
Clause
of
US
Constitution
and
states
that
it
is
not
freeassociated
state
Similar
conclusions
were
made
by
three
Presidential
Task
Forces
on
Puerto
Ricos
Status
in
and
In
particular
Lluch
notes
that
contrary
to
Elazars
assertions
in
his
and
works
power
to
terminate
or
modify
Puerto
RicoUSA
relationship
rests
squarely
on
US
Congress
and
that
US
government
contends
that
sovereignty
over
Puerto
Rico
resides
solely
in
United
States
and
not
in
people
of
Puerto
Rico
Lluch
notes
that
both
Watts
and
Elazar
define
federacy
as
political
arrangements
where
large
unit
is
linked
to
smaller
unit
or
units
but
smaller
unit
retains
considerable
autonomy
and
has
minimum
role
in
government
of
larger
one
and
where
relationship
can
be
dissolved
only
by
mutual
agreement
However
contrary
to
this
definition
he
notes
that
far
from
having
minimum
role
in
government
of
United
States
Puerto
Rico
has
no
effective
representation
in
Congress
except
for
token
representative
that
has
no
right
to
vote
there
Nor
do
residents
of
Puerto
Rico
vote
for
US
President
However
Puerto
Ricans
are
eligible
to
join
US
political
parties
and
both
major
parties
conduct
primary
elections
for
national
positions
in
Puerto
Rico
Puerto
Rico
thus
has
no
direct
representation
in
institutions
of
central
state
He
notes
that
essentially
Puerto
RicoUSA
relationship
exhibits
some
elements
of
empire
and
nearly
none
of
federalism
Puerto
Rico
is
better
conceptualized
as
exemplar
of
autonomism
with
category
of
federacy
being
less
helpful
to
explain
it

alsoedit

realm

Feudalism

Feudalism
From
Wikipedia
free
encyclopedia
Jump
to
navigation
Jump
to
search
Combination
of
legal
and
military
customs
and
form
of
government
in
medieval
Europe
This
article
is
about
classic
medieval
Western
European
form
of
feudalism
For
feudalism
as
practised
in
other
societies
as
well
as
that
of
Europeans
see
Examples
of
feudalism
Investiture
of
knight
miniature
from
statutes
of
Order
of
Knot
founded
in
by
Louis
I
of
Naples
Orava
Castle
in
Slovakia
A
Medieval
castle
is
traditional
symbol
of
feudal
society
Feudalism
also
known
as
feudal
system
was
combination
of
legal
economic
military
and
cultural
customs
that
flourished
in
Medieval
Europe
between
th
and
th
centuries
Broadly
defined
it
was
way
of
structuring
society
around
relationships
that
were
derived
from
holding
of
land
in
exchange
for
service
or
labor
Although
it
is
derived
from
Latin
word
feodum
or
feudum
fief
which
was
used
during
Medieval
period
term
feudalism
and
system
which
it
describes
were
not
conceived
of
as
formal
political
system
by
people
who
lived
during
Middle
Ages
The
classic
definition
by
FranoisLouis
Ganshof
describes
set
of
reciprocal
legal
and
military
obligations
which
existed
among
warrior
nobility
and
revolved
around
three
key
concepts
of
lords
vassals
and
fiefs
A
broader
definition
of
feudalism
as
described
by
Marc
Bloch
includes
not
only
obligations
of
warrior
nobility
but
obligations
of
all
three
estates
of
realm
nobility
clergy
and
peasantry
all
of
whom
were
bound
by
system
of
manorialism
this
is
sometimes
referred
to
as
feudal
society
Since
publication
of
Elizabeth
A
R
Browns
The
Tyranny
of
Construct
and
Susan
Reynoldss
Fiefs
and
Vassals
there
has
been
ongoing
inconclusive
discussion
among
medieval
historians
as
to
whether
feudalism
is
useful
construct
for
understanding
medieval
society

Definitionedit
There
is
no
commonly
accepted
modern
definition
of
feudalism
at
least
among
scholars
The
adjective
feudal
was
in
use
by
at
least
and
noun
feudalism
now
often
employed
in
political
and
propagandistic
context
was
coined
by
paralleling
French
fodalit
feudality
According
to
classic
definition
by
FranoisLouis
Ganshof
feudalism
describes
set
of
reciprocal
legal
and
military
obligations
which
existed
among
warrior
nobility
and
revolved
around
three
key
concepts
of
lords
vassals
and
fiefs
though
Ganshof
himself
noted
that
his
treatment
was
only
related
to
narrow
technical
legal
sense
of
word
A
broader
definition
as
described
in
Marc
Blochs
Feudal
Society
includes
not
only
obligations
of
warrior
nobility
but
obligations
of
all
three
estates
of
realm
nobility
clergy
and
those
who
lived
off
their
labor
most
directly
peasantry
which
was
bound
by
system
of
manorialism
this
order
is
often
referred
to
as
feudal
society
echoing
Blochs
usage
Outside
its
European
context
concept
of
feudalism
is
often
used
by
analogy
most
often
in
discussions
of
feudal
Japan
under
shoguns
and
sometimes
in
discussions
of
Zagwe
dynasty
in
medieval
Ethiopia
which
had
some
feudal
characteristics
sometimes
called
semifeudal
Some
have
taken
feudalism
analogy
further
seeing
feudalism
or
traces
of
it
in
places
as
diverse
as
China
during
Spring
and
Autumn
period
BCE
ancient
Egypt
Parthian
Empire
Indian
subcontinent
and
Antebellum
and
Jim
Crow
American
South
The
term
feudalism
has
also
been
appliedoften
inappropriately
or
pejorativelyto
nonWestern
societies
where
institutions
and
attitudes
which
are
similar
to
those
which
existed
in
medieval
Europe
are
perceived
to
prevail
Some
historians
and
political
theorists
believe
that
term
feudalism
has
been
deprived
of
specific
meaning
by
many
ways
it
has
been
used
leading
them
to
reject
it
as
useful
concept
for
understanding
society
Etymologyedit
Herr
Reinmar
von
Zweter
thcentury
Minnesinger
was
depicted
with
his
noble
arms
in
Codex
Manesse
The
root
of
term
feudal
originates
in
Aryan
word
peku
meaning
cattle
and
possessed
cognates
in
many
other
IndoEuropean
languages
Sanskrit
pacu
cattle
Latin
pecus
cf
pecunia
cattle
money
Old
High
German
fehu
fihu
cattle
property
money
Old
Frisian
fia
Old
Saxon
fehu
Old
English
feoh
fioh
feo
fee
The
term
fodal
was
first
used
in
thcentury
French
legal
treatises
and
translated
into
English
legal
treatises
as
adjective
such
as
feodal
government
In
th
century
Adam
Smith
seeking
to
describe
economic
systems
effectively
coined
forms
feudal
government
and
feudal
system
in
his
book
Wealth
of
Nations
The
phrase
feudal
system
appeared
in
in
Baronia
Anglica
published
nine
years
after
death
of
its
author
Thomas
Madox
in
In
in
his
History
of
Manchester
John
Whitaker
first
introduced
word
feudalism
and
notion
of
feudal
pyramid
The
term
feudal
or
feodal
is
derived
from
medieval
Latin
word
feodum
The
etymology
of
feodum
is
complex
with
multiple
theories
some
suggesting
Germanic
origin
most
widely
held
view
and
others
suggesting
Arabic
origin
Initially
in
medieval
Latin
European
documents
land
grant
in
exchange
for
service
was
called
beneficium
Latin
Later
term
feudum
or
feodum
began
to
replace
beneficium
in
documents
The
first
attested
instance
of
this
is
from
although
more
primitive
forms
were
seen
up
to
onehundred
years
earlier
The
origin
of
feudum
and
why
it
replaced
beneficium
has
not
been
well
established
but
there
are
multiple
theories
described
below
The
most
widely
held
theory
was
proposed
by
Johan
Hendrik
Caspar
Kern
in
being
supported
by
amongst
others
William
Stubbs
and
Marc
Bloch
Kern
derived
word
from
putative
Frankish
term
fehud
in
which
fehu
means
cattle
and
d
means
goods
implying
moveable
object
of
value
Bloch
explains
that
by
beginning
of
th
century
it
was
common
to
value
land
in
monetary
terms
but
to
pay
for
it
with
moveable
objects
of
equivalent
value
such
as
arms
clothing
horses
or
food
This
was
known
as
feos
term
that
took
on
general
meaning
of
paying
for
something
in
lieu
of
money
This
meaning
was
then
applied
to
land
itself
in
which
land
was
used
to
pay
for
fealty
such
as
to
vassal
Thus
old
word
feos
meaning
movable
property
changed
little
by
little
to
feus
meaning
exact
opposite
landed
property
It
has
also
been
suggested
that
word
comes
from
Gothic
faihu
meaning
property
specificallycattle
Another
theory
was
put
forward
by
Archibald
R
Lewis
Lewis
said
origin
of
fief
is
not
feudum
or
feodum
but
rather
foderum
earliest
attested
use
being
in
Astronomuss
Vita
Hludovici
In
that
text
is
passage
about
Louis
Pious
that
says
annona
militaris
quas
vulgo
foderum
vocant
which
can
be
translated
as
Louis
forbade
that
military
provender
which
they
popularly
call
fodder
be
furnished
Another
theory
by
Alauddin
Samarrai
suggests
Arabic
origin
from
fuy
plural
of
fay
which
literally
means
returned
and
was
used
especially
for
land
that
has
been
conquered
from
enemies
that
did
not
fight
Samarrais
theory
is
that
early
forms
of
fief
include
feo
feu
feuz
feuum
and
others
plurality
of
forms
strongly
suggesting
origins
from
loanword
The
first
use
of
these
terms
is
in
Languedoc
one
of
least
Germanic
areas
of
Europe
and
bordering
Muslim
Spain
Further
earliest
use
of
feuum
as
replacement
for
beneficium
can
be
dated
to
same
year
Muslim
base
at
Fraxinetum
La
GardeFreinet
in
Provence
was
established
It
is
possible
Samarrai
says
that
French
scribes
writing
in
Latin
attempted
to
transliterate
Arabic
word
fuy
plural
of
fay
which
was
being
used
by
Muslim
invaders
and
occupiers
at
time
resulting
in
plurality
of
forms
feo
feu
feuz
feuum
and
others
from
which
eventually
feudum
derived
Samarrai
however
also
advises
to
handle
this
theory
with
care
as
Medieval
and
Early
Modern
Muslim
scribes
often
used
etymologically
fanciful
roots
in
order
to
claim
most
outlandish
things
to
be
of
Arabian
or
Muslim
origin
Historyedit
Feudalism
in
its
various
forms
usually
emerged
as
result
of
decentralization
of
empire
especially
in
Carolingian
Empire
in
th
century
AD
which
lacked
bureaucratic
infrastructureclarification
needed
necessary
to
support
cavalry
without
allocating
land
to
these
mounted
troops
Mounted
soldiers
began
to
secure
system
of
hereditary
rule
over
their
allocated
land
and
their
power
over
territory
came
to
encompass
social
political
judicial
and
economic
spheres
These
acquired
powers
significantly
diminished
unitary
power
in
these
empires
However
once
infrastructure
to
maintain
unitary
power
was
reestablishedas
with
European
monarchiesfeudalism
began
to
yield
to
this
new
power
structure
and
eventually
disappeared
Classic
feudalismedit
See
also
Feudalism
in
England
Feudalism
in
Holy
Roman
Empire
and
Examples
of
feudalism
The
classic
FranoisLouis
Ganshof
version
of
feudalism
describes
set
of
reciprocal
legal
and
military
obligations
which
existed
among
warrior
nobility
revolving
around
three
key
concepts
of
lords
vassals
and
fiefs
In
broad
terms
lord
was
noble
who
held
land
vassal
was
person
who
was
granted
possession
of
land
by
lord
and
land
was
known
as
fief
In
exchange
for
use
of
fief
and
protection
by
lord
vassal
would
provide
some
sort
of
service
to
lord
There
were
many
varieties
of
feudal
land
tenure
consisting
of
military
and
nonmilitary
service
The
obligations
and
corresponding
rights
between
lord
and
vassal
concerning
fief
form
basis
of
feudal
relationship
Vassalageedit
Homage
of
ClermontenBeauvaisis
Before
lord
could
grant
land
fief
to
someone
he
had
to
make
that
person
vassal
This
was
done
at
formal
and
symbolic
ceremony
called
commendation
ceremony
which
was
composed
of
twopart
act
of
homage
and
oath
of
fealty
During
homage
lord
and
vassal
entered
into
contract
in
which
vassal
promised
to
fight
for
lord
at
his
command
whilst
lord
agreed
to
protect
vassal
from
external
forces
Fealty
comes
from
Latin
fidelitas
and
denotes
fidelity
owed
by
vassal
to
his
feudal
lord
Fealty
also
refers
to
oath
that
more
explicitly
reinforces
commitments
of
vassal
made
during
homage
Such
oath
follows
homage
Once
commendation
ceremony
was
complete
lord
and
vassal
were
in
feudal
relationship
with
agreed
obligations
to
one
another
The
vassals
principal
obligation
to
lord
was
to
aid
or
military
service
Using
whatever
equipment
vassal
could
obtain
by
virtue
of
revenues
from
fief
vassal
was
responsible
to
answer
calls
to
military
service
on
behalf
of
lord
This
security
of
military
help
was
primary
reason
lord
entered
into
feudal
relationship
In
addition
vassal
could
have
other
obligations
to
his
lord
such
as
attendance
at
his
court
whether
manorial
baronial
both
termed
court
baron
or
at
kings
court
France
in
late
th
century
mosaic
of
feudal
territories
It
could
also
involve
vassal
providing
counsel
so
that
if
lord
faced
major
decision
he
would
summon
all
his
vassals
and
hold
council
At
level
of
manor
this
might
be
fairly
mundane
matter
of
agricultural
policy
but
also
included
sentencing
by
lord
for
criminal
offences
including
capital
punishment
in
some
cases
Concerning
kings
feudal
court
such
deliberation
could
include
question
of
declaring
war
These
are
examples
depending
on
period
of
time
and
location
in
Europe
feudal
customs
and
practices
varied
see
examples
of
feudalism
The
Feudal
Revolution
in
Franceedit
In
its
origin
feudal
grant
of
land
had
been
seen
in
terms
of
personal
bond
between
lord
and
vassal
but
with
time
and
transformation
of
fiefs
into
hereditary
holdings
nature
of
system
came
to
be
seen
as
form
of
politics
of
land
expression
used
by
historian
Marc
Bloch
The
th
century
in
France
saw
what
has
been
called
by
historians
feudal
revolution
or
mutation
and
fragmentation
of
powers
Bloch
that
was
unlike
development
of
feudalism
in
England
or
Italy
or
Germany
in
same
period
or
later
Counties
and
duchies
began
to
break
down
into
smaller
holdings
as
castellans
and
lesser
seigneurs
took
control
of
local
lands
and
as
comital
families
had
done
before
them
lesser
lords
usurpedprivatized
wide
range
of
prerogatives
and
rights
of
state
most
importantly
highly
profitable
rights
of
justice
but
also
travel
dues
market
dues
fees
for
using
woodlands
obligations
to
use
lords
mill
etc
what
Georges
Duby
called
collectively
seigneurie
banale
Power
in
this
period
became
more
personal
This
fragmentation
of
powers
was
not
however
systematic
throughout
France
and
in
certain
counties
such
as
Flanders
Normandy
Anjou
Toulouse
counts
were
able
to
maintain
control
of
their
lands
into
th
century
or
later
Thus
in
some
regions
like
Normandy
and
Flanders
vassalfeudal
system
was
effective
tool
for
ducal
and
comital
control
linking
vassals
to
their
lords
but
in
other
regions
system
led
to
significant
confusion
all
more
so
as
vassals
could
and
frequently
did
pledge
themselves
to
two
or
more
lords
In
response
to
this
idea
of
liege
lord
was
developed
where
obligations
to
one
lord
are
regarded
as
superior
in
th
century
End
of
European
feudalism
sedit
Further
information
Abolition
of
feudalism
in
France
Most
of
military
aspects
of
feudalism
effectively
ended
by
about
This
was
partly
since
military
shifted
from
armies
consisting
of
nobility
to
professional
fighters
thus
reducing
nobilitys
claim
on
power
but
also
because
Black
Death
reduced
nobilitys
hold
over
lower
classes
Vestiges
of
feudal
system
hung
on
in
France
until
French
Revolution
of
s
and
system
lingered
on
in
parts
of
Central
and
Eastern
Europe
as
late
as
s
Slavery
in
Romania
was
abolished
in
Russia
finally
abolished
serfdom
in
Even
when
original
feudal
relationships
had
disappeared
there
were
many
institutional
remnants
of
feudalism
left
in
place
Historian
Georges
Lefebvre
explains
how
at
early
stage
of
French
Revolution
on
just
one
night
of
August
France
abolished
longlasting
remnants
of
feudal
order
It
announced
The
National
Assembly
abolishes
feudal
system
entirely
Lefebvre
explains
Without
debate
Assembly
enthusiastically
adopted
equality
of
taxation
and
redemption
of
all
manorial
rights
except
for
those
involving
personal
servitudewhich
were
to
be
abolished
without
indemnification
Other
proposals
followed
with
same
success
equality
of
legal
punishment
admission
of
all
to
public
office
abolition
of
venality
in
office
conversion
of
tithe
into
payments
subject
to
redemption
freedom
of
worship
prohibition
of
plural
holding
of
benefices
Privileges
of
provinces
and
towns
were
offered
as
last
sacrifice
Originally
peasants
were
supposed
to
pay
for
release
of
seigneurial
dues
these
dues
affected
more
than
quarter
of
farmland
in
France
and
provided
most
of
income
of
large
landowners
The
majority
refused
to
pay
and
in
obligation
was
cancelled
Thus
peasants
got
their
land
free
and
also
no
longer
paid
tithe
to
church
Feudal
societyedit
Main
article
Manorialism
Depiction
of
socage
on
royal
demesne
in
feudal
England
c
The
phrase
feudal
society
as
defined
by
Marc
Bloch
offers
wider
definition
than
Ganshofs
and
includes
within
feudal
structure
not
only
warrior
aristocracy
bound
by
vassalage
but
also
peasantry
bound
by
manorialism
and
estates
of
Church
Thus
feudal
order
embraces
society
from
top
to
bottom
though
powerful
and
welldifferentiated
social
group
of
urban
classes
came
to
occupy
distinct
position
to
some
extent
outside
classic
feudal
hierarchy
Historiographyedit
The
idea
of
feudalism
was
unknown
and
system
it
describes
was
not
conceived
of
as
formal
political
system
by
people
living
in
Medieval
Period
This
section
describes
history
of
idea
of
feudalism
how
concept
originated
among
scholars
and
thinkers
how
it
changed
over
time
and
modern
debates
about
its
use
Evolution
of
conceptedit
English
feudalism
Harold
Sacramentum

of

court

tenure

and

and

Tallage
Feudalism
v
t
e
The
concept
of
feudal
state
or
period
in
sense
of
either
regime
or
period
dominated
by
lords
who
possess
financial
or
social
power
and
prestige
became
widely
held
in
middle
of
th
century
as
result
of
works
such
as
Montesquieus
De
LEsprit
des
Lois
published
in
English
as
The
Spirit
of
Laws
and
Henri
de
Boulainvillierss
Histoire
des
anciens
Parlements
de
France
published
in
English
as
An
Historical
Account
of
Ancient
Parliaments
of
France
or
StatesGeneral
of
Kingdom
In
th
century
writers
of
Enlightenment
wrote
about
feudalism
to
denigrate
antiquated
system
of
Ancien
Rgime
or
French
monarchy
This
was
Age
of
Enlightenment
when
writers
valued
reason
and
Middle
Ages
were
viewed
as
Dark
Ages
Enlightenment
authors
generally
mocked
and
ridiculed
anything
from
Dark
Ages
including
feudalism
projecting
its
negative
characteristics
on
current
French
monarchy
as
means
of
political
gain
For
them
feudalism
meant
seigneurial
privileges
and
prerogatives
When
French
Constituent
Assembly
abolished
feudal
regime
in
August
this
is
what
was
meant
Adam
Smith
used
term
feudal
system
to
describe
social
and
economic
system
defined
by
inherited
social
ranks
each
of
which
possessed
inherent
social
and
economic
privileges
and
obligations
In
such
system
wealth
derived
from
agriculture
which
was
arranged
not
according
to
market
forces
but
on
basis
of
customary
labour
services
owed
by
serfs
to
landowning
nobles
Karl
Marxedit
Karl
Marx
also
used
term
in
th
century
in
his
analysis
of
societys
economic
and
political
development
describing
feudalism
or
more
usually
feudal
society
or
feudal
mode
of
production
as
order
coming
before
capitalism
For
Marx
what
defined
feudalism
was
power
of
ruling
class
aristocracy
in
their
control
of
arable
land
leading
to
class
society
based
upon
exploitation
of
peasants
who
farm
these
lands
typically
under
serfdom
and
principally
by
means
of
labour
produce
and
money
rents
Marx
thus
defined
feudalism
primarily
by
its
economic
characteristics
He
also
took
it
as
paradigm
for
understanding
powerrelationships
between
capitalists
and
wagelabourers
in
his
own
time
in
precapitalist
systems
it
was
obvious
that
most
people
did
not
control
their
own
destinyunder
feudalism
for
instance
serfs
had
to
work
for
their
lords
Capitalism
seems
different
because
people
are
in
theory
free
to
work
for
themselves
or
for
others
as
they
choose
Yet
most
workers
have
as
little
control
over
their
lives
as
feudal
serfs
Some
later
Marxist
theorists
eg
Eric
Wolf
have
applied
this
label
to
include
nonEuropean
societies
grouping
feudalism
together
with
Imperial
Chinese
and
preColumbian
Incan
societies
as
tributary
Later
studiesedit
Feudal
titles
and
status
Lord
paramountTerritorial
lord
Tenantinchief
Mesne
lord
Lord
of
manorOverlordVogtLiege
lord
EsquireGentlemanLanded
gentry

tenantHusbandman
SerfVilleinbordarcottar
