servant
Vagabond
Slave
v
t
e
In
late
th
and
early
th
centuries
John
Horace
Round
and
Frederic
William
Maitland
both
historians
of
medieval
Britain
arrived
at
different
conclusions
as
to
character
of
English
society
before
Norman
Conquest
in
Round
argued
that
Normans
had
brought
feudalism
with
them
to
England
while
Maitland
contended
that
its
fundamentals
were
already
in
place
in
Britain
before
The
debate
continues
today
but
consensus
viewpoint
is
that
England
before
Conquest
had
commendation
which
embodied
some
of
personal
elements
in
feudalism
while
William
Conqueror
introduced
modified
and
stricter
northern
French
feudalism
to
England
incorporating
oaths
of
loyalty
to
king
by
all
who
held
by
feudal
tenure
even
vassals
of
his
principal
vassals
holding
by
feudal
tenure
meant
that
vassals
must
provide
quota
of
knights
required
by
king
or
money
payment
in
substitution
In
th
century
two
outstanding
historians
offered
still
more
widely
differing
perspectives
The
French
historian
Marc
Bloch
arguably
most
influential
thcentury
medieval
historian
approached
feudalism
not
so
much
from
legal
and
military
point
of
view
but
from
sociological
one
presenting
in
Feudal
Society
English
feudal
order
not
limited
solely
to
nobility
It
is
his
radical
notion
that
peasants
were
part
of
feudal
relationship
that
sets
Bloch
apart
from
his
peers
while
vassal
performed
military
service
in
exchange
for
fief
peasant
performed
physical
labour
in
return
for
protection
both
are
form
of
feudal
relationship
According
to
Bloch
other
elements
of
society
can
be
seen
in
feudal
terms
all
aspects
of
life
were
centered
on
lordship
and
so
we
can
speak
usefully
of
feudal
church
structure
feudal
courtly
and
anticourtly
literature
and
feudal
economy
In
contradistinction
to
Bloch
Belgian
historian
FranoisLouis
Ganshof
defined
feudalism
from
narrow
legal
and
military
perspective
arguing
that
feudal
relationships
existed
only
within
medieval
nobility
itself
Ganshof
articulated
this
concept
in
Questce
que
la
fodalit
What
is
feudalism
translated
in
English
as
Feudalism
His
classic
definition
of
feudalism
is
widely
accepted
today
among
medieval
scholars
though
questioned
both
by
those
who
view
concept
in
wider
terms
and
by
those
who
find
insufficient
uniformity
in
noble
exchanges
to
support
such
model
Although
he
was
never
formally
student
in
circle
of
scholars
around
Marc
Bloch
and
Lucien
Febvre
that
came
to
be
known
as
Annales
School
Georges
Duby
was
exponent
of
Annaliste
tradition
In
published
version
of
his
doctoral
thesis
entitled
La
socit
aux
XIe
et
XIIe
sicles
dans
la
rgion
mconnaise
Society
in
th
and
th
centuries
in
Mconnais
region
and
working
from
extensive
documentary
sources
surviving
from
Burgundian
monastery
of
Cluny
as
well
as
dioceses
of
Mcon
and
Dijon
Duby
excavated
complex
social
and
economic
relationships
among
individuals
and
institutions
of
Mconnais
region
and
charted
profound
shift
in
social
structures
of
medieval
society
around
year
He
argued
that
in
early
th
century
governing
institutionsparticularly
comital
courts
established
under
Carolingian
monarchythat
had
represented
public
justice
and
order
in
Burgundy
during
th
and
th
centuries
receded
and
gave
way
to
new
feudal
order
wherein
independent
aristocratic
knights
wielded
power
over
peasant
communities
through
strongarm
tactics
and
threats
of
violence
In
Austrian
historian
Theodor
Mayer
de
subordinated
feudal
state
as
secondary
to
his
concept
of
Personenverbandsstaat
personal
interdependency
state
understanding
it
in
contrast
to
territorial
state
This
form
of
statehood
identified
with
Holy
Roman
Empire
is
described
as
most
complete
form
of
medieval
rule
completing
conventional
feudal
structure
of
lordship
and
vassalage
with
personal
association
between
nobility
But
applicability
of
this
concept
to
cases
outside
of
Holy
Roman
Empire
has
been
questioned
as
by
Susan
Reynolds
The
concept
has
also
been
questioned
and
superseded
in
German
histography
because
of
its
bias
and
reductionism
towards
legitimating
Fhrerprinzip
Challenges
to
feudal
modeledit
In
American
historian
Elizabeth
A
R
Brown
rejected
label
feudalism
as
anachronism
that
imparts
false
sense
of
uniformity
to
concept
Having
noted
current
use
of
many
often
contradictory
definitions
of
feudalism
she
argued
that
word
is
only
construct
with
no
basis
in
medieval
reality
invention
of
modern
historians
read
back
tyrannically
into
historical
record
Supporters
of
Brown
have
suggested
that
term
should
be
expunged
from
history
textbooks
and
lectures
on
medieval
history
entirely
In
Fiefs
and
Vassals
The
Medieval
Evidence
Reinterpreted
Susan
Reynolds
expanded
upon
Browns
original
thesis
Although
some
contemporaries
questioned
Reynoldss
methodology
other
historians
have
supported
it
and
her
argument
Reynolds
argues
Too
many
models
of
feudalism
used
for
comparisons
even
by
Marxists
are
still
either
constructed
on
thcentury
basis
or
incorporate
what
in
Marxist
view
must
surely
be
superficial
or
irrelevant
features
from
it
Even
when
one
restricts
oneself
to
Europe
and
to
feudalism
in
its
narrow
sense
it
is
extremely
doubtful
whether
feudovassalic
institutions
formed
coherent
bundle
of
institutions
or
concepts
that
were
structurally
separate
from
other
institutions
and
concepts
of
time
The
term
feudal
has
also
been
applied
to
nonWestern
societies
in
which
institutions
and
attitudes
similar
to
those
of
medieval
Europe
are
perceived
to
have
prevailed
See
Examples
of
feudalism
Japan
has
been
extensively
studied
in
this
regard
Friday
notes
that
in
st
century
historians
of
Japan
rarely
invoke
feudalism
instead
of
looking
at
similarities
specialists
attempting
comparative
analysis
concentrate
on
fundamental
differences
Ultimately
critics
say
many
ways
term
feudalism
has
been
used
have
deprived
it
of
specific
meaning
leading
some
historians
and
political
theorists
to
reject
it
as
useful
concept
for
understanding
society
Richard
Abels
notes
that
Western
Civilization
and
World
Civilization
textbooks
now
shy
away
from
term
feudalism

alsoedit

v
t
e
Meritocracy
merit
from
Latin
mere
and
cracy
from
Ancient
Greek
kratos
strength
power
is
political
system
in
which
economic
goods
andor
political
power
are
vested
in
individual
people
on
basis
of
talent
effort
and
achievement
rather
than
wealth
or
social
class
Advancement
in
such
system
is
based
on
performance
as
measured
through
examination
or
demonstrated
achievement
Although
concept
of
meritocracy
has
existed
for
centuries
term
itself
was
coined
in
by
sociologist
Michael
Dunlop
Young
in
his
dystopian
political
and
satirical
book
The
Rise
of
Meritocracy
Contents
Definitions
Early
definitions
More
recent
definitions
Etymology
History
Ancient
times
China
th
century
spread
to
Europe
th
century
West
Africa
th
century
th
century
to
today
Modern
meritocratic
movements
The
Meritocracy
Party
Criticism
See
also
Notes
References
Further
reading
External
links
Definitionsedit
Early
definitionsedit
The
most
common
definition
of
meritocracy
conceptualizes
merit
in
terms
of
tested
competency
and
ability
and
most
likely
as
measured
by
IQ
or
standardized
achievement
tests
In
government
and
other
administrative
systems
meritocracy
refers
to
system
under
which
advancement
within
system
turns
on
merits
like
performance
intelligence
credentials
and
education
These
are
often
determined
through
evaluations
or
examinationspage
needed
In
more
general
sense
meritocracy
can
refer
to
any
form
of
evaluation
based
on
achievement
Like
utilitarian
and
pragmatic
word
meritocratic
has
also
developed
broader
connotation
and
is
sometimes
used
to
refer
to
any
government
run
by
ruling
or
influential
class
of
educated
or
able
people
This
is
in
contrast
to
original
condemnatory
use
of
term
in
by
Michael
Dunlop
Young
in
his
work
The
Rise
of
Meritocracy
who
was
satirizing
ostensibly
meritbased
Tripartite
System
of
education
practiced
in
United
Kingdom
at
time
he
claimed
that
in
Tripartite
System
merit
is
equated
with
intelligencepluseffort
its
possessors
are
identified
at
early
age
and
selected
for
appropriate
intensive
education
and
there
is
obsession
with
quantification
testscoring
and
qualifications
Meritocracy
in
its
wider
sense
may
be
any
general
act
of
judgment
upon
basis
of
various
demonstrated
merits
such
acts
frequently
are
described
in
sociology
and
psychology
In
rhetoric
demonstration
of
ones
merit
regarding
mastery
of
particular
subject
is
essential
task
most
directly
related
to
Aristotelian
term
Ethos
The
equivalent
Aristotelian
conception
of
meritocracy
is
based
upon
aristocratic
or
oligarchic
structures
rather
than
in
context
of
modern
state
More
recent
definitionsedit
In
United
States
assassination
of
President
James
A
Garfield
in
prompted
replacement
of
American
Spoils
System
with
meritocracy
In
The
Pendleton
Civil
Service
Reform
Act
was
passed
stipulating
government
jobs
should
be
awarded
on
basis
of
merit
through
competitive
exams
rather
than
ties
to
politicians
or
political
affiliation
The
most
common
form
of
meritocratic
screening
found
today
is
college
degree
Higher
education
is
imperfect
meritocratic
screening
system
for
various
reasons
such
as
lack
of
uniform
standards
worldwide
lack
of
scope
not
all
occupations
and
processes
are
included
and
lack
of
access
some
talented
people
never
have
opportunity
to
participate
because
of
expense
most
especially
in
developing
countries
Nonetheless
academic
degrees
serve
some
amount
of
meritocratic
screening
purpose
in
absence
of
more
refined
methodology
Education
alone
however
does
not
constitute
complete
system
as
meritocracy
must
automatically
confer
power
and
authority
which
degree
does
not
accomplish
independentlycitation
needed
Etymologyedit
Although
concept
has
existed
for
centuries
term
meritocracy
is
relatively
new
It
was
used
pejoratively
by
British
politician
and
sociologist
Michael
Dunlop
Young
in
his
satirical
essay
The
Rise
of
Meritocracy
which
pictured
United
Kingdom
under
rule
of
government
favouring
intelligence
and
aptitude
merit
above
all
else
being
combination
of
root
of
Latin
origin
merit
from
mere
meaning
earn
and
Ancient
Greek
suffix
cracy
meaning
power
rule
The
purely
Greek
word
is
axiocracy
from
axios
worthy
cracy
power
In
this
book
term
had
distinctly
negative
connotations
as
Young
questioned
both
legitimacy
of
selection
process
used
to
become
member
of
this
elite
and
outcomes
of
being
ruled
by
such
narrowly
defined
group
The
essay
written
in
first
person
by
fictional
historical
narrator
in
interweaves
history
from
politics
of
pre
and
postwar
Britain
with
those
of
fictional
future
events
in
short
onward
and
long
term
onward
The
essay
was
based
upon
tendency
of
thencurrent
governments
in
their
striving
toward
intelligence
to
ignore
shortcomings
and
upon
failure
of
education
systems
to
utilize
correctly
gifted
and
talented
members
within
their
societies
Youngs
fictional
narrator
explains
that
on
one
hand
greatest
contributor
to
society
is
not
stolid
mass
or
majority
but
creative
minority
or
members
of
restless
elite
On
other
hand
he
claims
that
there
are
casualties
of
progress
whose
influence
is
underestimated
and
that
from
such
stolid
adherence
to
natural
science
and
intelligence
arises
arrogance
and
complacency
This
problem
is
encapsulated
in
phrase
Every
selection
of
one
is
rejection
of
many
It
was
also
used
by
Hannah
Arendt
in
her
essay
Crisis
in
Education
which
was
written
in
and
refers
to
use
of
meritocracy
in
English
educational
system
She
too
uses
term
pejoratively
It
was
not
until
that
Daniel
Bell
used
term
positively
Historyedit
Ancient
times
Chinaedit
Further
information
Chinese
Legalism
According
to
scholarly
consensus
earliest
example
of
administrative
meritocracy
based
on
civil
service
examinations
dates
back
to
Ancient
China
The
concept
originates
at
least
by
sixth
century
BC
when
it
was
advocated
by
Chinese
philosopher
Confucius
who
invented
notion
that
those
who
govern
should
do
so
because
of
merit
not
of
inherited
status
This
sets
in
motion
creation
of
imperial
examinations
and
bureaucracies
open
only
to
those
who
passed
tests
As
Qin
and
Han
dynasties
developed
meritocratic
system
in
order
to
maintain
power
over
large
sprawling
empire
it
became
necessary
for
government
to
maintain
complex
network
of
officials
Prospective
officials
could
come
from
rural
background
and
government
positions
were
not
restricted
to
nobility
Rank
was
determined
by
merit
through
civil
service
examinations
and
education
became
key
for
social
mobility
After
fall
of
Han

The

meritocracy
was
originally
intended
as
negative
concept
One

with

is
unclear
definition
of
merit
What
is
considered
as

can
differ
with
opinions
as
on
which

are

most
worthy

question

which

is
highestor

is
best
standard
As
supposed
effectiveness
of
meritocracy
is
based
on
supposed
competence
of
its
officials
this
standard
of
merit
cannot
be

and
has
to
also
reflect
competencies
required

authority

concern

against
system

as
rule
by
intelligence
has
been
applied
to
many
ancient
Greek
Indian
Chinese
and
Jewish
thinkers
and
statesmen
For
example
Sanhedrin
legislature
of
Ancient
Israel
and
Kingdom
of
Judah
is
sometimes
called
as
intellectual
meritocracy
in
sense
that
its
members
were
drawn
from
religious
scribes
and
not
aristocracy
Appointment
was
selfperpetuating
however
and
new
members
were
chosen
personally
by
existing
members
These
are
not
meritocracies
in
administrative
sense
in
which
merit
is
determined
objectively
as
tested
competency
or
ability

and

Francis
p
most
common
definition
of
meritocracy
conceptualizes
merit
in
terms
tested
competency
and
power
and
most
likely
as
measured
by
IQ
or
standardized
achievement
tests

Monarchy
Wikipedia
Monarchy
From
Wikipedia
free
encyclopedia
Jump
to
navigation
Jump
to
search
System
of
government
where
head
of
state
is
single
person
who
holds
position
for
life
or
until
abdication
For
other
uses
see
Monarchy
disambiguation

alDawla
Governmental
Lala
Agha
Hazinedar
Mostowfi
olMamalek
v
t
e
Richard
I
of
England
being
anointed
during
his
coronation
in
Westminster
Abbey
from
thcentury
chronicle
A
monarchy
is
form
of
government
in
which
person
monarch
is
head
of
state
for
life
or
until
abdication
The
political
legitimacy
and
authority
of
monarch
may
vary
from
purely
symbolic
crowned
republic
to
restricted
constitutional
monarchy
to
fully
autocratic
absolute
monarchy
and
can
expand
across
domains
of
executive
legislative
and
judicial
A
monarchy
can
be
polity
through
unity
personal
union
vassalage
or
federation
and
monarchs
can
carry
various
titles
such
as
emperor
king
queen
raja
khan
caliph
tsar
sultan
shah
or

The
word
monarch
Late
Latin
monarchia
comes
from
Ancient
Greek
word
monrkhs
derived
from
mnos
one
single
and
rkh
to
rule
compare
rkhn
ruler
chief
It
referred
to
single
at
least
nominally
absolute
ruler
In
current
usage
word
monarchy
usually
refers
to
traditional
system
of
hereditary
rule
as
elective
monarchies
are
quite
rare
Historyedit

WeldBlundell

Sumerian

The
similar
form

societal

known
as

or

is
prehistoric

provided
concept
of
state
formation
which
started
with

such
as
Mesopotamia
Ancient

and
Indus
Valley
Civilization
In
some

of

monarchies
Some
of

and

monarchies
were

of

and
Enmebaragesi

of

c

From

times
with

Sudanic
reconstructed

religion
and
others

functions

to

or

In

primarily

function
The

from

thing

to

of

The

continued
to

considered
living
Gods
into
modern
periodcitation
needed
Polybius
identified
monarchy
as
one
of
three
benign
basic
forms
of
government
monarchy
aristocracy
and
democracy
opposed
to
three
malignant
basic
forms
of
government
tyranny
oligarchy
and
ochlocracy
The
monarch
in
classical
antiquity
is
often
identified
as
king
or
ruler
translating
archon
basileus
rex
tyrannos
etc
or
as
queen
basilinna
Polybius
originally
understood
monarchynote
as
component
of
republics
but
since
antiquity
monarchy
has
contrasted
with
forms
of
republic
where
executive
power
is
wielded
by
free
citizens
and
their
assemblies
The
thcentury
BCE
Hindu
text
Arthasastra
laid
out
ethics
of
monarchism
In
antiquity
some
monarchies
were
abolished
in
favour
of
such
assemblies
in
Rome
Roman
Republic
BCE
and
Athens
Athenian
democracy
BCE
Map
of
monarchies
and
republics
in
By
th
century

was
challenged
by
evolving
parliamentarism
eg
through
regional

such
as
Icelandic
Commonwealth
Swiss
Landsgemeinde
and
later
Tagsatzung
and
High
Medieval
communal
movement
linked
to
rise
of
medieval
town
privileges
and
by
modern
antimonarchism
eg
of
temporary
overthrow
of
English
monarchy
by
Parliament
of
England
in
American
Revolution
of
and
French
Revolution
of
One
of
many
opponents
of
that
trend
was
Elizabeth
Dawbarn
whose
anonymous
Dialogue
between
Clara
Neville
and
Louisa
Mills
on

features
silly
Louisa
who
admires
liberty
Tom
Paine
and
USA
who
is
lectured
by
Clara
on
Gods
approval
of
monarchy
and
on
influence
women
can
exert
on
men
Since
then
advocacy
of
abolition
of
monarchy
or
respectively
of
republics
has
been
called
republicanism
while
advocacy
of
monarchies
is
called
monarchism
As
such
republics
have
become
opposing
and
alternative
form
of
government
to
monarchy
despite
some
having
seen
infringements
through
lifelong
or
even
hereditary
heads
of
state
With
rise
of
republicanism
diverse
division
between
republicanism
developed
in
thcentury
politics
such
as
antimonarchist
radicalism
and
conservative
or
even
reactionary
monarchism
In
following
th
century
many
countries
abolished
monarchy
and
became
republics
especially
in
wake
of
World
War
I
and
World
War
II
Today
fortyfive
sovereign
nations
in
world
have
monarch
including
sixteen
Commonwealth
realms
that
have
Elizabeth
II
as
head
of
state
Most
modern
monarchs
are
constitutional
monarchs
who
retain
unique
legal
and
ceremonial
role
but
exercise
limited
or
no
political
power
under
constitution
Many
are
socalled
crowned
republics
surviving
particularly
in
small
states
In
some
nations
however
such
as
Brunei
Morocco
Oman
Qatar
Saudi
Arabia
Eswatini
and
Thailand
hereditary
monarch
has
more
political
influence
than
any
other
single
source
of
authority
in
state
either
by
convention
or
by
constitutional
mandate
According
to
study
monarchy
arose
as
system
of
governance
because
of
efficiency
in
governing
large
populations
and
expansive
territories
during
periods
when
coordinating
such
populations
was
difficult
The
authors
argue
that
monarchy
declined
as
efficient
regime
type
with
innovations
in
communications
and
transportation
technology
as
efficiency
of
monarchy
relative
to
other
regime
types
declined
Characteristics
and
roleedit
King
George
III
of
United
Kingdom
Portrait
by
Allan
Ramsay
Monarchies
are
associated
with
hereditary
reign
in
which
monarchs
reign
for
lifenote
and
responsibilities
and
power
of
position
pass
to
their
child
or
another
member
of
their
family
when
they
die
Most
monarchs
both
historically
and
in
modern
day
have
been
born
and
brought
up
within
royal
family
centre
of
royal
household
and
court
Growing
up
in
royal
family
called
dynasty
when
it
continues
for
several
generations
future
monarchs
are
often
trained
for
their
expected
future
responsibilities
as
monarch
Different
systems
of
hereditary
succession
have
been
used
such
as
proximity
of
blood
primogeniture
and
agnatic
seniority
Salic
law
While
most

in

have
been
male
many

reigned
The
term
queen
regnant
refers
to
ruling

while

to

of
reigning
king
Rule
may
be
hereditary
in
practice
without
being
considered
monarchy
there
have

some

and
also
political

The
principal
advantage
of
hereditary
monarchy
is
immediate
continuity
of
leadership
as
evidenced
in
classic
phrase
The
King
is
dead
Long
live
King
Some
monarchies
are
not
hereditary
In
elective
monarchy
monarchs
are
elected
or
appointed
by
some
body
electoral
college
for
life
or
defined
period
Four
elective
monarchies
exist
today
Cambodia
Malaysia
and
United
Arab
Emirates
are
thcentury
creations
while
one
papacy
is
ancient
A
selfproclaimed
monarchy
is
established
when
person
claims
monarchy
without
any
historical
ties
to
previous
dynasty
There
are
examples
of
republican
leaders
who
have
proclaimed
themselves
monarchs
Napoleon
I
of
France
declared
himself
Emperor
of
French
and
ruled
First
French
Empire
after
having
held
title
of
First

of
French
Republic
for
five

from

seizing
power
in
coup
of
Brumaire
President
JeanBdel

in
Yuan
Shikai
first
formal

of
Republic

of

of

few

after
Republic
of
China
was
founded
Powers
of
monarchedit
King
Salman
of
Saudi
Arabia
is
absolute
monarch
In
absolute
monarchy
monarch
rules
as
autocrat
with
absolute
power
over
state
and
governmentfor
example
right
to
rule
by
decree
promulgate
laws
and
impose
punishments
In
constitutional
monarchy
monarchs
power
is
subject
to
constitution
In
most
current
constitutional
monarchies
monarch
is
mainly
ceremonial
figurehead
symbol
of
national
unity
and
state
continuity
Although
nominally
sovereign
electorate
through
legislature
exercises
political
sovereignty
Constitutional
monarchs
political
power
is
limited
Typical
monarchical
powers
include
granting
pardons
granting
honours
and
reserve
powers
eg
to
dismiss
prime
minister
refuse
to
dissolve
parliament
or
veto
legislation
withhold
Royal
Assent
They
often
also
have
privileges
of
inviolability
and
sovereign
immunity
A
monarchs
powers
and
influence
will
depend
on
tradition
precedent
popular
opinion
and
law
Semiconstitutional
monarchies
exhibit
fewer
parliamentary
powers
or
simply
monarchs
with
more
authority
The
term
parliamentary
monarchy
may
be
used
to
differentiate
from
semiconstitutional
monarchies
Monarchical
reign
has
often
been
linked
with
military
authority
In
late
Roman
Empire
Praetorian
Guard
several
times
deposed
Roman
Emperors
and
installed
new
emperors
Similarly
in
Abbasid
Caliphate
Ghilmans
slave
soldiers
deposed
Caliphs
once
they
became
prominent
allowing
new
ones
to
come
to
power
The
Hellenistic
kings
of
Macedon
and
of
Epirus
were
elected
by
army
which
was
similar
in
composition
to
ecclesia
of
democracies
council
of
all
free
citizens
military
service
was
often
linked
with
citizenship
among
male
members
of
royal
house
The
military
has
dominated
monarch
in
modern
Thailand
and
in
medieval
Japan
where
hereditary
military
chief
shgun
was
de
facto

although
Japanese

nominally
reigned

Most

only

single

at

although
two

have
ruled

in

situation
known
as
diarchy
Historically
this
was
case
in
ancient

of

There

parent
and

coprincipality

of

It

only

independent
countrys

is

by

In

union

may

claimant
to
abolished
throne
or

is
act

formally

monarchical

and

Monarchs

Role
of
monarchedit
Monarchy
especially
absolute
monarchy
is
sometimes
linked
to
religious
aspects
many
monarchs
once
claimed
right
to
rule
by
will
of
deity
Divine
Right
of
Kings
Mandate
of
Heaven
or
special
connection
to
deity
sacred
king
or
even
purported
to
be
divine
kings
or
incarnations
of
deities
themselves
imperial
cult
Many
European
monarchs
have
been
styled
Fidei
defensor
Defender
of
Faith
some
hold
official
positions
relating
to
state
religion
or
established
church
In
Western
political
tradition
morally
based
balanced
monarchy
was
stressed
as
ideal
form
of
government
and
little
attention
was
paid
to
modernday
ideals
of
egalitarian
democracy
eg
Saint
Thomas
Aquinas
unapologetically
declared
Tyranny
is
wont
to
occur
not
less
but
more
frequently
on
basis
of
polyarchy
rule
by
many
ie
oligarchy
or
democracy
than
on
basis
of
monarchy
On
Kingship
However
Thomas
Aquinas
also
stated
that
ideal
monarchical
system
would
also
have
at
lower
levels
of
government
both
aristocracy
and
elements
of
democracy
in
order
to
create
balance
of
power
The
monarch
would
also
be
subject
to
both
natural
and
divine
law
and
to
Church
in
matters
of
religion
In
Dante
Alighieris
De
Monarchia
spiritualised
imperial
Catholic
monarchy
is
strongly
promoted
according
to
Ghibelline
worldview
in
which
royal
religion
of
Melchizedek
is
emphasised
against
priestly
claims
of
rival
papal
ideology
In
Saudi
Arabia
king
is
head
of
state
who
is
both
absolute
monarch
of
country
and
Custodian
of
Two
Holy
Mosques
of
Islam

of

II

of

castle

have

title
pharaoh
for

and

in

Statehoodedit
Monarchies
predate
polities
like
nation
states
and
even
territorial
states
A
nation
or
constitution
is
not
necessary
in
monarchy
since
person
monarch
binds
separate
territories
and
political
legitimacy
eg
in
personal
union
together
Monarchies
though
have
applied
state
symbols
like
insignia
or
abstracts
like
concept
of
Crown
to
create
state
identity
which
is
to
be
carried
and
occupied
by
monarch
but
represents
monarchy
even
in
absence
and
succession
of
monarch
Nevertheless

can
also
be
bound
to

eg
King
of
Norway
and
peoples

of

Hereditary
monarchiesedit
Current
European
monarchies
by
succession
method
Absolute
primogeniture
Malepreference
cognatic
primogeniture
to
be
changed
to
absolute
primogeniture
Malepreference
cognatic
primogeniture
Agnatic
primogeniture
Elective
In
hereditary
monarchy
position
of
monarch
is
inherited
according
to
statutory
or
customary
order
of
succession
usually
within
one
royal
family
tracing
its
origin
through
historical
dynasty
or
bloodline
This
usually
means
that
heir
to
throne
is
known
well
in
advance
of
becoming
monarch
to
ensure
smooth
succession
Primogeniture
in
which
eldest
child
of
monarch
is
first
in
line
to
become
monarch
is
most
common
system
in
hereditary
monarchy
The
order
of
succession
is
usually
affected
by
rules
on
gender
Historically
agnatic
primogeniture
or
patrilineal
primogeniture
was
favoured
that
is
inheritance
according
to
seniority
of
birth
among
sons
of
monarch
or
head
of
family
with
sons
and
their
male
issue
inheriting
before
brothers
and
their
issue
and
maleline
males
inheriting
before
females
of
male
line
This
is
same
as
semiSalic
primogeniture
Complete
exclusion
of
females
from
dynastic
succession
is
commonly
referred
to
as
application
of
Salic
law
see
Terra
salica
Before
primogeniture
was
enshrined
in
European
law
and
tradition
kings
would
often
secure
succession
by
having
their
successor
usually
their
eldest
son
crowned
during
their
own
lifetime
so
for
time
there
would
be
two
kings
in
coregency
senior
king
and
junior
king
Examples
were
Henry
Young
King
of
England
and
early
Direct
Capetians
in
France
Sometimes
however
primogeniture
can
operate
through
female
line
King
Leopold
I
elected
founder
of
hereditary
monarchy
of
Belgium
In

first

declare
equal
full
cognatic
primogeniture
meaning
that
eldest
child
of
monarch
whether
female
or
male
ascends
to
throne
Other
kingdoms
such
as
Netherlands

Belgium

and

have

equal

subject
to

of
existing

on

following
agreement
by

Commonwealth

of
children
next
most

member

line
for

younger

previous

becomes
monarch

next
in

primogeniture

often

Elective

Pope
Francis
Sovereign
of
Vatican
City
State
In
elective
monarchy
monarchs
are
elected
or
appointed
by
somebody
electoral
college
for
life
or
defined
period
but
then
reign
like
any
other
monarch
There
is
no
popular
vote
involved
in
elective
monarchies
as
elective
body
usually
consists
of
small
number
of
eligible
people
Historical
examples
of
elective
monarchy
are
Holy
Roman
Emperors
chosen
by
princeelectors
but
often
coming
from
same
dynasty
and
free
election
of
kings
of
PolishLithuanian
Commonwealth
For
example
Pepin
Short
father
of
Charlemagne
was
elected
King
of
Franks
by
assembly
of
Frankish
leading
men
nobleman
Stanisaw
August
Poniatowski
of
Poland
was
elected
king
as
was
Frederick
I
of
Denmark
Germanic
peoples
also
had
elective
monarchies
Six
forms
of
elective
monarchies
exist
today
The
pope
of
Roman
Catholic
Church
who
rules
as
Sovereign
of
Vatican
City
State
is
elected
for
life
by
College
of
Cardinals
In
Sovereign

of
Malta

and

is
elected
for
life
tenure
by

Complete
of
State
from
within
its
members
In

king
called

or

is
elected
for
fiveyear
term
from
among
and
by

rulers
mostly
sultans
of
nine
of

states

its

is
President

French

in
form
of
CoPrince

is
only

different

and

Systems
of
government
Republican
forms
of
government
Presidential
republics
with
executive
presidency
separate
from
legislature
Semipresidential
system
with
both
executive
presidency
and
separate
head
of
government
that
leads
rest
of
executive
who
is
appointed
by
president
and
accountable
to
legislature
Parliamentary
republics
with
ceremonial
and
nonexecutive
president
where
separate
head
of
government
leads
executive
and
is
dependent
on
confidence
of
legislature
Republics
in
which
combined
head
of
state
and
government
is
elected
by
or
nominated
by
legislature
and
may
or
may
not
be
subject
to
parliamentary
confidence
Monarchical
forms
of
government
Constitutional
monarchies
with
ceremonial
and
nonexecutive
monarch
where
separate
head
of
government
leads
executive
Semiconstitutional
monarchies
with
ceremonial
monarch
but
where
royalty
still
hold
significant
executive
or
legislative
power
Absolute

where
monarch
leads
executive
Oneparty
states
in
principle
republics
Countries
where

provisions
for
government
have
been
suspended

any
of
above
systems
eg
provisional
government
or
unclear
political
situations

categories

European

The

and

Monaco

substantial

gave

of

Landtag

while

any
law
that
Prince
tries
to
pass
The
prince
can
appoint
or
dismiss
any
elective
member
or
government
employee
However
he
is
not
absolute
monarch
as
people
can
call
for
referendum
to
end
monarchs
reign
When
Hereditary
Prince
Alois
threatened
to
veto
referendum
to
legalize
abortion
in
it
came
as
surprise
because
prince
had
not
vetoed
any
law
for
over
yearsnote
The
prince
of
Monaco
has
simpler
powers
he
cannot
appoint
or
dismiss
any
elective
member
or
government
employee
to
or
from
his
or
her
post
but
he
can
elect
minister
of
state
government
council
and
judges
Both
Albert
II
Prince
of
Monaco
and
HansAdam
II
Prince
of
Liechtenstein
are
theoretically
very
powerful
within
their
small
states
but
they
have
very
limited
power
compared
to
Islamic
monarchs
see
below
They
also
own
huge
tracts
of
land
and
are
shareholders
in
many
companies
Islamic
monarchiesedit
The
Islamic
monarchs
of
Kingdom
of
Bahrain
State
of
Brunei
Darussalam
Hashemite
Kingdom
of
Jordan
State
of
Kuwait
Malaysia
Kingdom
of
Morocco
Sultanate
of
Oman
State
of
Qatar
Kingdom
of
Saudi
Arabia
and
United
Arab
Emirates
generally
retain
far
more
powers
than
their
European
or
Commonwealth
counterparts
Brunei
Darussalam
Oman
Qatar
and
Saudi
Arabia
remain
absolute
monarchies
Bahrain
Kuwait
and
United
Arab
Emirates
are
classified
as
mixed
meaning
there
are
representative
bodies
of
some
kind
but
monarch
retains
most
of
his
powers
Jordan
Malaysia
and
Morocco
are
constitutional
monarchies
but
their
monarchs
still
retain
more
substantial
powers
than
European
equivalents
East
and
Southeast
Asian
constitutional
monarchiesedit
The
Kingdom
of
Bhutan
Kingdom
of
Cambodia
Kingdom
of
Thailand
and
Japan
are
constitutional
monarchies
where
monarch
has
limited
or
merely
ceremonial
role
Japan
changed
from
traditional
absolute
monarchy
into
constitutional
one
during
th
century
and
Bhutan
made
change
in
Cambodia
had
its
own
monarchy
after
independence
from
French
Colonial
Empire
but
it
was
deposed
after
Khmer
Rouge
came
into
power
The
monarchy
was
subsequently
restored
in
peace
agreement
of
Thailand
transitioned
into
constitutional
monarchy
over
course
of
th
Century
Other
monarchiesedit
Five
monarchies
do
not
fit
into
any
of
above
groups
by
virtue
of
geography
or
class
of
monarchy
Kingdom
of
Tonga
in
Polynesia
Kingdom
of
Eswatini
and
Kingdom
of
Lesotho
in
Africa
Vatican
City
State
in
Europe
and
Sovereign
Military
Order
of
Malta
Of
these
Lesotho
and
Tonga
are
constitutional
monarchies
while
Eswatini
and
Vatican
City
are
absolute
monarchies
Eswatini
is
unique
among
these
monarchies
often
being
considered
diarchy
King
or
Ngwenyama
rules
alongside
his
mother
Ndlovukati
as
dual
heads
of
statecitation
needed
This
was
originally
intended
to
provide
check
on
political
power
The
Ngwenyama
however
is
considered
administrative
head
of
state
while
Ndlovukati
is
considered
spiritual
and
national
head
of
state
position
which
more
or
less
has
become
symbolic
in
recent
yearscitation
needed
The
Pope
is
absolute
monarch
of
Vatican
City
State
separate
entity
from
Holy
See
by
virtue
of
his
position
as
head
of
Roman
Catholic
Church
and
Bishop
of
Rome
he
is
elected
rather
than
hereditary
ruler
and
does
not
have
to
be
citizen
of
territory
prior
to
his
election
by
cardinalscitation
needed
The
Order
of
Malta
describes
itself
as
sovereign
subject
based
on
its
unique
history
and
unusual
present
circumstances
but
its
exact
status
in
international
law
is
subject
of
debate
Samoa
position
is
described
in
Part
III
of
Samoan
constitution
At
time
constitution
was
adopted
it
was
anticipated
that
future
heads
of
state
would
be
chosen
from
among
four
Tama
Aiga
royal
paramount
chiefs
However
this
is
not
required
by
constitution
so
for
this
reason
Samoa
can
be
considered
republic
rather
than
constitutional
monarchy
The
ruling
Kim
family
in
North
Korea
Kim
Ilsung
Kim
Jongil
and
Kim
Jongun
has
been
described
as
de
facto
absolute
monarchy
or
hereditary
dictatorship
In
Clause
of
Article
of
new
edited
Ten
Fundamental
Principles
of
Korean
Workers
Party
states
that
party
and
revolution
must
be
carried
eternally
by
Baekdu
Kims
bloodline
This
also
happened
in
Azerbaijan
when
Heydar
Aliyev
president
of
Azerbaijan
died
He
was
succeeded
by
his
son
Ilham
But
it
is
referred
as
Monarch
Presidentcitation
needed
See
alsoedit

portal

Notes
and
referencesedit
Notesedit
Now
substituted
with
concept
of
autocracy
Malaysia
is
special
case
Malaysias
head
of
state
Yang
diPertuan
Agong
often
translated
as
King
is
elected
to
serve
fiveyear
term
However
he
is
elected
from
among
federations
subnational
monarchies
each
of
whom
inherit
their
position
and
rule
for
life
Examples
are
Oliver
Cromwell
and
Richard
Cromwell
in
Commonwealth
of
England
Kim
ilSung
and
Kim
Jongil
in
North
Korea
Somoza
family
in
Nicaragua
Franois
Duvalier
and
JeanClaude
Duvalier
in
Haiti
and
Hafez
alAssad
and
Bashar
alAssad
in
Syria
For
example
Kennedy
family
in
United
States
and
NehruGandhi
family
in
India
See
list
of
political
families
In
end
this
referendum
failed
to
make
it
to
vote

Form
of
government
Antidefection
law
redirects
here
For
law
in
India
see
Antidefection
law
India
Worlds
states
coloured
by
form
of
government
Full
presidential
republics
Semipresidential
republics
Republics
with
executive
president
elected
by
or
nominated
by
legislature
that
may
or
may
not
be
subject
to
parliamentary
confidence
Parliamentary
republics
Parliamentary
constitutional
monarchies
Constitutional
monarchies
which
have
separate
head
of
government
but
where
royalty
still
holds
significant
executive
andor
legislative
power
Absolute
monarchies
Oneparty
states
Countries
where
constitutional
provisions
for
government
have
been
suspended
eg
military
dictatorships
Countries
which
do
not
fit
any
of
above
systems
eg
provisional
governments
This
map
was
compiled

Wikipedia

of
countries
by
system
of
government
See
there
for
sources
Several
states
constitutionally
deemed
to
be
multiparty
republics
are
broadly
described
by
outsiders
as
authoritarian
states
This
map
presents
only
de
jure
form
of
government
and
not
de
facto
degree
of
democracy
v
t
e

Heads

Politics
portal
v
t
e
A
parliamentary
system
or
parliamentary
democracy
is
system
of
democratic
governance
of
state
or
subordinate
entity
where
executive
derives
its
democratic
legitimacy
from
its
ability
to
command
confidence
of
legislature
typically
parliament
and
is
also
held
accountable
to
that
parliament
In
parliamentary
system
head
of
state
is
usually
person
distinct
from
head
of
government
This
is
in
contrast
to
presidential
system
where
head
of
state
often
is
also
head
of
government
and
most
importantly
where
executive
does
not
derive
its
democratic
legitimacy
from
legislature
Countries
with
parliamentary
democracies
may
be
constitutional
monarchies
where
monarch
is
head
of
state
while
head
of
government
is
almost
always
member
of
parliament
such
as
Denmark
Norway
Japan
Malaysia
Sweden
and
United
Kingdom
or
parliamentary
republics
where
mostly
ceremonial
president
is
head
of
state
while
head
of
government
is
regularly
from
legislature
such
as
Ireland
Germany
India
Italy
and
Singapore
In
few
parliamentary
republics
such
as
Botswana
Kiribati
and
South
Africa
among
some
others
head
of
government
is
also
head
of
state
but
is
elected
by
and
is
answerable
to
parliament
In
bicameral
parliaments
head
of
government
is
generally
though
not
always
member
of
lower
house
Parliamentarianism
is
dominant
form
of
government
in
Europe
with
of
its
sovereign
states
being
parliamentarian
It
is
also
common
in
Caribbean
being
form
of
government
of
of
its
island
states
and
in
Oceania
Elsewhere
in
world
parliamentary
countries
are
less
common
but
they
are
distributed
through
all
continents
most
often
in
former
colonies
of
British
Empire
that
subscribe
to
particular
brand
of
parliamentarianism
known
as
Westminster
system
Contents
History
Characteristics
Types
Westminster
system
Consensus
system

of
head
of
government
Power
of
dissolution
and
call
for
election
Antidefection
law

Adaptability
Scrutiny
and
accountability
Distribution
of
power
Calling
of
elections
Disadvantages
and
criticisms
Legislative
flipflopping
Party
fragmentation

Africa
Americas
Asia
Europe
Oceania

also

links
Historyedit
Further
information
History
of
Parliamentarism
Since
ancient
times
when
societies
were
tribal
there
were
councils
or
headman
whose
decisions
were
assessed
by
village
elders
Eventually
these
councils
have
slowly
evolved
into
modern
parliamentary
system
The
first
parliaments
date
back
to
Europe
in
Middle
Ages
specifically
in
Alfonso
IX
King
of
Leon
Spain
convened
three
states
in
Cortes
of
Len
An
early
example
of
parliamentary
government
developed
in
todays
Netherlands
and
Belgium
during
Dutch
revolt
when
sovereign
legislative
and
executive
powers
were
taken
over
by
States
General
of
Netherlands
from
monarch
King
Philip
II
of
Spaincitation
needed
The
modern
concept
of
parliamentary
government
emerged
in
Kingdom
of
Great
Britain
between
and
and
its
contemporary
Parliamentary
System
in
Sweden
between
and
In
England
Simon
de
Montfort
is
remembered
as
one
of
fathers
of
representative
government
for
convening
two
famous
parliaments
The
first
in
stripped
king
of
unlimited
authority
and
second
in
included
ordinary
citizens
from
towns
Later
in
th
century
Parliament
of
England
pioneered
some
of
ideas
and
systems
of
liberal
democracy
culminating
in
Glorious
Revolution
and
passage
of
Bill
of
Rights
In
Kingdom
of
Great
Britain
monarch
in
theory
chaired
cabinet
and
chose
ministers
In
practice
King
George
Is
inability
to
speak
English
led
responsibility
for
chairing
cabinet
to
go
to
leading
minister
literally
prime
or
first
minister
Robert
Walpole
The
gradual
democratisation
of
parliament
with
broadening
of
voting
franchise
increased
parliaments
role
in
controlling
government
and
in
deciding
whom
king
could
ask
to
form
government
By
th
century
Great
Reform
Act
of
led
to
parliamentary
dominance
with
its
choice
invariably
deciding
who
was
prime
minister
and
complexion
of
government
Other
countries
gradually
adopted
what
came
to
be
called
Westminster
Model
of
government
with
executive
answerable
to
parliament
and
exercising
in
name
of
head
of
state
powers
nominally
vested
in
head
of
state
Hence
use
of
phrases
like
Her
Majestys
government
or
His
Excellencys
government
Such
system
became
particularly
prevalent
in
older
British
dominions
many
of
which
had
their
constitutions
enacted
by
British
parliament
such
as
Australia
New
Zealand
Canada
Irish
Free
State
and
Union
of
South
Africa
Some
of
these
parliaments
were
reformed
from
or
were
initially
developed
as
distinct
from
their
original
British
model
Australian
Senate
for
instance
has
since
its
inception
more
closely
reflected
US
Senate
than
British
House
of
Lords
whereas
since
there
is
no
upper
house
in
New
Zealand
Democracy
and
parliamentarianism
became
increasingly
prevalent
in
Europe
in
years
after
World
War
I
partially
imposed
by
democratic
victorshow
United
States
Great
Britain
and
France
on
defeated
countries
and
their
successors
notably
Germanys
Weimar
Republic
and
new
Austrian
Republic
Nineteenthcentury
urbanisation
Industrial
Revolution
and
modernism
had
already
fuelled
political
lefts
struggle
for
democracy
and
parliamentarianism
for
long
time
In
radicalised
times
at
end
of
World
War
I
democratic
reforms
were
often
seen
as
means
to
counter
popular
revolutionary
currents
Characteristicsedit
This
section
needs
additional
citations
for
verification
Please
help
improve
this
article
by
adding
citations
to
reliable
sources
Unsourced
material
may
be
challenged
and
removed
January
Learn
how
and
when
to
remove
this
template
message
Further
information
Parliamentary
procedure
A
parliamentary
system
may
be
either
bicameral
with
two
chambers
of
parliament
or
houses
or
unicameral
with
just
one
parliamentary
chamber
A
bicameral
parliament
usually
consists
of
directly
elected
lower
house
with
power
to
determine
executive
government
and
upper
house
which
may
be
appointed
or
elected
through
different
mechanism
from
lower
house
Typesedit
Scholars
of
democracy
such
as
Arend
Lijphart
distinguish
two
types
of
parliamentary
democracies
Westminster
and
Consensus
systems
The
Palace
of
Westminster
in
London
United
Kingdom
The
Westminster
system
originates
from
British
Houses
of
Parliament
Westminster
systemedit
The
Reichstag
Building
in
Berlin
Germany
The
Consensus
system
is
used
in
most
Western
European
countries
The
Westminster
system
is
usually
found
in
Commonwealth
of
Nations
and
countries
which
were
influenced
by
British
political
tradition
These
parliaments
tend
to
have
more
adversarial
style
of
debate
and
plenary
session
of
parliament
is
more
important
than
committees
Some
parliaments
in
this
model
are
elected
using
plurality
voting
system
first
past
post
such
as
United
Kingdom
Canada
and
India
while
others
use
some
form
of
proportional
representation
such
as
Ireland
and
New
Zealand
The
Australian
House
of
Representatives
is
elected
using
instantrunoff
voting
while
Senate
is
elected
using
proportional
representation
through
single
transferable
vote
Regardless
of
which
system
is
used
voting
systems
tend
to
allow
voter
to
vote
for
named
candidate
rather
than
closed
list
Consensus
systemedit
The
Western
European
parliamentary
model
eg
Spain
Germany
tends
to
have
more
consensual
debating
system
and
usually
has
semicircular
debating
chambers
Consensus
systems
have
more
of
tendency
to
use
proportional
representation
with
open
party
lists
than
Westminster
Model
legislatures
The
committees
of
these
Parliaments
tend
to
be
more
important
than
plenary
chamber
Some
Western
European
countries
parliaments
eg
in
Netherlands
Luxembourg
and
Sweden
implement
principle
of
dualism
as
form
of
separation
of
powers
In
countries
using
this
system
Members
of
Parliament
have
to
resign
their
place
in
Parliament
upon
being
appointed
or
elected
minister
Ministers
in
those
countries
usually
actively
participate
in
parliamentary
debates
but
are
not
entitled
to
vote
Election
of
head
of
governmentedit
Implementations
of
parliamentary
system
can
also
differ
as
to
how
prime
minister
and
government
are
appointed
and
whether
government
needs
explicit
approval
of
parliament
rather
than
just
absence
of
its
disapproval
Some
countries
such
as
India
also
require
prime
minister
to
be
member
of
legislature
though
in
other
countries
this
only
exists
as
convention
The
head
of
state
appoints
prime
minister
who
will
likely
have
majority
support
in
parliament
While
in
practice
most
prime
ministers
under
Westminster
system
including
Australia
Canada
India
New
Zealand
and
United
Kingdom
are
leaders
of
largest
party
in
parliament
technically
appointment
of
prime
minister
is
prerogative
exercised
by
monarch
governorgeneral
or
president
No
parliamentary
vote
takes
place
on
who
is
forming
government
but
since
parliament
can
immediately
defeat
government
with
motion
of
no
confidence
head
of
state
is
limited
by
convention
to
choosing
candidate
who
can
command
confidence
of
parliament
and
thus
has
little
or
no
influence
in
decisioncitation
needed
The
head
of
state
appoints
prime
minister
who
must
gain
vote
of
confidence
within
set
time
Examples
Italy
Thailand
The
head
of
state
appoints
leader
of
political
party
holding
plurality
of
seats
in
parliament
as
prime
minister
For
example
in
Greece
if
no
party
has
majority
leader
of
party
with
plurality
of
seats
is
given
exploratory
mandate
to
receive
confidence
of
parliament
within
three
days
If
this
is
not
possible
then
leader
of
party
with
second
highest
seat
number
is
given
exploratory
mandate
If
this
fails
then
leader
of
third
largest
party
is
given
it
and
so
on
The
head
of
state
nominates
candidate
for
prime
minister
who
is
then
submitted
to
parliament
for
approval
before
appointment
Example
Spain
where
King
sends
proposal
to
Congress
of
Deputies
for
approval
Also
Germany
where
under
German
Basic
Law
constitution
Bundestag
votes
on
candidate
nominated
by
federal
president
In
these
casescitation
needed
parliament
can
choose
another
candidate
who
then
would
be
appointed
by
head
of
state
Parliament
nominates
candidate
whom
head
of
state
is
constitutionally
obliged
to
appoint
as
prime
minister
Example
Japan
where
Emperor
appoints
Prime
Minister
on
nomination
of
National
Diet
Also
Ireland
where
President
of
Ireland
appoints
Taoiseach
on
nomination
of
Dil
ireann
A
public
officeholder
other
than
head
of
state
or
their
representative
nominates
candidate
who
if
approved
by
parliament
is
appointed
as
prime
minister
Example
Under
Swedish
Instrument
of
Government
power
to
appoint
someone
to
form
government
has
been
moved
from
monarch
to
Speaker
of
Parliament
and
parliament
itself
The
speaker
nominates
candidate
who
is
then
elected
to
prime
minister
statsminister
by
parliament
if
absolute
majority
of
members
of
parliament
does
not
vote
no
ie
they
can
be
elected
even
if
more
members
of
parliament
vote
No
than
Yes
Direct
election
by
popular
vote
Example
Israel
where
prime
minister
was
elected
in
general
election
with
no
regard
to
political
affiliation
and
whose
procedure
can
also
be
described
as
of
semiparliamentary
system
Power
of
dissolution
and
call
for
electionedit
Furthermore
there
are
variations
as
to
what
conditions
exist
if
any
for
government
to
have
right
to
dissolve
parliament
In
some
countries
such
as
Denmark
Malaysia
Australia
and
New
Zealand
prime
minister
has
de
facto
power
to
call
election
at
will
This
was
also
case
in
United
Kingdom
until
passage
of
Fixedterm
Parliaments
Act
In
Spain
prime
minister
is
only
person
with
de
jure
power
to
call
election
granted
by
Article
of
Constitution
In
Israel
parliament
may
vote
in
order
to
call
election
or
pass
vote
of
no
confidence
against
government
Other
countries
only
permit
election
to
be
called
in
event
of
vote
of
no
confidence
against
government
supermajority
vote
in
favour
of
early
election
or
prolonged
deadlock
in
parliament
These
requirements
can
still
be
circumvented
For
example
in
Germany
in
Gerhard
Schrder
deliberately
allowed
his
government
to
lose
confidence
motion
in
order
to
call
early
election
In
Sweden
government
may
call
snap
election
at
will
but
newly
elected
Riksdag
is
only
elected
to
fill
out
previous
Riksdags
term
The
last
time
this
option
was
used
was
in
In
Greece
general
election
is
called
if
Parliament
fails
to
elect
new
head
of
state
when
his
or
her
term
ends
In
January
this
constitutional
provision
was
exploited
by
Syriza
to
trigger
snap
election
win
it
and
oust
rivals
New
Democracy
from
power
Norway
is
unique
among
parliamentary
systems
in
that
Storting
always
serves
whole
of
its
fouryear
term
Since
in
United
Kingdom
House
of
Commons
may
be
dissolved
early
only
by
vote
of
twothirds
of
its
members
or
if
vote
of
nonconfidence
passes
and
no
alternative
government
is
formed
in
next
fourteen
days
The
parliamentary
system
can
be
contrasted
with
presidential
system
which
operates
under
stricter
separation
of
powers
whereby
executive
does
not
form
part
ofnor
is
appointed
by
parliamentary
or
legislative
body
In
such
system
parliaments
or
congresses
do
not
select
or
dismiss
heads
of
governments
and
governments
cannot
request
early
dissolution
as
may
be
case
for
parliaments
There
also
exists
semipresidential
system
that
draws
on
both
presidential
systems
and
parliamentary
systems
by
combining
powerful
president
with
executive
responsible
to
parliament
for
example
French
Fifth
Republic
Parliamentarianism
may
also
apply
to
regional
and
local
governments
An
example
is
city
of
Oslo
which
has
executive
council
Byrd
as
part
of
parliamentary
system
Antidefection
lawedit
A
few
parliamentary
democratic
nations
such
as
India
Pakistan
Bangladesh
etc
have
enacted
law
which
prohibits
floor
crossing
or
switching
party
after
election
process
With
this
law
elected
representative
have
to
lose
their
seat
in
Parliament
House
if
they
defy
direction
of
party
in
any
voting
In
UK
Parliament
member
is
free
to
cross
over
to
other
side
without
being
daunted
by
any
disqualification
law
In
Canada
and
Australia
there
is
no
restraint
on
legislators
switching
sides
Advantagesedit
See
also
Presidential
system
Advantages
and
Presidential
system
Criticism
and
disadvantages
Supporters
generally
claim
three
basic
advantages
for
parliamentary
systems
Adaptability
Scrutiny
and
accountability
Distribution
of
power
Adaptabilityedit
Parliamentary
systems
like
that
found
in
United
Kingdom
are
widely
considered
to
be
more
flexible
allowing
rapid
change
in
legislation
and
policy
as
long
as
there
is
stable
majority
or
coalition
in
parliament
allowing
government
to
have
few
legal
limits
on
what
it
can
do
Due
to
firstpastpost
this
system
produces
classic
Westminster
Model
with
twin
virtues
of
strong
but
responsive
party
government
This
electoral
system
providing
strong
majority
in
House
of
Commons
paired
with
fused
power
system
results
in
particularly
powerful
Government
able
to
provide
change
and
innovate
Scrutiny
and
accountabilityedit
The
United
Kingdoms
fused
power
system
is
often
noted
to
be
advantageous
with
regards
to
accountability
The
centralised
government
allows
for
more
transparency
as
to
where
decisions
originate
from
this
directly
contrasts
with
United
States
system
with
former
Treasury
Secretary
C
Douglas
Dillon
saying
president
blames
Congress
Congress
blames
president
and
public
remains
confused
and
disgusted
with
government
in
Washington
Furthermore
ministers
of
UK
cabinet
are
subject
to
weekly
Question
Periods
in
which
their
actionspolicies
are
scrutinised
no
such
regular
check
on
government
exists
in
US
system
Distribution
of
poweredit
Parliamentary
government
has
attractive
features
for
nations
that
are
ethnically
racially
or
ideologically
divided
In
presidential
system
all
executive
power
is
vested
in
one
person
president
whereas
power
is
more
divided
in
parliamentary
system
with
its
collegial
executive
In
Lebanese
Taif
Agreement
in
order
to
give
Muslims
greater
political
power
Lebanon
moved
from
semipresidential
system
with
powerful
president
to
system
more
structurally
similar
to
classical
parliamentary
government
Iraq
similarly
disdained
presidential
system
out
of
fears
that
such
system
would
be
tantamount
to
Shiite
domination
of
large
Sunni
minority
Afghanistans
minorities
refused
to
go
along
with
presidency
as
strong
as
Pashtuns
desired
It
can
be
argued
that
power
is
more
evenly
spread
out
in
parliamentary
government
as
government
and
prime
minister
do
not
have
power
to
make
unilateral
decisions
as
entire
government
cabinet
is
answerable
and
accountable
to
parliament
Parliamentary
systems
are
less
likely
to
allow
celebritybased
politics
to
fully
dominate
society
unlike
what
often
happens
in
presidential
systems
where
namerecall
and
popularity
can
catapult
celebrity
actor
or
popular
politician
to
presidency
despite
such
candidates
lack
of
competence
and
experience
Some
scholars
like
Juan
Linz
Fred
Riggs
Bruce
Ackerman
and
Robert
Dahl
have
found
that
parliamentary
government
is
less
prone
to
authoritarian
collapse
These
scholars
point
out
that
since
World
War
II
twothirds
of
Third
World
countries
establishing
parliamentary
governments
successfully
made
transition
to
democracycitation
needed
By
contrast
no
Third
World
presidential
system
successfully
made
transition
to
democracy
without
experiencing
coups
and
other
constitutional
breakdownscitation
needed
A
World
Bank
study
found
that
parliamentary
systems
are
associated
with
less
corruption
which
is
supported
by
separate
study
that
arrived
at
same
conclusionscitation
needed
Calling
of
electionsedit
In
his
book
The
English
Constitution
Walter
Bagehot
praised
parliamentary
governments
for
producing
serious
debates
for
allowing
for
change
in
power
without
election
and
for
allowing
elections
at
any
time
Bagehot
considered
fouryear
election
rule
of
United
States
to
be
unnatural
as
it
can
potentially
allow
president
who
has
disappointed
public
with
dismal
performance
in
second
year
of
his
term
to
continue
on
until
end
of
his
fouryear
term
Under
parliamentary
system
prime
minister
that
has
lost
support
in
middle
of
his
term
can
be
easily
replaced
by
his
own
peers
Although
Bagehot
praised
parliamentary
governments
for
allowing
election
to
take
place
at
any
time
lack
of
definite
election
calendar
can
be
abused
Previously
under
some
systems
such
as
British
ruling
party
could
schedule
elections
when
it
felt
that
it
was
likely
to
retain
power
and
so
avoid
elections
at
times
of
unpopularity
Election
timing
in
UK
however
is
now
partly
fixed
under
Fixedterm
Parliaments
Act
Thus
by
shrewd
timing
of
elections
in
parliamentary
system
party
can
extend
its
rule
for
longer
than
is
feasible
in
functioning
presidential
system
This
problem
can
be
alleviated
somewhat
by
setting
fixed
dates
for
parliamentary
elections
as
is
case
in
several
of
Australias
state
parliaments
In
other
systems
such
as
Dutch
and
Belgian
ruling
party
or
coalition
has
some
flexibility
in
determining
election
date
Conversely
flexibility
in
timing
of
parliamentary
elections
can
avoid
periods
of
legislative
gridlock
that
can
occur
in
fixed
period
presidential
system
In
any
case
voters
ultimately
have
power
to
choose
whether
to
vote
for
ruling
party
or
someone
else
Disadvantages
and
criticismsedit
Critics
of
parliamentarianism
namely
proponents
of
antiparliamentarianism
or
antiparliamentarism
generally
claim
these
basic
disadvantages
for
parliamentary
systems
Legislative
flipflopping
Party
fragmentation
Legislative
flipfloppingedit
The
ability
for
strong
parliamentary
governments
to
push
legislation
through
with
ease
of
fused
power
systems
such
as
in
United
Kingdom
whilst
positive
in
allowing
rapid
adaptation
when
necessary
eg
nationalisation
of
services
during
world
wars
does
have
its
drawbacks
The
flipflopping
of
legislation
back
and
forth
as
majority
in
parliament
changed
between
Conservatives
and
Labour
over
period
contesting
over
nationalisation
and
privatisation
of
British
Steel
Industry
resulted
in
major
instability
for
British
steel
sector
Party
fragmentationedit
In
R
Kent
Weavers
book
Are
Parliamentary
Systems
Better
he
writes
that
advantage
of
presidential
systems
is
their
ability
to
allow
and
accommodate
more
diverse
viewpoints
He
states
that
because
legislators
are
not
compelled
to
vote
against
their
constituents
on
matters
of
local
concern
parties
can
serve
as
organizational
and
rollcall
cuing
vehicles
without
forcing
out
dissidents

Folketinget

of

candidate

Britain
pioneered
system
of
liberal
democracy
that
has
now
spread
in
one
form
or
another
to
most
of
worlds
countries
Constitutionalism
America
Beyond
Bureau
of
International
Information
Programs
IIP
US
Department
of
State
Archived
from
original
on
October
Retrieved
October
The
earliest
and
perhaps
greatest
victory
for
liberalism
was
achieved
in
England
The
rising
commercial
class
that
had
supported
Tudor
monarchy
in
th
century
led
revolutionary
battle
in
th
and
succeeded
in
establishing
supremacy
of
Parliament
and
eventually
of
House
of
Commons
What
emerged
as
distinctive
feature
of
modern
constitutionalism
was
not
insistence
on
idea
that
king
is
subject
to
law
although
this
concept
is
essential
attribute
of
all
constitutionalism
This
notion
was
already
well
established
in
Middle
Ages
What
was
distinctive
was
establishment
of
effective
means
of
political
control
whereby
rule
of
law
might
be
enforced
Modern
constitutionalism
was
born
with
political
requirement
that
representative
government
depended
upon
consent
of
citizen
subjects
However
as
can
be
seen
through
provisions
in
Bill
of
Rights
English
Revolution
was
fought
not
just
to
protect
rights
of
property
in
narrow
sense
but
to
establish
those
liberties
which
liberals
believed
essential
to
human
dignity
and
moral
worth
The
rights
of
man
enumerated
in
English
Bill
of
Rights
gradually
were
proclaimed
beyond
boundaries
of
England
notably
in
American
Declaration
of
Independence
of
and
in
French
Declaration
of
Rights
of
Man
in
Blick
Andrew
Jones
George
January

Institution
of

Minister
